	<item>
		<title>November 23 - A Day Without A Bag Takes Over San Diego County on December 16</title>
		<link>http://localhost/demodata/?p=42</link>
		<pubDate>Fri, 12 Nov 2010 08:00:00 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[saltdevelopment]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://localhost/demodata/?p=42</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<p>{readmorelink}Read the full article...{/readmorelink}</p>  <!--more-->  <p>San Diego, CA – Cities throughout the San Diego region, local community groups, environmental organizations, and the County of San Diego have proclaimed the third Thursday of December as “A Day Without a Bag” to raise awareness and promote a greener holiday season.  <br /><br />On Thursday, December 16, 2010, businesses and residents will promote or utilize reusable bags for their holiday and regular shopping needs instead of standard single-use plastic and paper bags.  <br /><br />“This is a community-wide event to support the development of behavior that is a more sustainable use of our resources by encouraging shoppers to choose reusable shopping bags over disposables. Reuse is far better than recycling – it prevents waste and litter, which in the end is the highest and best use of resources,” stated Regional Coordinator Jacy Bolden.<br /><br />Each year, people in the greater San Diego region use more than 1.7 billion plastic bags, which is about 500 bags per person annually.  According to the U.S. EPA, less than five percent of plastic bags are actually recycled, and they are made from non-renewable fossil fuels.  Even though paper bags are easily recycled in curbside programs, proponents of “A Day Without A Bag” stress that a single-use of any disposable bag is not the highest and best use of natural resources. <br /><br />Over the last two years the cities of Chula Vista, Encinitas, Oceanside and Solana Beach have shown that “Day Without A Bag” efforts in their communities have increased reusable bag use. <br /><br />“Day Without A Bag is going region-wide this year, and we’re thrilled to see such strong early support in coordinating this type of an event. Retailers in the cities that have carried this event out previously have indicated a 20-50% decrease in disposable bag usage. Clearly it’s an effective promotion,” noted Bolden. <br /><br />To make the event possible, retailers and volunteers will give away more than 25,000 reusable shopping bags, while supplies last, at over 100 locations throughout the county.  Retailers currently committed to participate in the event include: all Jimbo’s Natural Foods, Smart &amp; Final, Stater Bros Grocery,  and Target locations; SeaWorld stores; San Diego Padres Team Store; San Diego Zoo and Zoo Safari stores; select Albertsons, Ralphs and Walmart locations; as well as all major grocers in Encinitas, Oceanside and Solana Beach.  <br /><br />Beyond the above retailers, additional bags have been donated or provided by:  Chico Bags, EDCO Waste &amp; Recycling, EnviroSax, Republic/Allied Waste, Think Blue San Diego Region, Surfrider Foundation and the cities of Chula Vista, Encinitas, Lemon Grove, Poway, San Marcos and Santee.  Key financial and in-kind sponsors include SeaWorld, Sycuan Casino, San Diego Union Tribune, and the cities of Chula Vista, Encinitas, and Oceanside.  Environmental organizations coordinating volunteers and promotions countywide include:  San Diego Coastkeeper, I Love A Clean San Diego, Solana Center for Environmental Innovation and the San Diego Chapter of the Surfrider Foundation.<br /><br />Retailers and volunteers interested in participating can find more information about the event by visiting www.NoBagDaySD.org, which also includes a Google map with bag giveaway locations and times.<br />###</p>]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>December 10 - IPR Coalition Changes its Name to Water Reliability Coalition</title>
		<link>http://localhost/demodata/?p=43</link>
		<pubDate>Fri, 10 Dec 2010 18:47:11 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[saltdevelopment]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://localhost/demodata/?p=43</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<p>New name better reflects the mission of the diverse group</p> <p>{readmorelink}Read the full article...{/readmorelink}</p>  <!--more-->  <p>San Diego, Calif. – Friday, Dec. 10, 2010 –The IPR Coalition today has announced it has changed its name to the Water Reliability Coalition. A broad-based affiliation of environmental, consumer, business, labor, development, taxpayer and technical organizations, the Water Reliability Coalition selected the new name because it better matches its long-term goals to support the development of a safe, reliable, sustainable and cost-effective local water supply.<br /><br />The group currently focuses on supporting the recently approved City of San Diego Water Purification Demonstration Project, which will test the feasibility of treating wastewater to drinking water standards. The Coalition members recognize that a stable, dependable supply of water is a necessity for San Diego’s growing community. Coalition members support the region investing in local sources for a drought-proof water supply to decrease its dependence on less reliable and ever-more expensive imported water. The Coalition believes that recycling water for potable use can be an important part of San Diego’s water supply portfolio diversification. In the San Diego region, potable reuse could provide one of the most cost-effective and environmentally friendly options to enhance local water supplies.  <br /><br />###<br /><br />The Water Reliability Coalition is a broad-based affiliation of environmental, consumer, business, labor, development, taxpayer and technical organizations that have come together to support exploration of Indirect Potable Reuse as a potential strategy to develop a safe, reliable, sustainable &amp; cost-effective local water supply. <br /><br />Coalition members include: BIOCOM; Building Industry Association; Building Owners and Managers Association, San Diego Chapter; Citizens Coordinate for Century 3; Coastal Environmental Rights Foundation; Empower San Diego; Endangered Habitats League; Environmental Health Coalition; Friends of Infrastructure; Industrial Environmental Association; National Association of Industrial and Office Properties, San Diego Chapter;  San Diego and Imperial Counties Labor Council; San Diego Audubon Society; San Diego Regional Economic Development Corporation; San Diego Coastkeeper; San Diego County Taxpayers Association; San Diego Regional Chamber of Commerce; San Diego River Park Foundation; Surfrider Foundation, San Diego Chapter; Sustainability Alliance of Southern California; Utility Consumers’ Action Network</p>]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
		<wp:post_id>43</wp:post_id>

	<item>
		<title>December 15 - San Diego Ocean Protection Takes Historic Step Forward</title>
		<link>http://localhost/demodata/?p=44</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 15 Dec 2010 23:35:44 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[saltdevelopment]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://localhost/demodata/?p=44</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<p>Fish and Game Commission approves network of “underwater parks” including critical protections for some of San Diego’s marine areas</p> <p>{readmorelink} Read the full article... {/readmorelink}</p>  <!--more-->  <p>San Diego – Dec. 15, 2010 – In a landmark decision, the California Fish and Game Commission (FGC) today voted 3-2 to adopt a network of marine protected areas (MPAs) that will stretch from Santa Barbara to the Mexican border.  San Diego’s new MPAs will include locations at Swamis in Encinitas, south La Jolla, Point Loma and Imperial Beach, areas that San Diego Coastkeeper has worked to protect over the past four years. These protected areas will join the existing network of MPAs in the statewide system of underwater parks called for in California’s ocean conservation law, the Marine Life Protection Act (MLPA) adopted with bipartisan support in 1999.</p> <p>The FGC voted in favor of the Integrated Preferred Alternative (IPA), a compromise plan that combines MPA proposals from fishermen, divers, conservationists and scientists. The governor convened a Blue Ribbon Task Force of policy experts to review a selection of MPA proposals created by a group of 64 representatives from Southern California, including a San Diego Coastkeeper representative.  In December 2009, the Task Force unanimously recommended the IPA to the Commission for adoption into law.<br /><br />This afternoon, following lengthy review and before adopting the IPA into law today, the FGC made several small boundary modifications to a selection of the MPAs. These included a slight expansion of the conservation area at Swamis in Encinitas, adding just over a mile of protection at this geography. The Swamis conservation area is the largest in San Diego at over three shoreline miles and ten-square-miles of protected area. It will allow for spear fishing and shore fishing by hook and line gear. <br /><br />The size of the marine reserve at south La Jolla was also expanded by two city blocks so that boundaries would be more easily recognized by the public, providing this area with just over seven-square-miles of critical protection. The reserve in south La Jolla now stretches from Palomar Avenue to Missouri Street in Pacific Beach. In addition, the historic marine protected area at La Jolla shores, stretching to the Scripps pier, has been retained. <br /><br />The MLPA planning effort has sparked an outpouring of public support from elected officials, local businesses, community organizations and scientists. Thousands of San Diegans and Southern Californians attended meetings, made public comments or signed petitions supporting improved ocean protection.<br /><br />“We’ve been working toward this historic vote for more than four years,” said Meagan Wylie, San Diego Coastkeeper’s Marine Conservation Manager. “It’s like a savings account for our ocean—set a little aside so it can recuperate and thrive and we will all—fisherman, residents, recreational users, marine life--benefit from the interest.”  <br /><br />At today’s final meeting in Santa Barbara, the FGC heard testimony from elected officials, conservationists, scientists, fisherman and recreational users, who testified for the Commission to set aside strong marine protection areas for the good of the community.<br /><br />"We are on the side of fishermen, protected areas protect their business," said Jean-Michael Cousteau, the first son of ocean explorer Jacques-Yves Cousteau. “I want future generations to have the same privileges I’ve had.”<br /><br />The compromise IPA plan will protect sea life and habitats at biodiversity hot spots—San Diego’s include south La Jolla and Swamis-- while leaving nearly 90 percent of the coast open for fishing (see a map of fishing areas left open).  The new MPAs will improve access for recreation, study and education while boosting the overall health of California’s ocean.<br /><br />Marine protected areas (MPAs) are a scientifically proven tool for improving the health of marine life and habitat. A five-year review of protections around the Channel Islands has shown that MPAs have greater diversity and productivity than similar fished habitats, without any decline in sportfishing.  <br /><br />“Every place you are considering here today is as worthy of protection as Yellowstone and Yosemite,” said student Adam Livingston in his public testimony.<br /><br />For more information visit localhost/sdcoastkeeper. <br /><br />### <br />Founded in 1995, San Diego Coastkeeper protects the region’s inland and coastal waters for the communities and wildlife that depend on them by blending education, community empowerment and advocacy. Visit us online at http://localhost/sdcoastkeeper.</p>]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>December 28 - San Diego Coastkeeper Selects Cook + Schmid for Public Awareness Campaign</title>
		<link>http://localhost/demodata/?p=45</link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 03 Jan 2011 19:39:36 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[saltdevelopment]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://localhost/demodata/?p=45</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<p>Organization seeks volunteer participation to protect and preserve inland and coastal waters</p> <p>{readmorelink}Read the full article...{/readmorelink}</p>  <!--more-->  <p>SAN DIEGO, Dec. 28, 2010—Cook + Schmid, a full-service integrated communications agency based in San Diego, has partnered with San Diego Coastkeeper, the region’s largest professional environmental organization working to protect inland and coastal waters, to provide public relations services. Cook + Schmid will help San Diego Coastkeeper spread the word to San Diego residents about important environmental issues and how to get involved in protecting local waters.   <br /><br />“San Diego Coastkeeper leads the region in water conservation and protection—something from which we all benefit,” said Jon Schmid, Cook + Schmid managing partner.  “As a local business, we understand the need to educate residents about our water issues, and we’re happy to employ our public relations services to help San Diego Coastkeeper with that mission.”<br /><br />Cook + Schmid has planned and implemented a number of successful brand image and outreach campaigns.  They have garnered a tremendous amount of coverage for other local non profits, including the Ocean Discovery Institute and the San Diego Bay Parade of Lights.<br /><br />Through this partnership, Cook + Schmid and San Diego Coastkeeper hope to increase awareness and help the public to better understand San Diego’s water issues and how residents’ daily decisions impact the environment.<br /><br />About Cook + Schmid:<br />Based in San Diego, California, Cook &amp; Schmid is a full-service integrated communications agency. Services include interactive marketing, creative and design, advertising, multi-cultural marketing, mobile marketing, Web site development and design, and public relations. The agency counsels public and private companies and government agencies, including the San Diego Redevelopment Agency, public biotech firm Illumina, international supply chain company DW Morgan, and the San Bernardino County Office of the Administrator among others. Cook &amp; Schmid is characterized by creativity, quality of service, and depth of knowledge, with a focus on providing measurable results to clients. Additional information is available at www.cookandschmid.com. <br /><br />About San Diego Coastkeeper:<br />Founded in 1995, San Diego Coastkeeper protects the region’s inland and coastal waters for the communities and wildlife that depend on them by blending education, community empowerment and advocacy. Visit them online at http://localhost/sdcoastkeeper.<br /><br />###</p>]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>February 7 - Coastkeeper, Surfrider Announce 2010 San Diego Beach Cleanup Data</title>
		<link>http://localhost/demodata/?p=46</link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 07 Feb 2011 17:09:30 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[saltdevelopment]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://localhost/demodata/?p=46</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<p>Volunteers removed more than 25,000 pieces of Styrofoam</p> <p>{readmorelink}Read the full article...{/readmorelink}</p>  <!--more-->  <p>SAN DIEGO, CA- Feb. 7, 2011- Cigarette butts, Styrofoam pieces and plastics continue to be the top three most common items found on San Diego County’s beaches, according to data released today by San Diego Coastkeeper and the Surfrider Foundation San Diego Chapter. In partnership since 2003, the environmental organizations conduct twice-monthly beach cleanups throughout the county and ask volunteers to keep detailed records of the debris they remove. The data allows comparisons between clean and dirty beaches; Torrey Pines State Beach had the least trash in 2009 and 2010, while Pacific Beach’s Tourmaline Beach had the most trash collected by volunteer.<br /><br />“We presented this data to the City of San Diego last week and asked council members to not spend taxpayer money on single-use plastic water bottles and Styrofoam food containers, which harm our environment,” said Alicia Glassco, San Diego Coastkeeper’s Education and Marine Debris Manager. <br /><br />Data collection cards from the 2010 cleanups also show: <br /><br />•    Cigarette butts, Styrofoam and “other plastics” are the top three most common items found since 2007. <br />•    Volunteers removed more than 70,000 pieces of plastic from area beaches in 2010. <br />•    Pieces of Styrofoam have increased in three years from 10,000 to nearly 25,000. Interesting items found in 2010 included an electronic keyboard, conveyor belt and soup ladle. <br /><br />“The data highlights the trend of improper disposal of plastics such as single-use plastic bags, Styrofoam, food wrappers and bottles/caps, which do not biodegrade,” said Surfrider Foundation San Diego Chapter Coordinator Bill Hickman. “Cigarette butts remain a serious concern.”<br /><br />In addition to Coastkeeper and Surfrider’s twice-monthly cleanups, both organizations participate in additional special cleanups organized by several local non-profits. When totals from all major area cleanups are combined, nearly 40,000 volunteers collected 635,000 pounds of trash from San Diego waterways and coastal beaches in 2010. <br /><br />Coastkeeper and Surfrider are also announcing the full 2011 schedule, which will again rotate locations of popular beaches throughout the county and are open to all volunteers. At each cleanup, organizers anticipate 100 to 500 people. They do supply bags, gloves and water for those who participate, but request that volunteers bring their own gardening gloves, buckets and reusable water bottles to help reduce plastic usage during the pickup. <br /><br />For more information on San Diego beach cleanups, visit Coastkeeper’s website at localhost/sdcoastkeeper or Surfrider’s website at www.surfriderSD.org.<br /><br /># # #<br /><br />San Diego Coastkeeper<br />Founded in 1995, San Diego Coastkeeper protects the region’s bays, beaches, watersheds and ocean for the people and wildlife that depend on them.  We balance community outreach, education, and advocacy to promote stewardship of clean water and a healthy coastal ecosystem. <br /><br />Surfrider Foundation San Diego Chapter<br />The Surfrider Foundation is a non-profit grassroots organization dedicated to the protection and enjoyment of our world’s oceans, waves and beaches. Founded in 1984 by a handful of visionary surfers in Malibu, California, the Surfrider Foundation now maintains over 50,000 members and 80 chapters worldwide.</p>]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>February 10 - High Tides on February 16 - 18 to Illustrate Vulnerability of San Diego’s Shoreline</title>
		<link>http://localhost/demodata/?p=47</link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 07 Feb 2011 17:09:30 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[saltdevelopment]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://localhost/demodata/?p=47</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<p>Volunteer photography of highest tides to demonstrate potential impacts of sea level rise</p> <p>{readmorelink}Read the full article...{/readmorelink}</p>  <!--more-->  <p>February 8, 2011 – San Diego, Calif. - Next week some of the year’s highest tides will breach California’s coastal and bay shorelines, providing a glimpse of what the state can expect as sea levels rise in the coming years. Local environmental organizations are working within a statewide project to have volunteers in San Diego County document this winter’s highest tides—known as “king tides.” Local organizers, focused on capturing pictures around San Diego Bay to support the current sea level rise adaptation planning process, expect king tides from February 16 – 18 with particularly high tides on February 17 from 7:30 – 9 a.m. San Diego participants will be eligible to win one of three prize packs.<br /><br />Statewide, the organizations will use the photography to help policymakers visualize projected impacts from rising sea levels and take action to protect homes, harbors, airports, and other key infrastructure as well as wetlands, beaches, and public access to the coast. Local partners include Tijuana River National Estuarine Research Reserve, San Diego Coastkeeper, the San Diego Foundation, Surfrider San Diego Chapter, and ICLEI-Local Governments for Sustainability.<br /><br />“Our shoreline greatly contributes to our economy and our livelihood, and it houses important habitat for a variety of plants and animals,” says Jen Kovecses, staff scientist for San Diego Coastkeeper.  “These king tides give us a rare chance to visualize how gravely sea level rise will change our shoreline. One common sense solution is to restore and protect wetlands, which function like natural sponges, buffering against rising sea levels, higher tides, and increased storm and wave activity.”<br /><br />According to The San Diego Foundation’s Regional Focus 2050 Study, which included contributions from more than 40 multi-disciplinary experts from regional universities, local governments, public sector agencies, nonprofits, and private sector organizations, increases in sea level in San Diego could be 12 – 18 inches by 2050. The king tide event on February 17 is predicted to raise water levels five to eight inches above normal, providing a glimpse of San Diego’s future.  <br /><br />To help document the potential impacts of rising sea levels, local groups are calling on residents to submit photos taken during high tides of areas known to flood and areas where high water levels can be gauged against sea walls, jetties, bridge supports, or dikes. The photos—especially before and after shots-- will help to identify and catalog coastal areas vulnerable to tidal inundation and to promote awareness of the potential impacts of sea level rise.<br /> NOAA’s Tidal Charts showcase the precise locations and tide predictions (http://www.co-ops.nos.noaa.gov/tides11/tab2wc1a.html#122) for the high tides expected February 16 – 18. Residents are encouraged to get out their cameras each morning and help capture sea level rise impacts by submitting photos, along with their contact information, photo location, orientation, and date and time of day, directly to the San Diego King Tide page at http://www.flickr.com/groups/sandiegokingtides/. <br /><br /><br />Locations in San Diego will focus on San Diego Bay and include spots throughout the county. San Diego’s key areas to capture the king tides are in San Diego Bay, Oceanside Beach, San Elijo Lagoon, Del Mar Dog Beach/San Dieguito Lagoon Entrance, Torrey Pines (at the beach strand where Penasquitos enters the ocean), La Jolla Shores, and Mission Beach. <br /><br />Media can arrange a personal tour from shore or on boat and get more information by contacting Kristen Goodrich (kgoodrich@parks.ca.gov, 619-575-3613 x314) at TRNERR or Jen Kovecses (jenlk@localhost/sdcoastkeeper, 619-758-7743 x113) at San Diego Coastkeeper. Residents can learn more about the king tides and the photography submission guidelines by visiting the Flickr site: http://www.flickr.com/groups/sandiegokingtides/. <br /><br />###<br /><br />About National Estuarine Research Reserve System The National Estuarine Research Reserve System (NERRS) is a network of protected areas established for long-term research, education, and stewardship.  Through a partnership between the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration’s Estuarine Reserves Division and the coastal states, the NERRS plays a critical role in sustaining the nation’s estuaries and coastal communities.  There are currently 28 Reserves located throughout the United States, comprising more than one million acres of estuarine land and water.  Reserves conduct research, monitoring, restoration, education, and training designed to improve our understanding and management of estuaries. For more information, visit www.trnerr.org<br /><br />About San Diego Coastkeeper<br /> Founded in 1995, San Diego Coastkeeper protects the region’s inland and coastal waters for the communities and wildlife that depend on them by blending education, community empowerment, and advocacy. For more information, http://localhost/sdcoastkeeper</p>]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>February 23-Coastkeeper Announces County’s 2010 Water Quality Monitoring Data</title>
		<link>http://localhost/demodata/?p=48</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 16 Feb 2011 20:59:54 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[saltdevelopment]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://localhost/demodata/?p=48</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<p>Elevated pollutant levels found in Escondido and Tijuana watersheds</p> <p><span>{readmorelink}Read the full article...{/readmorelink}</span></p> <p>  <!--more-->  <span style="font-size: small;"><span style="font-size: medium;"><span style="font-size: small;"><span style="font-size: medium;"> </span></span></span></span></p> <div class="Section1"> <p style="MARGIN: 0in 0in 0pt" class="MsoNormal"><span style="FONT-SIZE: 11pt; FONT-FAMILY: Arial">SAN DIEGO, CA-Feb. 23, 2011- <a href="http://localhost/sdcoastkeeper/"><span style="color: #800080;">San Diego Coastkeeper’s</span></a> Water Quality Monitoring data show high levels of nitrate concentration in Escondido Creek and increasing amounts of fecal indicator in the Tijuana River, according to data released today by the organization. During 2010, Coastkeeper’s 17 watershed captains led 142 newly trained volunteers to complete 2,206 hours of sampling and testing in the region’s creeks and streams. Monthly, the <span style="text-decoration: underline;"><a href="act/green-events-in-san-diego/san-diego-county-water-quality-monitoring.html">Water Quality Monitoring</a> </span>team collects water samples in nine out of eleven watersheds in <st1:city w:st="on"><st1:place w:st="on">San Diego</st1:place></st1:city> and then screens them for basic chemistry, nutrients, bacteria and toxicity.<br /><br /><em style="mso-bidi-font-style: normal"> <o:p></o:p></em></span></p> <p style="MARGIN: 0in 0in 0pt" class="MsoNormal"><em style="mso-bidi-font-style: normal"><span style="FONT-SIZE: 11pt; FONT-FAMILY: Arial"><span style="mso-spacerun: yes"> </span><o:p></o:p></span></em></p> <p style="MARGIN: 0in 0in 0pt" class="MsoNormal"><strong><span style="FONT-WEIGHT: normal; FONT-SIZE: 11pt; FONT-FAMILY: Arial; mso-bidi-font-weight: bold">The data from 2010 show that </span></strong><span style="FONT-SIZE: 11pt; FONT-FAMILY: Arial">Escondido creek has some of the highest nitrate concentration in the region, which can lead to clogging<span class="apple-style-span"><span style="COLOR: black; FONT-FAMILY: Arial"> of the waterway and negative impacts to aquatic organisms. Nitrate can be an indicator of fertilizer run-off, sewage, animal manure and other types of contamination. <br /><br /><o:p></o:p></span></span></span></p> <p style="MARGIN: 0in 0in 0pt" class="MsoNormal"><span class="apple-style-span"><span style="FONT-SIZE: 11pt; COLOR: black; FONT-FAMILY: Arial"><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p> <p style="MARGIN: 0in 0in 0pt" class="MsoNormal"><span style="FONT-SIZE: 11pt; FONT-FAMILY: Arial">“The Regional Water Quality Control Board does not currently list Escondido Creek for nitrates. We submitted our data showing the elevated levels to the regulators to be considered under the next listing process,” said Travis Pritchard, San Diego Coastkeeper’s Water Quality Lab Coordinator. “This is how our Water Quality Monitoring program and its team of volunteers are making <st1:city w:st="on"><st1:place w:st="on">San Diego</st1:place></st1:city>’s water healthier.”<br /><br /><o:p></o:p></span></p> <p style="MARGIN: 0in 0in 0pt" class="MsoNormal"><em style="mso-bidi-font-style: normal"><span style="FONT-SIZE: 11pt; FONT-FAMILY: Arial"><o:p> </o:p></span></em></p> <p style="MARGIN: 0in 0in 0pt" class="MsoNormal"><span style="FONT-SIZE: 11pt; FONT-FAMILY: Arial">According the 2010 data, the nutrient concentrations found in the <st1:place w:st="on"><st1:placename w:st="on">Tijuana</st1:placename> <st1:placetype w:st="on">River</st1:placetype></st1:place> exceed standards due to raw, untreated sewage that gets flushed through the river system during rain events. This water source closes southern county beaches that extend to <st1:city w:st="on"><st1:place w:st="on">Coronado</st1:place></st1:city>. Complete 2010 data sets for <a href="http://www.sdwatersheds.org/wiki/Carlsbad%20Watershed">Escondido Creek</a> and <a href="http://www.sdwatersheds.org/wiki/Tijuana%20Watershed">Tijuana River</a>, along with sampling sites in all nine watersheds, can be found at <a href="http://www.sdwatesheds.org/">www.sdwatesheds.org</a>. <br /><br /><o:p></o:p></span></p> <p style="MARGIN: 0in 0in 0pt" class="MsoNormal"><em style="mso-bidi-font-style: normal"><span style="FONT-SIZE: 11pt; FONT-FAMILY: Arial"><o:p> </o:p></span></em></p> <p style="MARGIN: 0in 0in 0pt" class="MsoNormal"><span style="FONT-SIZE: 11pt; FONT-FAMILY: Arial">In addition to the unusual levels found in Escondido and Tijuana River, the data Coastkeeper’s Water Quality Monitoring program collect help establish water quality trends in the county’s watersheds. Not all data show extreme levels of differentiation, but it’s still essential to improve government decision making regarding local water bodies. <o:p></o:p></span></p> <p style="MARGIN: 0in 0in 0pt" class="MsoNormal"><span style="FONT-SIZE: 11pt; FONT-FAMILY: Arial"><o:p> </o:p></span></p> <p style="MARGIN: 0in 0in 0pt" class="MsoNormal"><span style="FONT-SIZE: 11pt; FONT-FAMILY: Arial">“In data analyzed region wide, we see concentrations of pollutants increase during storm events,” said Pritchard. “This illustrates the significant negative effects of urban storm water runoff on the regional water quality.”<br /><br /><o:p></o:p></span></p> <p style="MARGIN: 0in 0in 0pt" class="MsoNormal"><span style="FONT-SIZE: 11pt; FONT-FAMILY: Arial"><o:p> </o:p></span></p> <p style="MARGIN: 0in 0in 0pt" class="MsoNormal"><strong><span style="FONT-WEIGHT: normal; FONT-SIZE: 11pt; FONT-FAMILY: Arial; mso-bidi-font-weight: bold">The results from monitoring events, along with <a href="learn/san-diegos-waters/san-diego-watersheds.html"><span style="mso-bidi-font-weight: normal">watershed information</span></a> and locations of monitoring sites, are posted online for the public to access. Find data for locations near cities at:<o:p></o:p></span></strong></p> <p style="MARGIN: 0in 0in 0pt" class="MsoNormal"><strong><span style="FONT-WEIGHT: normal; FONT-SIZE: 11pt; FONT-FAMILY: Arial; mso-bidi-font-weight: bold"><o:p> </o:p></span></strong></p> </div> <div class="Section2"> <ul style="MARGIN-TOP: 0in" type="square"> <li style="MARGIN: 0in 0in 0pt; mso-list: l0 level1 lfo1; tab-stops: list .5in" class="MsoNormal"><st1:city w:st="on"><span style="FONT-SIZE: 11pt; FONT-FAMILY: Arial">Chula Vista</span></st1:city><span style="FONT-SIZE: 11pt; FONT-FAMILY: Arial">, <st1:city w:st="on">Imperial Beach</st1:city>, <st1:city w:st="on">Coronado</st1:city>, <st1:city w:st="on">National City</st1:city>, and <st1:city w:st="on"><st1:place w:st="on">San Diego</st1:place></st1:city>: <span style="text-decoration: underline;"><a href="http://www.sdwatersheds.org/wiki/Otay%20Watershed">Otay Watershed</a> </span></span></li> </ul> </div> <ul style="MARGIN-TOP: 0in" type="square"> <li style="MARGIN: 0in 0in 0pt; mso-list: l0 level1 lfo1; tab-stops: list .5in" class="MsoNormal"><st1:city w:st="on"><span style="FONT-SIZE: 11pt; FONT-FAMILY: Arial">San Diego</span></st1:city><span style="FONT-SIZE: 11pt; FONT-FAMILY: Arial">, <st1:city w:st="on">El Cajon</st1:city>, <st1:city w:st="on">La Mesa</st1:city>, Poway and <st1:place w:st="on">Santee</st1:place>: <span style="text-decoration: underline;"><a href="http://www.sdwatersheds.org/wiki/Los%20Penasquitos%20Watershed">Los Penasquitos Watershed</a> <o:p></o:p></span></span></li> </ul> <p style="MARGIN: 0in 0in 0pt" class="MsoNormal"><span style="FONT-SIZE: 11pt; FONT-FAMILY: Arial"><o:p></o:p></span></p> <ul style="MARGIN-TOP: 0in" type="square"> <li style="MARGIN: 0in 0in 0pt; mso-list: l0 level1 lfo1; tab-stops: list .5in" class="MsoNormal"><st1:city w:st="on"><span style="FONT-SIZE: 11pt; FONT-FAMILY: Arial">San Diego</span></st1:city><span style="FONT-SIZE: 11pt; FONT-FAMILY: Arial">, <st1:city w:st="on">El Cajon</st1:city>, <st1:city w:st="on">La Mesa</st1:city>, Poway, and Santee: <span style="text-decoration: underline;"><a href="http://www.sdwatersheds.org/wiki/San%20Diego%20Watershed">San Diego Watershed</a></span> <o:p></o:p></span></li> </ul> <ul style="MARGIN-TOP: 0in" type="square"> <li style="MARGIN: 0in 0in 0pt; mso-list: l0 level1 lfo1; tab-stops: list .5in" class="MsoNormal"><st1:state w:st="on"><span style="FONT-SIZE: 11pt; FONT-FAMILY: Arial">Del</span></st1:state><span style="FONT-SIZE: 11pt; FONT-FAMILY: Arial"> Mar, <st1:city w:st="on">Escondido</st1:city>, Poway, <st1:city w:st="on">San Diego</st1:city>, and <st1:place w:st="on"><st1:placename w:st="on">Solana</st1:placename> <st1:placetype w:st="on">Beach</st1:placetype></st1:place><span style="text-decoration: underline;"> : <a href="http://www.sdwatersheds.org/wiki/San%20Dieguito%20Watershed">San Dieguito Watershed</a> </span><o:p></o:p></span></li> </ul> <p style="MARGIN: 0in 0in 0pt" class="MsoNormal"><span style="FONT-SIZE: 11pt; FONT-FAMILY: Arial"><o:p></o:p></span></p> <ul style="MARGIN-TOP: 0in" type="square"> <li style="MARGIN: 0in 0in 0pt; mso-list: l0 level1 lfo1; tab-stops: list .5in" class="MsoNormal"><st1:city w:st="on"><span style="FONT-SIZE: 11pt; FONT-FAMILY: Arial">San Diego</span></st1:city><span style="FONT-SIZE: 11pt; FONT-FAMILY: Arial">, <st1:city w:st="on">La Mesa</st1:city>, Lemon Grove and <st1:city w:st="on">National City</st1:city><span style="text-decoration: underline;"> : <a href="http://www.sdwatersheds.org/wiki/Pueblo%20Watershed">Pueblo Watershed</a></span> <o:p></o:p></span></li> </ul> <p style="MARGIN: 0in 0in 0pt" class="MsoNormal"><span style="FONT-SIZE: 11pt; FONT-FAMILY: Arial"><o:p></o:p></span></p> <ul style="MARGIN-TOP: 0in" type="square"> <li style="MARGIN: 0in 0in 0pt; mso-list: l0 level1 lfo1; tab-stops: list .5in" class="MsoNormal"><st1:city w:st="on"><span style="FONT-SIZE: 11pt; FONT-FAMILY: Arial">Carlsbad</span></st1:city><span style="FONT-SIZE: 11pt; FONT-FAMILY: Arial">, <st1:city w:st="on">San Marcos</st1:city>, and Encinitas: <span style="text-decoration: underline;"><a href="http://www.sdwatersheds.org/wiki/Carlsbad%20Watershed">Carlsbad Watershed</a> </span><o:p></o:p></span></li> </ul> <p style="MARGIN: 0in 0in 0pt" class="MsoNormal"><span style="FONT-SIZE: 11pt; FONT-FAMILY: Arial"><o:p></o:p></span></p> <ul style="MARGIN-TOP: 0in" type="square"> <li style="MARGIN: 0in 0in 0pt; mso-list: l0 level1 lfo1; tab-stops: list .5in" class="MsoNormal"><span style="FONT-SIZE: 11pt; FONT-FAMILY: Arial">Spring Valley, <st1:city w:st="on"><st1:place w:st="on">National City</st1:place></st1:city><span style="text-decoration: underline;"> :<a href="http://www.sdwatersheds.org/wiki/Sweetwater%20Watershed">Sweetwater Watershed</a></span><o:p></o:p></span></li> </ul> <p style="MARGIN: 0in 0in 0pt" class="MsoNormal"><span style="FONT-SIZE: 11pt; FONT-FAMILY: Arial"><o:p></o:p></span></p> <ul style="MARGIN-TOP: 0in" type="square"> <li style="MARGIN: 0in 0in 0pt; mso-list: l0 level1 lfo1; tab-stops: list .5in" class="MsoNormal"><st1:city w:st="on"><span style="FONT-SIZE: 11pt; FONT-FAMILY: Arial">Tijuana</span></st1:city><span style="FONT-SIZE: 11pt; FONT-FAMILY: Arial">, <st1:city w:st="on">Imperial Beach</st1:city>, <st1:city w:st="on">San Diego</st1:city>:<span style="mso-spacerun: yes"> </span><span style="text-decoration: underline;"><a href="http://www.sdwatersheds.org/wiki/Tijuana%20Watershed">Tijuana Watershed</a> </span><o:p></o:p></span></li> </ul> <p style="MARGIN: 0in 0in 0pt" class="MsoNormal"><span style="FONT-SIZE: 11pt; FONT-FAMILY: Arial"><o:p></o:p></span></p> <ul style="MARGIN-TOP: 0in" type="square"> <li style="MARGIN: 0in 0in 0pt; mso-list: l0 level1 lfo1; tab-stops: list .5in" class="MsoNormal"><st1:city w:st="on"><span style="FONT-SIZE: 11pt; FONT-FAMILY: Arial">San Diego</span></st1:city><span style="FONT-SIZE: 11pt; FONT-FAMILY: Arial">, <st1:city w:st="on">Orange</st1:city>, and <st1:city w:st="on">Riverside</st1:city>: <span style="text-decoration: underline;"><a href="http://www.sdwatersheds.org/wiki/San%20Juan%20Watershed">San Juan Watershed</a></span> <o:p></o:p></span></li> </ul> <p><span style="FONT-SIZE: 11pt; FONT-FAMILY: Arial; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-ansi-language: EN-US; mso-fareast-language: EN-US; mso-bidi-language: AR-SA"><br style="PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE: auto; mso-break-type: section-break" clear="all" /></span><span style="FONT-SIZE: 11pt; FONT-FAMILY: Arial">All events are open to community members interested in monitoring water quality. New volunteer trainings take place every other month. For more information, visit Coastkeeper’s website at <a href="http://localhost/sdcoastkeeper/"><span style="color: #800080;">localhost/sdcoastkeeper</span></a>, or email Dylan Edwards at monitor@localhost/sdcoastkeeper<span style="COLOR: #333333">. <o:p></o:p></span></span></p> <p style="MARGIN: 0in 0in 0pt" class="MsoNormal"><strong><span style="FONT-WEIGHT: normal; FONT-SIZE: 11pt; FONT-FAMILY: Arial; mso-bidi-font-weight: bold">San Diego Coastkeeper also posts the current <a href="learn/san-diegos-waters/coastal-water.html"><span style="mso-bidi-font-weight: normal">beach water quality status</span></a> on its site, along with the historic beach water quality data in graphs. The watershed information and water quality data can be accessed through Coastkeeper’s site at <a href="http://localhost/sdcoastkeeper/"><span style="mso-bidi-font-weight: normal"><span style="color: #800080;">localhost/sdcoastkeeper</span></span></a>.<span style="mso-spacerun: yes"> </span><o:p></o:p></span></strong></p> <p style="MARGIN: 0in 0in 0pt" class="MsoNormal"><span style="FONT-SIZE: 11pt; FONT-FAMILY: Arial"><o:p> </o:p></span></p> <p style="MARGIN: 0in 0in 0pt; TEXT-INDENT: 0.5in; LINE-HEIGHT: 150%; TEXT-ALIGN: center" class="MsoNormal" align="center"><span style="FONT-SIZE: 11pt; COLOR: #333333; LINE-HEIGHT: 150%; FONT-FAMILY: Arial"># # #<o:p></o:p></span></p> <p style="MARGIN: 0in 0in 0pt" class="MsoNormal"><st1:city w:st="on"><st1:place w:st="on"><strong style="mso-bidi-font-weight: normal"><span style="FONT-SIZE: 11pt; FONT-FAMILY: Arial">San Diego</span></strong></st1:place></st1:city><strong style="mso-bidi-font-weight: normal"><span style="FONT-SIZE: 11pt; FONT-FAMILY: Arial"> Coastkeeper<o:p></o:p></span></strong></p> <p style="MARGIN: 0in 0in 0pt" class="MsoNormal"><span style="FONT-SIZE: 11pt; FONT-FAMILY: Arial">Founded in 1995, San Diego Coastkeeper protects the region’s bays, beaches, watersheds and ocean for the people and wildlife that depend on them.<span style="mso-spacerun: yes"> </span>We balance community outreach, education, and advocacy to promote stewardship of clean water and a healthy coastal ecosystem.<o:p></o:p></span></p> <p><span><span style="font-size: small;"><span><span style="FONT-SIZE: small; FONT-FAMILY: "><span style="font-size: small;"><span><span style="font-size: small;"><span><span style="FONT-SIZE: small; FONT-FAMILY: "><span style="font-size: small;"> <p> </p> </span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></p> <p> </p> <p><span style="font-size: x-small; font-family: Arial;"><span style="font-size: x-small; font-family: Arial;"> </span></span></p> <p> </p> <p> </p>]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>March 28 - San Diego Coastkeeper Celebrates Earth Day with ‘Smart on Water’ Trivia</title>
		<link>http://localhost/demodata/?p=49</link>
		<pubDate>Fri, 25 Mar 2011 20:45:21 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[saltdevelopment]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://localhost/demodata/?p=49</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<p>Environmental organization also hosts other volunteer events in first quarter 2011</p> <p><span>{readmorelink}Read the full article...{/readmorelink}</span></p>  <!--more-->  <p>SAN DIEGO, Calif.—This Earth Day, San Diego Coastkeeper will merge leisure with education by hosting Smart on Water Earth Day Challenge on April 20 from 6-9 p.m. The event at El Take It Easy includes a water trivia contest and a raffle boasting many prizes including a mouth-watering pound of locally raised, sustainable bacon. The evening will conclude with the crowning of San Diego’s first “Water Whiz.”<br /><br />Members can attend the fundraiser for $5 and non-members can join for $15, which comes with a year membership to Coastkeeper and a complementary "I Bottle My Own" reusable water bottle. El Take it easy is located at 3926 30th Street and will donate 15% of restaurant proceeds to protecting water. <br /><br />“Earth Day provides a spotlight for Earth-friendly practices and we wanted to use this opportunity to provide education in a fun, social environment,” said Coastkeeper’s Interim Executive Director Gabriel Solmer. “This event is rooted in emphasizing sustainability and is part of Coastkeeper’s ongoing efforts to protect our marine life and waters while keeping San Diegans aware and engaged.”<br /><br />In addition to the Smart on Water event, San Diego Coastkeeper provides San Diego residents with a variety of opportunities to act as partners in preservation including Water Quality Monitoring and beach cleanups. <br /><br />Water Quality Monitoring, an essential component in establishing water quality trends in the county’s creeks and rivers, will occur on:<br /><br />April 16: No training. Field session begins at 9 a.m.<br />May 21: Volunteer training at 8:30 a.m. Field session at 11 a.m.<br />June 11: No training. Field Session begins at 9 a.m.<br /><br />Twice-monthly Beach Cleanups, hosted alongside Surfrider San Diego Chapter, are as follows:<br />March 26: Coronado City Beach<br />April 9: Sunset Cliffs<br />April 30: Creek to Bay Cleanup<br />May 14: Oceanside Harbor<br />May 21: Encinitas- Moonlight Beach<br />May 28: Mission Bay-Fiesta Island<br />June 11: Oceanside Harbor<br />June 25: Pacific Beach- Crystal Pier<br /><br />For more information, visit Coastkeeper’s website at localhost/sdcoastkeeper, or email Dylan Edwards at dylan@localhost/sdcoastkeeper.<br /><br /># # # <br /><br />Founded in 1995, San Diego Coastkeeper protects the region’s inland and coastal waters for the communities and wildlife that depend on them by blending education, community empowerment and advocacy. For more information, go to http://localhost/sdcoastkeeper.</p>]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>April 25 - May 12 Signs of the Tide explores water quality: “Is Mission Bay Gross?”</title>
		<link>http://localhost/demodata/?p=50</link>
		<pubDate>Fri, 25 Mar 2011 20:45:21 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[saltdevelopment]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://localhost/demodata/?p=50</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<p>San Diego Coastkeeper hosts monthly events to educate about coastal waters</p> <p><span>{readmorelink}Read the full article...{/readmorelink}</span></p>  <!--more-->  <p>SAN DIEGO—“Is Mission Bay Gross?” On Thursday, May 12 from 6 p.m. – 8 p.m., San Diego Coastkeeper’s free quarterly Signs of the Tide public forum will clear the fog surrounding the urban jewel and popular getaway spot’s water quality and safety. The region’s leading environmental nonprofit protecting inland and coastal waters will educate the public with the help of four expert panelists at Urban Corps San Diego, located at 3127 Jefferson Street. <br /><br />Panelists will examine different aspects of the bay and address attendees about Mission Bay’s ecosystem; land use and development history; infrastructure upgrades to improve urban impacts; and water quality data. Speakers and topics are as follows:<br /><br />•    Rob Hutsel, executive director of San Diego River Parks Foundation, will share Mission Bay’s history and how it transformed to one of the biggest recreational assets in San Diego. Hutsel will explore the change of the course of water flowing to the bay from the San Diego River, concluding on water circulation happening throughout the year in Mission Bay.<br />•    Ken Schiff, deputy director of Southern California Coastal Water Research Project, will compare Mission Bay’s water quality status with similar water bodies in the region. A water quality expert, Schiff will explain various water quality testing methods and draw a connection between government water quality standards and human health. <br />•    Ruth Kolb, program manager at City of San Diego Transportation and Stormwater Department, will discuss how Mission Bay got its bad reputation and how the City of San Diego has taken drastic steps to improve the Bay’s water quality.<br />•    Jen Kovecses, staff scientist at San Diego Coastkeeper, will share her expertise about current problems Coastkeeper sees affecting Mission Bay’s water quality and explain Coastkeeper’s goals for improving the water quality. Kovecses will outline next steps and different ways community members can get involved in the process. <br /><br />Attendees with appetite for knowledge will be offered light appetizers and beverages. <br /><br />Coastkeeper’s next Signs of the Tide on Thursday, Aug. 9, will examine “San Diego Bay’s Dirty Little Secret.”  All of the Signs of the Tide events are free and open to the public.<br /><br />In addition to Signs of the Tide forums, Coastkeeper provides San Diego residents with a variety of opportunities to act as partners in preservation, including Water Quality Monitoring and beach cleanups. <br /><br />Water Quality Monitoring, an essential component in establishing water quality trends in the county’s creeks and rivers, will occur on:<br /><br />•    May 21: Volunteer training at 8:30 a.m. Field session at 11 a.m.<br />•    June 11: No training. Field Session begins at 9 a.m.<br />•    July 16: Volunteer training at 8:30 a.m. Field session at 11 a.m.<br /><br />Twice-monthly Beach Cleanups, hosted alongside Surfrider San Diego Chapter, are as follows:<br />•    April 30: Creek to Bay Cleanup<br />•    May 14: Oceanside Harbor<br />•    May 21: Encinitas- Moonlight Beach<br />•    May 28: Mission Bay-Fiesta Island<br />•    June 11: Oceanside Harbor<br />•    June 25: Pacific Beach- Crystal Pier<br />•    July 5: “The Morning After Mess”-Various locations<br />•    July 16: Encinitas- Moonlight Beach<br />•    July 30: South Mission Beach- Meet next to parking lot and lifeguard tower<br /><br />For more information about community events, visit Coastkeeper’s website at localhost/sdcoastkeeper, or email Dylan Edwards at dylan@localhost/sdcoastkeeper.<br /><br /># # #<br />Founded in 1995, San Diego Coastkeeper protects the region’s inland and coastal waters for the communities and wildlife that depend on them by blending education, community empowerment and advocacy. Visit us online at http://localhost/sdcoastkeeper.</p>]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>April 27 - Sea Rocket Bistro to Host Sustainable Seafood Cooking Classes May 22 - 24</title>
		<link>http://localhost/demodata/?p=51</link>
		<pubDate>Tue, 03 May 2011 19:46:37 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[saltdevelopment]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://localhost/demodata/?p=51</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<p>Three hands-on lessons featuring San Diego fish will benefit San Diego Coastkeeper</p> <p>{readmorelink} Read the full article...{/readmorelink}</p>  <!--more-->  <p>SAN DIEGO—San Diegans are invited to dine and attend a three-part sustainable seafood cooking class from May 22 - 24 at Sea Rocket Bistro. Chef Jenn Felmley will give hands-on instructions using local, in-season seafood and ingredients to help attendees select, purchase, and prepare sustainable dishes. Each class costs $65 and proceeds with benefit San Diego Coastkeeper, the region’s largest environmental organization protecting inland and coastal waters. Tickets can be upgraded to $75 to include a membership for San Diego Coastkeeper, normally priced at $25.  <br /><br />•     May 22, from 5 p.m. – 8 p.m., Sustainable Seafood Basics<br />In this introductory course to sustainable cooking, participants can learn how to choose environmentally friendly seafood as well as how to fillet and cut fish into individual portions. beginners to learn the steps needed for a healthy lifestyle and allow them to have their questions answered directly throughout the evening. <br /><br />•    May 23, from 6 p.m. – 9 p.m., Everyday Sustainable Seafood<br />Chef Jenn will demonstrate sustainable, simple and everyday seafood meals with recipes that are easy to  for or those with an on-the-go lifestyle, these cooking recipes will be easy to prepare and at the same time will keep the family full during a hectic work week. <br /><br />•    May 24, from 6 p.m. – 9 p.m., Fine Dining Sustainable Seafood<br /> For participants who like to entertain friends and guests, the class on will share impressive ideas to showcase sustainable seafood dinners. Those who like to be challenged will explore detailed and delicious recipes that will keep guests coming for more. <br /><br />Sea Rocket Bistro, Chef Jenn Felmley and San Diego Coastkeeper created the Sustainable Seafood Cooking Classes to help educate San Diego residents about ocean-friendly practices, including the importance of marine protected areas to ensure a healthy coastal ecosystem. Supporting local fisherman who embrace sustainable fishing practices that allows the San Diego region to cook and dine on seafood while giving the marine life a chance to repopulate, grow and thrive. Additionally, incorporating organic, locally grown and in-season ingredients supports low-impact farming that generates considerably less pollution from pesticides and fertilizers.<br /><br />Participants can purchase tickets online at San Diego Coastkeeper’s website at http://localhost/sdcoastkeeper. <br /><br />Chef Jenn Felmley’s journey began in Miami and Rhode Island at Johnson &amp; Wales University, college of the culinary arts. Since graduating, she traveled the world honing her cooking skills before returning to San Diego where she is now a full-time culinary teacher. Throughout three evenings, Chef Jenn’s passion for cooking and teaching about food will tickle the taste buds of any environmentalist and foodie.<br /><br />Sea Rocket Bistro is located in North Park and focuses on sustainably harvested seafood, organic produce and pastured meats, serving food directly from local region’s farmers, fishermen and ranchers. The restaurant is located at 3382 30th Street, San Diego, CA 92104. <br /><br />Founded in 1995, San Diego Coastkeeper protects the region’s inland and coastal waters for the communities and wildlife that depend on them by blending education, community empowerment and advocacy. Visit it online at http://localhost/sdcoastkeeper.<br /># # #</p> <p> </p>]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>June 17 - Coastkeeper Invites Public to View Nautical Art on July 1</title>
		<link>http://localhost/demodata/?p=55</link>
		<pubDate>Thu, 16 Jun 2011 17:31:29 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[saltdevelopment]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://localhost/demodata/?p=55</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<p style="text-align: left;">Event unveils 26-Foot Recycled Whale Art as Part of Friday Night <st1:city w:st="on"><st1:place w:st="on">Liberty</st1:place></st1:city></p> <p style="text-align: left;"><st1:city w:st="on"><st1:place w:st="on"></st1:place></st1:city></p>  <!--more-->  <p style="text-align: left;"><st1:city w:st="on"><st1:place w:st="on">SAN DIEGO</st1:place></st1:city> – San Diego Coastkeeper invites San Diegans to join them in welcoming <em>L’il Gray</em>, an environmental art piece in the form of a life-size gray whale, to its new home in the Coastkeeper office.  Three local artists will show several pieces of ocean-themed artwork to accompany the installation of the 26-foot long whale at “Coastal Pollution: A Whale of a Problem”  on Friday, July 1. Complete with light appetizers, beverages and music, the event is part of Friday Night Liberty, a monthly open house of museums and shops at Liberty Station.</p> <p style="text-align: left;">The whale is part of Coastkeeper’s educational campaign to counter coastal pollution.  Plastic pollution is particularly devastating as it does not decompose, and wildlife can mistake the plastic pieces for food.  Plastic is also the main component of the whale.  Theresa Espaniola directed 130 first-graders from <st1:placename w:st="on">Jefferson</st1:placename> <st1:placetype w:st="on">Elementary School</st1:placetype> in <st1:city w:st="on"><st1:place w:st="on">Carlsbad</st1:place></st1:city> to create the whale.  Different classes worked on six separate panels of canvas, each with a section of whale and decorated each section with found beach trash that they collected themselves. </p> <p style="text-align: left;">Theresa Espaniola will also be displaying some of her own artwork at Coastkeeper’s for Coastal Pollution: A Whale of a Problem.  Her gARTbage series utilizes trash found on the beaches near her home in quirky dioramas designed to provoke amusement and generate awareness of coastal plastic pollution as a problem.  She works frequently with children to create artwork from marine debris; <em>L’il Gray</em> was the result of one of these collaborations.</p> <p style="text-align: left;">Myles McGuinness, an <st1:city w:st="on"><st1:place w:st="on">Oceanside</st1:place></st1:city> photographer, will also be represented at the Coastkeeper event.  He spearheaded Coastkeeper’s rebrand and designed and  photographed Coastkeeper’s 2010 Annual Report, available on the Coastkeeper website.  He will show an assortment of photographs of local ocean scenes.</p> <p style="text-align: left;">Tony Peters is the third artist, a local oil painter who will be displaying two of his pieces with Coastkeeper.  He uses the techniques of a landscape painter and applies them to city scenes.</p> <p style="text-align: left;">Artists will be selling their art at the event and will donate a portion of the proceeds to Coastkeeper.</p> <p style="text-align: left;">Attend Coastal Pollution: A Whale of a Problem Friday, July 1, 2011 from 5 p.m. to 8 p.m., at the Coastkeeper office, <st1:address w:st="on"><st1:street w:st="on">2825 Dewey Road, Suite 200</st1:street>, <st1:city w:st="on">San Diego</st1:city>, <st1:state w:st="on">CA</st1:state> <st1:postalcode w:st="on">92106</st1:postalcode></st1:address>.  The event will be occurring in conjunction with Friday Night Liberty, a monthly event for which all of the shops and museums of Liberty Station are open to the public, so there will be plenty to see for environmentalists and art aficionados alike.  For more information, visit Coastkeeper online at <a href="http://localhost/sdcoastkeeper/">http://localhost/sdcoastkeeper</a> or call (619) 758-7743.</p> <p style="text-align: left;">Founded in 1995, San Diego Coastkeeper protects the region’s inland and coastal waters for the communities and wildlife that depend on them by blending education, community empowerment and advocacy.  The Coastkeeper office is located at <st1:address w:st="on"><st1:street w:st="on">2825 Dewey Road, Suite 200</st1:street>, <st1:city w:st="on">San Diego</st1:city>, <st1:state w:st="on">CA</st1:state> <st1:postalcode w:st="on">92106</st1:postalcode></st1:address>. Visit online at <a href="http://localhost/sdcoastkeeper/">http://localhost/sdcoastkeeper</a>.</p>]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>June 29 - Southern California Marine Protected Areas Take Effect October 1, 2011</title>
		<link>http://localhost/demodata/?p=56</link>
		<pubDate>Thu, 16 Jun 2011 17:31:29 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[saltdevelopment]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://localhost/demodata/?p=56</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<p>Scientific Studies Underscore Urgency of Protecting Ocean Hot Spots</p> <p style="text-align: left;"><st1:city w:st="on"><st1:place w:st="on"></st1:place></st1:city></p>  <!--more-->  <p><st1:city w:st="on">STOCKTON</st1:city>, <st1:state w:st="on">CA</st1:state> – <st1:state w:st="on">California</st1:state>’s Fish and Game Commission voted four to one today in favor of an October 1, 2011 implementation date for the <a href="http://www.dfg.ca.gov/mlpa/pdfs/scmpas121510.pdf">Southern California marine protected areas</a> approved last December. These underwater state parks will provide critically needed protections for <st1:city w:st="on">San Diego</st1:city> coastal hot spots like south <st1:place w:st="on">La Jolla</st1:place> and Swamis in Encinitas.  </p> <p>Several recent studies underscore the urgent need for a comprehensive marine protected area system, like the one <st1:state w:st="on"><st1:place w:st="on">California</st1:place></st1:state> is creating through the Marine Life Protection Act (MLPA), to buffer against growing threats like climate change, habitat loss and fishing pressure.  A <a href="http://www.iucn.org/knowledge/news/?7695/Multiple-ocean-stresses-threaten-globally-significant-marine-extinction">report</a> to the United Nations warned of potential mass extinctions within our lifetimes if preventative action is not taken, and identified marine protected areas as a key solution.  A <a href="http://www.mpa.gov/pdf/helpful-resources/factsheets/us_marinereserves.pdf">NOAA study</a> emphasized the benefits marine protected areas provide for people. </p> <p>“These science-based marine protected areas will help replenish <st1:placetype w:st="on">San Diego</st1:placetype>’s coastal ecosystems so that marine life and habitats can recover and thrive,” says Gabriel Solmer, Coastkeeper’s Interim Executive Director. </p> <p>“Thousands of south coast residents participated in the planning process for these marine protected areas, and dozens of community efforts are already underway to support education, research and outreach needs,” said Karen Garrison of Natural Resources Defense Council. </p> <p>The new marine protected areas were planned by local stakeholders, including members of Coastkeeper staff, during a two-year public process that spanned more than 50 public meetings and generated tens of thousands of community emails. The network was designed to protect sea life and habitats at biodiversity hot spots while leaving nearly 90 percent of the coast open for fishing (see a <a href="http://caloceans.org/document/fishing-areas-left-open-under-socal-ipa.pdf.">map of fishing areas left open</a>).  The new protected areas will improve access for recreation, study and education while boosting the overall health of <st1:placetype w:st="on">California</st1:placetype>’s ocean. </p> <p>On December 15, 2010, the California Fish &amp; Game Commission voted in favor of adopting marine protected areas in southern <st1:placetype w:st="on">California</st1:placetype>. <st1:placetype w:st="on">San Diego</st1:placetype>’s new marine protected areas include a fully protected marine reserve at south La Jolla, and conservation areas at Swamis in Encinitas, <st1:placetype w:st="on"><st1:placetype w:st="on">La Jolla</st1:placetype> <st1:placetype w:st="on">Shores</st1:placetype></st1:placetype> and the Tijuana River Mouth. </p> <p>For more information about marine protected areas, visit Coastkeeper’s website at <a href="http://localhost/sdcoastkeeper/">localhost/sdcoastkeeper</a>.</p> <p align="center">###</p> <p>Founded in 1995, San Diego Coastkeeper protects the region’s inland and coastal waters for the communities and wildlife that depend on them by blending education, community empowerment and advocacy. Visit us online at <a href="http://localhost/sdcoastkeeper/">http://localhost/sdcoastkeeper</a>.</p> <p> </p>]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>June 30 - Water Reliability Coalition Supports Water Purification Pilot Project</title>
		<link>http://localhost/demodata/?p=57</link>
		<pubDate>Thu, 16 Jun 2011 17:31:29 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[saltdevelopment]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://localhost/demodata/?p=57</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<p><em>Broad-based affiliation sees need to explore safe, reliable options for drinking water in <st1:place w:st="on"><st1:city w:st="on">San Diego</st1:city></st1:place></em></p> <p style="text-align: left;"><st1:city w:st="on"><st1:place w:st="on"></st1:place></st1:city></p>  <!--more-->  <p>San Diego, Calif. – Thursday, June 30, 2011 –The Water Reliability Coalition, a broad-based affiliation of environmental, consumer, business, labor, development, taxpayer and technical organizations, supports the City of San Diego’s pilot project to explore the purification of wastewater into drinking water.  </p> <p>Today, City of <st1:place w:st="on">San Diego Mayor Jerry Sanders</st1:place> announced the kick-off of the year-long testing period, which will examine the feasibility of treating wastewater to drinking water standards for the City of <st1:place w:st="on">San Diego</st1:place>. </p> <p>“A stable, dependable supply of water is critical for <st1:place w:st="on">San Diego</st1:place>’s growing community,” said co-chair Lani Lutar of the San Diego County Taxpayers Association. “The coalition members support investment in the water purification pilot project because it is anticipated to result in a local, drought-proof water supply source that will help decrease the city’s reliance on expensive, imported water.” </p> <p>To perform the pilot study, the city built a test facility at the North City Water Reclamation Plant, where the city purifies wastewater into so-called “reclaimed” water that can be used for industrial landscaping and other non-drinking purposes. The new facility will purify this water even further, so clean it could be safe enough to drink. Currently, the facility will pump the finished product back into the reclaimed water system for industrial use. This year-long testing of one million gallons a day will provide scientific data that will help determine whether the process is clean and safe. </p> <p>If the results of the pilot project gain approval from the California Department of Public Health, then <st1:place w:st="on">San Diego</st1:place>’s leadership will vote whether to pursue wastewater recycling as a means to augment <st1:place w:st="on">San Diego</st1:place>’s water supply.  If they vote in favor of wastewater recycling, then the project will enter into the next phase, which includes building a full-scale Advanced Water Purification Facility adjacent to the North City Water Reclamation Plant. Additionally, the City would build a 23-mile pipeline to transport the highly purified water to the San Vicente Reservoir, where the water would blend with <st1:place w:st="on">San Diego</st1:place>’s alternate sources of water and then get treated once again before reaching the homes of <st1:place w:st="on">San Diego</st1:place>. </p> <p>“We’re not the first city to explore this safe water supply option,” said co-chair Ms. <st1:place w:st="on">Gabriel Solmer</st1:place> of San Diego Coastkeeper. “In fact, in Southern California, the Irvine Ranch Water District has distributed recycled water for over thirty years and <st1:place w:st="on"><st1:place w:st="on">Orange</st1:place> <st1:place w:st="on">County</st1:place></st1:place> has added highly purified recycled wastewater to groundwater supplies that residents use as a source of drinking water. This technology is used around the world.” </p> <p>The Coalition believes that recycling water for potable use can be an important part of <st1:place w:st="on">San Diego</st1:place>’s water supply portfolio diversification. In the <st1:place w:st="on">San Diego</st1:place> region, potable reuse could provide one of the most cost-effective and environmentally friendly options to enhance local water supplies.</p> <p><span style="font-size: 10pt;"><span style="font-family: arial,helvetica,sans-serif;">### <o:p> </o:p></span></span></p> <p class="MsoNormal" style="margin: 0in 0in 0pt;"><span style="font-size: 10pt;"><span style="font-family: arial,helvetica,sans-serif;">The Water Reliability Coalition is a broad-based affiliation of environmental, consumer, business, labor, development, taxpayer and technical organizations that have come together to support exploration of Indirect Potable Reuse as a potential strategy to develop a safe, reliable, sustainable &amp; cost-effective local water supply. <o:p> <br /></o:p></span></span><span style="font-size: 10pt;"><span style="font-family: arial,helvetica,sans-serif;"><span style="mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-bidi-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-ansi-language: EN-US; mso-fareast-language: EN-US; mso-bidi-language: AR-SA;"><br />Coalition members include: BIOCOM; Building Industry Association; Building Owners and Managers Association, San Diego Chapter; Citizens Coordinate for Century 3; Coastal Environmental Rights Foundation; Empower San Diego; Endangered Habitats League; Environmental Health Coalition; Friends of Infrastructure; Industrial Environmental Association; National Association of Industrial and Office Properties, San Diego Chapter;<span style="mso-spacerun: yes;">  </span>San Diego and Imperial Counties Labor Council; San Diego Audubon Society; San Diego Regional Economic Development Corporation; San Diego Coastkeeper; San Diego County Taxpayers Association; San Diego Regional Chamber of Commerce; San Diego River Park Foundation; Surfrider Foundation, San Diego Chapter; Sustainability Alliance of Southern California; Utility Consumers' Action Network</span> </span></span></p>]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>June 28 -San Diego Clean Beach Coalition Preps Beaches for Holiday Crowds</title>
		<link>http://localhost/demodata/?p=58</link>
		<pubDate>Thu, 16 Jun 2011 17:31:29 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[saltdevelopment]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://localhost/demodata/?p=58</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<p><em><st1:place w:st="on"><st1:city w:st="on"></st1:city></st1:place></em></p> <p style="text-align: left;"><st1:city w:st="on"><st1:place w:st="on"></st1:place></st1:city></p>  <!--more-->  <p>San Diego, CA – As the Fourth of July holiday weekend draws near, the San Diego Clean Beach Coalition (CBC) is poised to prevent the pollution problem that plagues area beaches during major summer holidays. The Coalition has raised close to $15,000 from local businesses and government agencies to support the purchase and placement of 110 temporary trash and 90 recycle bins for the Independence Day and Labor Day holidays. Look for these temporary cardboard bins on the sand in the areas of Ocean Beach, Mission Beach, Mission Bay Park, and Pacific Beach.</p> <p>This year the Clean Beach Coalition encourages awareness about individuals’ ability to reduce their waste.  Each person has the capacity to anticipate the trash they will create in their day and act prudently to prevent that trash from ending up on the beach and in the ocean.  The CBC has provided a list of suggestions for what to bring to the beach as well as what not to bring, in order to make it easier to enjoy the holiday without the guilt and mess of trash littering the coastline.  Based on combined beach cleanup data, the CBC advises to avoid Styrofoam, single use plastics cups/bottles, and heavily plastic-packaged goods.  The CBC also suggests that beachgoers bring reusable bottles that can be refilled at water fountains, pack lunch in Tupperware within a durable, reusable cooler, and if you need a trash bag, borrow one from a less eco-minded neighbor who packed their party in plastic.  It’s important to spread the knowledge about why your patriotic celebration is plastic-free; this step is a worthy investment in the future of local environment. While the Coalition’s focus is on preventing the mess, it also sponsors the annual July 5 “Morning After Mess” cleanup. See http://sandiego.surfrider.org/the-morning-after-mess for details and to find out how to help.</p> <p>The Clean Beach Coalition, which consists of local environmental organizations, community groups, and government agencies, has come together for the fourth consecutive year to raise awareness of and prevent beach litter issues. CBC member agencies include: FreePB.org, I Love A Clean San Diego, San Diego Coastkeeper, the San Diego Chapter of Surfrider Foundation as well as the City of San Diego Parks &amp; Recreation Department. T<span style="font-size: 12pt;">his year’s efforts would not be pos</span>sible without the support of generous sponsors, including title sponsor Pacific Beach Shore Club and others including Woodstock’s Pizza, Lahaina Beach House, Verant Group, Allied Waste Services, Mission Beach Town Council, SDG&amp;E, Vavi Sport and Social Club, Mission Beach Woman’s Club, City of San Diego District 2 and San Diego Coaster Company. More information about the San Diego Clean Beach Coalition is available at www.cleanbeachcoalition.org.</p> <p><span style="font-size: 12pt;">The San Diego Clean Beach Coalition is a collaboration of local non-profit organizations and city agencies focused on coastal stewardship, raising awareness of beach litter issues, and preventing marine debris.</span><br /><br />###</p>]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>July 11 - San Diego Coastkeeper Announces New Executive Director</title>
		<link>http://localhost/demodata/?p=59</link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 11 Jul 2011 17:38:02 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[saltdevelopment]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://localhost/demodata/?p=59</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<p>Career environmental prosecutor Gale Filter joins water watchdog group on July 18</p> <p>{readmorelink}Read the full article{/readmorelink}</p>  <!--more-->  <p>SAN DIEGO (July 11, 2011) - San Diego Coastkeeper announced today its new executive director, Gale Filter, who will join the organization on July 18. Filter comes to San Diego from his role as deputy director of enforcement and emergency response for the California Environmental Protection Agency’s Department of Toxic Substances Control. Filter’s previous work experience includes time as the deputy executive director for consumer, environmental and legal services at the California District Attorney’s Association, as a deputy district attorney in Imperial County and as an instructor at Joliet Junior College.<br /><br />“Enforcing the law is at the heart of every Waterkeeper organization, and Gale has built his professional career on this notion,” said San Diego Coastkeeper Board President David Welborn. “He brings to San Diego Coastkeeper a long history of success in environmental leadership and enforcement perfectly paired with a commitment to education and collaboration.”<br /><br />While at the Department of Toxic Substances Control, Filter worked to ensure that businesses and others followed state laws and regulations in how they managed, stored and transported hazardous waste in California. Working with an annual budget of approximately $20 million, he directed all aspects of the enforcement program including a staff of 150 scientists, inspectors and criminal investigators at eight state offices.</p> <p>“Enforcement is powerful, but the power of collaboration should not be overlooked. In many cases, I’ve found that we can achieve compliance if the parties involved possess a collective will to address and fix the environmental problem,” said Filter. “We have much to gain from working together to improve the health of our environment. Enforcement is only part of the solution.”</p> <p>When hired at the Department of Toxic Substances, Filter was tasked to modernize the environmental enforcement program into a transparent, accountable and efficient program that maximized reduction of environmental harms in the state. The Environmental Protection Agency considers his reorganized and modernized environmental enforcement program as one of its five “showcase models” that brought improvements in public health and the environment.</p> <p>He also created the Environmental Justice Enforcement Initiative, a community-based policing and task force program that focuses on collecting intelligence and “spotting and squishing” environmental harms.  The Ash Center for Democratic Governance and Innovation at Harvard University’s Kennedy School of Government honored this initiative as a 2010 Bright Idea in American Government.<br /><br />“The future of environmental protection and enforcement is in agile, dynamic and creative groups like San Diego Coastkeeper,” said Filter. “As our city and state governments struggle with budgets, the people of this region will depend on our efforts to ensure that San Diego’s inland and coastal waters remain clean.”<br /><br />From 1999 to 2003, Filter was the environmental project director for the California District Attorneys Association. And before joining the Toxic Substances Control department of the state, he served as the deputy executive director of consumer, environmental and legal services at the District Attorneys Association.<br /><br />A lifelong environmentalist, Filter started his official environmental work in California in 1991 when he was a prosecutor in the Imperial County District Attorney’s office. Along with prosecuting murder and serious felony cases, Filter took on environmental crimes and prosecuted people responsible for harming the environment.<br /><br />Gale has a Juris Doctorate degree from the University Of San Diego School of Law, a Master of Public Administration degree from Governors State University in Illinois and a Bachelor of Arts degree from Humboldt State University.</p> <p>Interim Executive Director Gabriel Solmer, who stepped into the position in late 2010 to guide the organization through its transition, will continue her role as legal director, leading the organization’s Environmental Law &amp; Policy Clinic. <br /><br />###<br /><br />Founded in 1995, San Diego Coastkeeper protects the region’s inland and coastal waters for the communities and wildlife that depend on them by blending education, community empowerment and advocacy. For more information, visit Coastkeeper’s website at localhost/sdcoastkeeper.</p>]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>

		<wp:status><![CDATA[publish]]></wp:status>

		<wp:post_type><![CDATA[post]]></wp:post_type>
