	</item>
	<item>
		<title>March 14 - Regional Water Quality Control Board Unanimously Adopts San Diego Bay Cleanup</title>
		<link>http://localhost/demodata/?p=90</link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 25 Jul 2011 20:33:31 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[saltdevelopment]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://localhost/demodata/?p=90</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<p><span style="color: #808080;"><em><span style="font-size: 11pt; font-family: Arial;"> </span></em></span>Wednesday’s final ruling comes after a 20-year-long battle by Coastkeeper, EHC</p> <p></p>  <!--more-->  <div> <p><strong> </strong></p> <div style="position: absolute; left: -10000px; top: 90px; width: 1px; height: 1px; overflow: hidden;" id="_mcePaste"><strong>SAN DIEGO, Sept. 6, 2011 – On Saturday, September 17, around 10,000 volunteers will visit 90 coastal and inland cleanup sites for a one-day attack on marine debris and inland pollution. This year, Coastal Cleanup Day coordinators I Love A Clean San Diego and San Diego Coastkeeper highlight on their website several green “in need” cleanup sites, where data from the annual event show a higher demand for volunteers. To reduce the event’s carbon footprint and individual waste, organizers also ask volunteers to select local sites in their own communities and to bring reusable buckets, bags, work gloves and water bottles.</strong></div> <div style="font-weight: bold; position: absolute; left: -10000px; top: 90px; width: 1px; height: 1px; overflow: hidden;" id="_mcePaste">“Trash travels from inland communities into storm drains which empty into our canyons, creek beds and eventually the ocean,” said Pauline Martinson, Executive Director for I Love A Clean San Diego. “That’s why it’s especially important for volunteers to lend a hand in their local neighborhood—our entire county needs a cleaning.”</div> <div style="font-weight: bold; position: absolute; left: -10000px; top: 90px; width: 1px; height: 1px; overflow: hidden;" id="_mcePaste">To encourage participation in areas that need extra hands, San Diego’s Coastal Cleanup Day website, www.cleanupday.org features “in need” sites labeled in green in areas such as Clairemont, Normal Heights, City Heights, La Mesa, Tijuana River Valley and more. These sites were identified based on data from previous cleanups, indicating that some inland sites recover more debris as well as larger items such as tires, couches, and more.</div> <div style="font-weight: bold; position: absolute; left: -10000px; top: 90px; width: 1px; height: 1px; overflow: hidden;" id="_mcePaste">“A recent statewide survey shows that this event significantly increases knowledge about the causes of marine debris—and that’s the first step in stopping the problem,” said Alicia Glassco, Education and Marine Debris Manager at Coastkeeper. “We see Coastal Cleanup Day as a hands-on educational event that connects residents to their neighborhood while removing harmful debris.”</div> <div style="font-weight: bold; position: absolute; left: -10000px; top: 90px; width: 1px; height: 1px; overflow: hidden;" id="_mcePaste">I Love A Clean San Diego and San Diego Coastkeeper also ask volunteers to reduce their carbon footprint while participating in the event. <span style="white-space: pre;"> </span>Instead of traveling long distance to a site, volunteers should stay at their local cleanup locations and remember to bring their own reusable bag or bucket, work gloves and water bottle.</div> <div style="font-weight: bold; position: absolute; left: -10000px; top: 90px; width: 1px; height: 1px; overflow: hidden;" id="_mcePaste">Last year in San Diego County, volunteer involvement rose to approximately 9,000 participants, with another 3,000 volunteers lending their support across the border in the U.S./Mexico-shared Tijuana Watershed. Volunteers removed close to 100 tons of debris from more than 80 cleanup sites along the coastline and in canyons, creek beds, lagoons, estuaries and open spaces.</div> <div style="font-weight: bold; position: absolute; left: -10000px; top: 90px; width: 1px; height: 1px; overflow: hidden;" id="_mcePaste">This year, volunteers should register on the San Diego County event website at www.cleanupday.org. The website includes an interactive Google Map with all cleanup sites in the region, including a handful of green “in need” sites. Sites where registration is at capacity are denoted in red. Information for children, scouts, and groups are also available on the website.</div> SAN DIEGO, March 14, 2012 – San Diego Coastkeeper and Environmental Health Coalition (EHC) salute the Regional Water Quality Control Board (Regional Board) on ordering a cleanup of the 143,400 cubic yards of toxic sediments from the bottom of San Diego Bay. After a 20-year battle, the polluters will be held accountable, and the bay will have a chance to return to a cleaner state. In addition to celebrating the long-awaited cleanup order, both organizations asked the Regional Board to require that the cleanup actually achieve the alternative cleanup levels that the Regional Board staff has determined is safe for public health and environment. <br /><br />“The Regional Board should be applauded for finally acknowledging this pollution and the harm it causes to human, environmental and economic health,” said Jill Witkowski, legal director at San Diego Coastkeeper. “It’s about time that we make those responsible for the pollution clean up their mess.”<br /><br />San Diego Bay is listed under the federal Clean Water Act for 20 separate pollutants including sediment toxicity, copper, mercury, PAHs, PCBs, zinc, chlordane and benthic community effects. Due to the fish contamination from the pollutants, the Port of San Diego posted all piers along San Diego Bay with fish consumption advisories. However, because residents still catch and eat fish from the bay, they continue to be exposed to serious human health risks. The bay also plays a major role in San Diego County’s tourism economy, which depends on clean and safe coastal waters to attract visitors.<br /><br /> “This toxic pollution at the bottom of San Diego Bay prevents it from being safely fishable,” said Environmental Health Coalition’s Laura Hunter. “The cleanup is great news for the communities surrounding the bay. This cleanup action will reduce pollution in the bay and is an important step toward improving a food source for many families that fish it to feed their children.”<br /><br />Unfortunately, as approved, the cleanup order includes some loopholes that may let the responsible parties leave more sediment pollution in the bay than the analysis shows is safe. <br /><br />“The best way to illustrate the gravity of this situation is to look at mercury levels in the bay,” said Witkowski. “Currently, the Regional Board found mercury levels in San Diego Bay that are unsafe for human and environmental health. But given the loopholes in this cleanup plan, the cleanup will be considered a ‘success’ even if the mercury level is exactly the same as it is right now.”  <br /><br />Coastkeeper and EHC will continue to monitor the process to ensure that the bay is cleaned and the cleanup plan is executed in a manner that reduces impacts to communities. Both organizations suggested steps to the Regional Board that it can enact to protect the community during the cleanup process while it achieves safe cleanup levels.    To find out more about San Diego Bay, Coastkeeper and EHC’s work on the cleanup, visit Coastkeeper’s website localhost/sdcoastkeeper.   <br /><br />###  <br /><br />SAN DIEGO COASTKEEPER: Founded in 1995, San Diego Coastkeeper protects and restores fishable, swimmable and drinkable waters in San Diego County. Visit us online at http://localhost/sdcoastkeeper.  <br /><br />ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH COALITION: Founded in 1980, Environmental Health Coalition (EHC) builds grassroots campaigns to confront the unjust consequences of toxic pollution, discriminatory land use, and unsustainable energy policies. Visit us online at http://www.environmentalhealth.org/.<br /><br /> <div></div> <div></div> <div style="font-style: italic;"></div> </div>]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>April 2 - San Diego Coastkeeper Encourages San Diegans to Celebrate Earth Day</title>
		<link>http://localhost/demodata/?p=91</link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 25 Jul 2011 20:33:31 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[saltdevelopment]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://localhost/demodata/?p=91</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<p><em><span style="color: #808080;"><em><span style="font-size: 11pt; font-family: Arial;"> </span></em></span>Environmental organization hosts April 19 trivia contest, Sprinkles Cupcakes fundraiser, volunteer opportunities</em></p> <p></p>  <!--more-->  <div> <p><strong> </strong></p> <div id="_mcePaste" style="position: absolute; left: -10000px; top: 90px; width: 1px; height: 1px; overflow: hidden;"><strong>s are also available on the website.</strong></div> <strong> <div style="font-weight: bold;"></div> <div style="font-weight: bold;"></div> <div style="font-weight: bold;"> <div style="font-weight: normal;">SAN DIEGO, April 2, 2012 – San Diego Coastkeeper invites San Diegans to celebrate Earth Day by testing their environmental knowledge on April 19 from 7 p.m. – 10 p.m. at Raglan Public House in Ocean Beach. Sponsored by San Diego CityBeat, the event includes a water trivia contest, a raffle boasting many prizes and a chance to enjoy organic, local and sustainable food and service at Raglan. CityBeat editorial team duo David Rolland and Dave Maass create and host the four-part trivia series that includes multiple choice, picture matching, drawing and fill-in-the-blank challenges.</div> <br /> <div style="font-weight: normal;"></div> <div style="font-weight: normal;"></div> <div style="font-weight: normal;">Focusing on environmental sustainability, Raglan Public House practices a “reduce and reuse” mantra and uses 100 percent organic beef on its burgers, which were voted the best in San Diego in 2006-2012.</div> <br /> <div style="font-weight: normal;"></div> <div style="font-weight: normal;"></div> <div style="font-weight: normal;">“Coastkeeper proudly partners with Raglan Public House for our trivia event on Earth Day because supporting local, sustainably minded businesses is one of the best ways for San Diegans to think Earth first every day of the year,” said San Diego Coastkeeper Executive Director Gale Filter.</div> <br /> <div style="font-weight: normal;"></div> <div style="font-weight: normal;"></div> <div style="font-weight: normal;">Coastkeeper invites residents join the fun for $10 a person. Teams of up to six people are allowed. Join at Raglan at 1851 Bacon St, Ocean Beach, San Diego, CA 92107 on Thursday from 7 pm. - 10 p.m. on April 19 for the ultimate Earth Day destination.</div> <br /> <div style="font-weight: normal;"></div> <div style="font-weight: normal;"></div> <div style="font-weight: normal;">Also, in honor of Earth Day, Sprinkles Cupcakes invites planet lovers to get their Earth Day cupcake during the week of April 16 - 20. One hundred percent of proceeds will go to Coastkeeper to protect and restore fishable, swimmable and drinkable waters in San Diego County.</div> <br /> <div style="font-weight: normal;"></div> <div style="font-weight: normal;"></div> <div style="font-weight: normal;">In addition to the Earth Day Trivia event, San Diego Coastkeeper invites San Diego residents to celebrate Earth Day with its Water Quality Monitoring and Moonlight Beach Cleanup on April 21. Along with the events, the organization offers sponsored cleanups, Beach Cleanup in a Box and boat tours for those interested in philanthropic and learning opportunities.</div> <br /> <div style="font-weight: normal;"></div> <div style="font-weight: normal;"></div> <div style="font-weight: normal;">For other events, please visit Coastkeeper’s events calendar.For more information on the event and San Diego Coastkeeper, please visit organization’s official website at localhost/sdcoastkeeper.</div> <div style="font-weight: normal;"></div> <div style="font-weight: normal;"></div> </div> </strong></div> <p><br />###<br /><br />SAN DIEGO COASTKEEPER: Founded in 1995, San Diego Coastkeeper protects and restores fishable, swimmable and drinkable waters in San Diego County. Visit us online at http://localhost/sdcoastkeeper.</p>]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>March 22 - San Diego Coastkeeper Hosts 5th Annual Walk the Watershed on March 31</title>
		<link>http://localhost/demodata/?p=92</link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 25 Jul 2011 20:33:31 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[saltdevelopment]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://localhost/demodata/?p=92</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<p><em><span style="color: #808080;"><em><span style="font-size: 11pt; font-family: Arial;"> </span></em></span>Supervisor Cox, Councilmember Alvarez to visit event in Otay Valley Regional Park</em></p> <p></p>  <!--more-->  <div> <p><strong> </strong></p> <div style="position: absolute; left: -10000px; top: 90px; width: 1px; height: 1px; overflow: hidden;" id="_mcePaste"><strong>s are also available on the website.</strong></div> </div> <p>SAN DIEGO, March 22, 2012 – On March 31 from 9 a.m. - noon, San Diego Coastkeeper combines education, outdoor exploration and restoration during its 5th Annual Walk the Watershed at Otay Valley Regional Park. The free event will engage participants with activities to restore the watershed and teach how pollution affects our inland waters and ocean.</p> <p>Walk the Watershed will bring together school students and community members of all ages to take a walk through five educational stations consisting of watershed models, an introduction to native and invasive plants and wildlife, historical land use, urban runoff and a restoration project. Participants will also have the option to volunteer on invasive plant removal to restore Otay Watershed.</p> <p>Event organizers expect about 300 students and community members to participate in the event, which concludes with closing ceremonies, food, entertainment and raffle prizes. San Diego County Supervisor Greg Cox and Councilmember David Alvarez will join the event to talk about protecting our environment and the role Otay Valley Regional Park plays in a community effort to restore open spaces.</p> <p>This event is free and open to the public, but participants must RSVP to outreach@localhost/sdcoastkeeper. It takes place at Otay Valley Regional Park at Finney Elementary, 3950 Byrd Street, San Diego, CA 92154.Unified Port of San Diego, Metropolitan Water District of Southern California, WiLDCOAST, Elementary Institute of Science, Allied Waste, City of Chula Vista, Otay Valley Regional Park, REI and I Love A Clean San Diego partnered with Coastkeeper to make this event a success.</p> <p>For more information about Walk the Watershed, visit Coastkeeper’s website at http://localhost/sdcoastkeeper/act/green-events-in-san-diego/walk-the-watershed.html.</p> <p>###<br /><br />SAN DIEGO COASTKEEPER: Founded in 1995, San Diego Coastkeeper protects and restores fishable, swimmable and drinkable waters in San Diego County. Visit us online at http://localhost/sdcoastkeeper.</p>]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>November 4 - “First Flush” Rain Poses Serious Threat to San Diego’s Water Quality</title>
		<link>http://localhost/demodata/?p=79</link>
		<pubDate>Fri, 04 Nov 2011 21:40:57 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[saltdevelopment]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://localhost/demodata/?p=79</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<p><st1:personname w:st="on"><em>San Diego Coastkeeper</em></st1:personname><em> advises beachgoers to check beach status page, change habits</em></p> <p></p>  <!--more-->  <p><st1:city w:st="on">SAN DIEGO</st1:city>, Friday, Nov. 4, 2011 – As of today, the rainy season marches into the <st1:city w:st="on"><st1:place w:st="on">San Diego</st1:place></st1:city> region. But the change from sunny to gloomy is not <st1:personname w:st="on">San Diego Coastkeeper</st1:personname>’s main concern. The organization, a watchdog for inland and coastal water quality protection, advises San Diego residents about urban runoff from land that will dramatically impact water quality across the county’s coastline.</p> <p>Known as the single biggest threat to water quality in San Diego, urban runoff creates many negative impacts for San Diego’s coastal waters. As the rainwater washes over man-made surfaces in densely populated areas, it will absorb the materials collected on the surface such as oil, grease, pesticides, metals, bacteria, viruses and toxic chemicals that have cumulated after many dry months. As this washes into the waters with the season’s rain, San Diego experiences the “first flush,” which causes dangerously high levels of pollution in the county’s waters. <a href="blog/urban-runoff/item/192-first-flush-of-urban-runoff.html">Read more about San Diego’s water quality during the first flush</a> in a blog post written by Coastkeeper Lab Manager <st1:personname w:st="on">Travis Pritchard</st1:personname>.</p> <p>In addition to carrying pollutants into the waters, the first flush also captures litter scattered across the county. Research estimates that 80 percent of marine debris comes from land, and Coastkeeper’s <a href="learn/marine-debris/data-from-san-diego-beach-cleanups.html">beach cleanup data</a> demonstrate that plastic materials account for the vast majority of marine debris found regionally.</p> <p>Coastkeeper reminds residents that they can take steps today to reduce the runoff impact such as using fewer pesticides and fertilizers, picking up litter, using reusable items and cleaning up after their pets. <a href="blog/marine-debris/item/194-welcome-to-the-first-flush-the-start-of-san-diegos-rain.html">Learn more about the first flush and steps residents can take to reduce marine debris that enters our ocean</a> as written by <st1:personname w:st="on">Alicia Glassco</st1:personname>, Coastkeeper’s education and marine debris manager.</p> <p>Coastkeeper also suggests residents check <a href="quick-links/beach-advisories.html">its beach status page</a> before going out in the water. The website contains advisories and closures for 56 beach locations where the county collects water quality samples to determine whether human contact with coastal waters is safe. <st1:personname w:st="on">San Diego Coastkeeper</st1:personname> updates the site daily.</p> <p>“Today’s biggest pollution problem is no longer caused by one major evildoer,” said Coastkeeper Executive Director <st1:personname w:st="on">Gale Filter</st1:personname>. “Our biggest threat to water quality is urban runoff, and every single resident plays a role in bringing that monster down.”</p> <p>The organization also invites San Diegans to learn more about urban runoff and how to slow it at <a href="act/green-events-in-san-diego/signs-of-the-tide.html">Signs of the Tide: Put a LID</a> on Pollution on Dec. 6. The event will focus on how residents can utilize the principles of low impact development (LID) to improve water quality, while also making San Diego a greener city.</p> <p>For more information on beach water quality, watershed monitoring by Coastkeeper volunteers and beach cleanups, visit Coastkeeper’s website at <a href="http://localhost/sdcoastkeeper/">http://localhost/sdcoastkeeper</a>.</p> <p align="center">###</p> <p>Founded in 1995, <st1:personname w:st="on">San Diego Coastkeeper</st1:personname> protects the region's bays, beaches, watersheds and ocean for the people and wildlife that depend on them. We balance community outreach, education, and advocacy to promote stewardship of clean water and a healthy coastal ecosystem. For more information, visit <st1:personname w:st="on">San Diego Coastkeeper</st1:personname> online at http://localhost/sdcoastkeeper.</p> <p> </p>]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>November 7 - San Diego Coastkeeper Honors 2011 Coastal Champions at Ocean Gala</title>
		<link>http://localhost/demodata/?p=80</link>
		<pubDate>Fri, 04 Nov 2011 21:40:57 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[saltdevelopment]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://localhost/demodata/?p=80</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<p><em>Around 300 registered guests help raise $100,000 at environmental fundraiser</em></p> <p></p>  <!--more-->  <p>SAN DIEGO, Nov. 7, 2011 – On Saturday, San Diego Coastkeeper honored Ashok Israni, CEO of Pacifica Companies, and David Alvarez, San Diego City Councilmember, as the 2011 Coastal Champions at the organization’s 15<sup>th</sup> Annual Ocean Gala. The awardees were honored at the event with nearly 300 guests, who helped raise more than $100,000.</p> <p>During the event, Coastkeeper recognized Pacifica, a real estate investment company, for building projects that are models of sustainability in coastal development and for its role in two approvals for the Chula Vista Bayfront Master Plan. Chair of the San Diego City Council’s Natural Resources &amp; Culture Committee, Councilmember Alvarez earned recognition for his efforts in ensuring that San Diego relies on technologies providing the community with alternative sources of water in the most environmentally responsible way.</p> <p>Gale Filter, San Diego Coastkeeper’s new executive director closed the evening with his first formal address to the organization’s supporters.</p> <p>“I am Coastkeeper. You are Coastkeeper. We are Coastkeeper,” Gale told the guests. “Together we are leading the movement for clean water in San Diego.”</p> <p>Throughout the evening, the guests enjoyed fine and sustainable dining, 60 “going green” themed live and silent auction items, an art show of local artists’ work and the presence of city, county and school board officials. Surrounded by luxury décor at the Westin Gaslamp Quarter, the environmentally conscious attendees celebrated Coastkeeper’s movement to protect inland and coastal waters.</p> <p>Event sponsors include: Liquid Environmental Solutions; Ecology Auto Parts; Hunter Industries and David Welborn &amp; Ann Hunter-Welborn; San Diego Gas &amp; Electric; IBEW Local 569/United Association of Plumbers &amp; Pipefitters Local 230/Sheet Metal Workers Local 206/ NECA; KD Development; Pacifica Companies; Regency Centers Corporation; San Diego County Regional Airport Authority; Toma Sol Café; Unified Port of San Diego; Waitt Foundation. Generous contributions to make the evening look, taste and feel its best came from IKEA San Diego, Kona Brewing Company, Schmidt Design Group and OneHOPE Wine.</p> <p>For more information, visit San Diego Coastkeeper’s website <a href="http://localhost/sdcoastkeeper/">localhost/sdcoastkeeper</a> or official Ocean Gala website <a href="http://www.oceangala.org/">www.oceangala.org</a>.</p> <p align="center">###</p> <p>Founded in 1995, <st1:personname w:st="on">San Diego Coastkeeper</st1:personname> protects the region's bays, beaches, watersheds and ocean for the people and wildlife that depend on them. We balance community outreach, education, and advocacy to promote stewardship of clean water and a healthy coastal ecosystem. For more information, visit <st1:personname w:st="on">San Diego Coastkeeper</st1:personname> online at http://localhost/sdcoastkeeper.</p>]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
		<wp:post_id>80</wp:post_id>
		<wp:post_date><![CDATA[2011-11-04 21:40:57]]></wp:post_date>

		<wp:comment_status><![CDATA[open]]></wp:comment_status>
		<wp:ping_status><![CDATA[open]]></wp:ping_status>
		<wp:post_name><![CDATA[november-7-san-diego-coastkeeper-honors-2011-coastal-champions-at-ocean-gala]]></wp:post_name>
		<wp:status><![CDATA[publish]]></wp:status>
		<wp:post_parent>0</wp:post_parent>
		<wp:menu_order>49</wp:menu_order>
		<wp:post_type><![CDATA[post]]></wp:post_type>
		<wp:post_password><![CDATA[]]></wp:post_password>
		<wp:is_sticky>0</wp:is_sticky>
		<category domain="category" nicename="import-cate"><![CDATA[import cate]]></category>

			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[327]]></wp:meta_value>

	</item>
	<item>
		<title>November 10 - Public Urges Regional Board to Finally Order Cleanup of San Diego Bay</title>
		<link>http://localhost/demodata/?p=81</link>
		<pubDate>Thu, 10 Nov 2011 20:17:07 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[saltdevelopment]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://localhost/demodata/?p=81</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<p><em>Wednesday’s packed hearing had nearly unanimous support for an end to 20-year debate <br /></em><em></em></p>  <!--more-->  <p><br />SAN DIEGO, Nov. 10, 2011 – San Diego Coastkeeper, Environmental Health Coalition (EHC) and community and business members gathered last night to give public comment to the Regional Water Quality Control Board regarding the cleanup of pollution in San Diego Bay. Almost without exception, the public testimony asked the Regional Board to end the 20-year battle and finally order a cleanup of the bay. <br /><br />“I’m a bit overwhelmed with all of the support for this cleanup,” said San Diego Coastkeeper Advocacy Director Gabriel Solmer, who began her career working on this issue eight years ago. “The message we heard here tonight is clear—we all want a cleaner San Diego Bay without any further delays.”<br /><br />Hundreds of supporters filled the Regional Board’s hearing room for the start of public comment at 5 p.m., which lasted until 7:30 p.m. Those who expressed affiliation with BAE or NASSCO wore green shirts. And those affiliated with Coastkeeper and EHC wore blue shirts.<br /><br />“Regardless of shirt color, the people who testified asked the Regional Board to finally pass a cleanup order to remove the toxic pollution at the bottom of our bay,” said Environmental Health Coalition’s Laura Hunter. “We agree.”<br /><br />In considering the proposed cleanup order, Coastkeeper and EHC asked the board to change monitoring and trigger levels to better safeguard the cleanup. According to Solmer, these additional measures will add minimal, if any cost, and will allow the dischargers to know when they’ve successfully hit their marks. <br /><br />“The people last night shared so many reasons to get this cleanup done and done right—environmental justice, economic impact, health concerns and more,” said Hunter. “We need these additional measures to ensure this cleanup meets its goals the first time.” <br /><br />The Regional Board will continue the four-day panel hearing next week. Currently the board only has three members, which is not enough to reach quorum for a vote on the issue. But according to Regional Board officials, the members expect to make an official vote before the end of the year. <br /> <br />San Diego Bay is listed under the federal Clean Water Act for 20 separate pollutants including sediment toxicity, copper, mercury, PAHs, PCBs, zinc, chlordane and benthic community effects. Its ongoing toxicity hurts fish, aquatic wildlife and the community that depends on them. Due to the fish contamination from the pollutants, the Port of San Diego posted all piers along San Diego Bay with fish consumption advisories. Unfortunately, residents still catch and eat fish from the bay, resulting in serious human health risks.<br /><br />“After 20 long years of delay and postponement, we are buoyed by the amazing public response to clean the bay now. Decision makers heard loud and clear that San Diegans want their bay back,” said Solmer.  <br /><br />To find out more about San Diego Bay, Coastkeeper and Environmental Health Coalition’s work on the cleanup, visit Coastkeeper’s official website localhost/sdcoastkeeper. <br /><br />###<br /><br />Founded in 1995, San Diego Coastkeeper protects the region’s inland and coastal waters for the communities and wildlife that depend on them by blending education, community empowerment and advocacy. Visit us online at http://localhost/sdcoastkeeper.<br /><br />Founded in 1980, Environmental Health Coalition (EHC) builds grassroots campaigns to confront the unjust consequences of toxic pollution, discriminatory land use, and unsustainable energy policies. Visit us online at http://www.environmentalhealth.org/.</p>]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
		<wp:post_id>81</wp:post_id>

	<item>
		<title>November 14 - San Diego Coastkeeper’s Signs of the Tide Puts a LID on Pollution</title>
		<link>http://localhost/demodata/?p=82</link>
		<pubDate>Thu, 10 Nov 2011 20:17:07 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[saltdevelopment]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://localhost/demodata/?p=82</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<p><em>The event unravels how low impact development can seize urban runoff</em></p> <p><em> </em></p>  <!--more-->  <div id="_mcePaste" style="position: absolute; left: -10000px; top: 0px; width: 1px; height: 1px; overflow-x: hidden; overflow-y: hidden;">SAN DIEGO, Nov. 14, 2011 – Urban runoff, the single biggest threat to San Diego water, continues to impact the region’s water quality of inland and coastal waters. On Dec. 6, San Diego Coastkeeper invites residents to its Signs of the Tide: Put a LID on Pollution event to find out how they can stop the urban runoff and save the region’s waters from pollution.</div> <div id="_mcePaste" style="position: absolute; left: -10000px; top: 0px; width: 1px; height: 1px; overflow-x: hidden; overflow-y: hidden;">Moderated by Robert Santos, a weathercaster and reporter at ABC10 News, the attendees will learn from the various experts about low impact development (LID) and options San Diego has to implement this urban runoff prevention tool.</div> <div id="_mcePaste" style="position: absolute; left: -10000px; top: 0px; width: 1px; height: 1px; overflow-x: hidden; overflow-y: hidden;">The speakers include:</div> <div id="_mcePaste" style="position: absolute; left: -10000px; top: 0px; width: 1px; height: 1px; overflow-x: hidden; overflow-y: hidden;">•<span style="white-space: pre;"> </span>Edward Beldenwill, a US Green Council Boardmember and principal at SCALEgreen LLC, will discuss the major LID features in Southern California. He will address LID costs and benefits, including reducing polluted runoff, improved water supply and flood control.</div> <div id="_mcePaste" style="position: absolute; left: -10000px; top: 0px; width: 1px; height: 1px; overflow-x: hidden; overflow-y: hidden;">•<span style="white-space: pre;"> </span>Bill Harris, supervising public information officer for the City of San Diego, will answer the questions like why San Diego needs the LID and the outcomes of using LID in our community.</div> <div id="_mcePaste" style="position: absolute; left: -10000px; top: 0px; width: 1px; height: 1px; overflow-x: hidden; overflow-y: hidden;">•<span style="white-space: pre;"> </span>Leslie Ryan, landscape architecture department chair at the NewSchool of Architecture and Design, will explore a real-world low impact development designs to address current problems with stormwater and flooding in the Ocean Beach community.</div> <div id="_mcePaste" style="position: absolute; left: -10000px; top: 0px; width: 1px; height: 1px; overflow-x: hidden; overflow-y: hidden;">To highlight the real-world application of LID in San Diego, Coastkeeper partnered with landscape architecture students from the NewSchool of Architecture and Design and Ocean Beach Mainstreet Association to work on creating innovative urban designs to reduce water pollution in Ocean Beach. The students worked on low impact development design solutions that focus on keeping stormwater on site, infiltrating or capturing it, primarily by harnessing the power of plants. The students will present these low impact design projects at the event.</div> <div id="_mcePaste" style="position: absolute; left: -10000px; top: 0px; width: 1px; height: 1px; overflow-x: hidden; overflow-y: hidden;">The Signs of the Tide is on Dec. 6, 2011, from 6 p.m. – 8 p.m. at Electric Ladyland Art and Music Center at 4944 Newport Ave., San Diego, CA 92107. Coastkeeper will provide light food and refreshments. The coordinators advise the attendees to park along Newport Ave. The participants can also park at The Apple Tree Market, municipal parking at the end of Newport Ave. or a parking lot behind OB Surf and Skate.</div> <div id="_mcePaste" style="position: absolute; left: -10000px; top: 0px; width: 1px; height: 1px; overflow-x: hidden; overflow-y: hidden;">Ocean Beach Mainstreet Association, NewSchool of Architecture and Design and Think Blue San Diego proudly sponsor Signs of the Tide: Put a Lid on Pollution event.</div> <div id="_mcePaste" style="position: absolute; left: -10000px; top: 0px; width: 1px; height: 1px; overflow-x: hidden; overflow-y: hidden;">For more information, please visit localhost/sdcoastkeeper.</div> <div id="_mcePaste" style="position: absolute; left: -10000px; top: 0px; width: 1px; height: 1px; overflow-x: hidden; overflow-y: hidden;">###</div> <div id="_mcePaste" style="position: absolute; left: -10000px; top: 0px; width: 1px; height: 1px; overflow-x: hidden; overflow-y: hidden;">Founded in 1995, San Diego Coastkeeper protects the region's bays, beaches, watersheds and ocean for the people and wildlife that depend on them. We balance community outreach, education, and advocacy to promote stewardship of clean water and a healthy coastal ecosystem. For more information, visit San Diego Coastkeeper online at http://localhost/sdcoastkeeper.</div> <div></div> <p> <p>SAN DIEGO, Nov. 14, 2011 – Urban runoff, the single biggest threat to San Diego water, continues to impact the region’s water quality of inland and coastal waters. On Dec. 6, San Diego Coastkeeper invites residents to its Signs of the Tide: Put a LID on Pollution event to find out how they can stop the urban runoff and save the region’s waters from pollution.</p> <p>Moderated by Robert Santos, a weathercaster and reporter at ABC10 News, the attendees will learn from the various experts about low impact development (LID) and options San Diego has to implement this urban runoff prevention tool.</p> <p>The speakers include:</p> <p>•<span style="white-space: pre;"> </span>Edward Beldenwill, a US Green Council Boardmember and principal at SCALEgreen LLC, will discuss the major LID features in Southern California. He will address LID costs and benefits, including reducing polluted runoff, improved water supply and flood control.</p> <p>•<span style="white-space: pre;"> </span>Bill Harris, supervising public information officer for the City of San Diego, will answer the questions like why San Diego needs the LID and the outcomes of using LID in our community.</p> <p>•<span style="white-space: pre;"> </span>Leslie Ryan, landscape architecture department chair at the NewSchool of Architecture and Design, will explore a real-world low impact development designs to address current problems with stormwater and flooding in the Ocean Beach community.</p> <p>To highlight the real-world application of LID in San Diego, Coastkeeper partnered with landscape architecture students from the NewSchool of Architecture and Design and Ocean Beach Mainstreet Association to work on creating innovative urban designs to reduce water pollution in Ocean Beach. The students worked on low impact development design solutions that focus on keeping stormwater on site, infiltrating or capturing it, primarily by harnessing the power of plants. The students will present these low impact design projects at the event.</p> <p>The Signs of the Tide is on Dec. 6, 2011, from 6 p.m. – 8 p.m. at Electric Ladyland Art and Music Center at 4944 Newport Ave., San Diego, CA 92107. Coastkeeper will provide light food and refreshments. The coordinators advise the attendees to park along Newport Ave. The participants can also park at The Apple Tree Market, municipal parking at the end of Newport Ave. or a parking lot behind OB Surf and Skate.</p> <p>Ocean Beach Mainstreet Association, NewSchool of Architecture and Design and Think Blue San Diego proudly sponsor Signs of the Tide: Put a Lid on Pollution event.</p> <p>For more information, please visit localhost/sdcoastkeeper.</p> <p style="text-align: center;">###</p> <p>Founded in 1995, San Diego Coastkeeper protects the region's bays, beaches, watersheds and ocean for the people and wildlife that depend on them. We balance community outreach, education, and advocacy to promote stewardship of clean water and a healthy coastal ecosystem. For more information, visit San Diego Coastkeeper online at http://localhost/sdcoastkeeper.</p> </p> <p> </p>]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>December 5 -  Shop Smart and Win with Reusable Bags in San Diego County on Dec. 15</title>
		<link>http://localhost/demodata/?p=83</link>
		<pubDate>Thu, 10 Nov 2011 20:17:07 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[saltdevelopment]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://localhost/demodata/?p=83</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<p></p>  <!--more-->  <div id="_mcePaste" style="position: absolute; left: -10000px; top: 0px; width: 1px; height: 1px; overflow-x: hidden; overflow-y: hidden;">SAN DIEGO, Nov. 14, 2011 – Urban runoff, the single biggest threat to San Diego water, continues to impact the region’s water quality of inland and coastal waters. On Dec. 6, San Diego Coastkeeper invites residents to its Signs of the Tide: Put a LID on Pollution event to find out how they can stop the urban runoff and save the region’s waters from pollution.</div> <div id="_mcePaste" style="position: absolute; left: -10000px; top: 0px; width: 1px; height: 1px; overflow-x: hidden; overflow-y: hidden;">Moderated by Robert Santos, a weathercaster and reporter at ABC10 News, the attendees will learn from the various experts about low impact development (LID) and options San Diego has to implement this urban runoff prevention tool.</div> <div id="_mcePaste" style="position: absolute; left: -10000px; top: 0px; width: 1px; height: 1px; overflow-x: hidden; overflow-y: hidden;">The speakers include:</div> <div id="_mcePaste" style="position: absolute; left: -10000px; top: 0px; width: 1px; height: 1px; overflow-x: hidden; overflow-y: hidden;">•<span style="white-space: pre;"> </span>Edward Beldenwill, a US Green Council Boardmember and principal at SCALEgreen LLC, will discuss the major LID features in Southern California. He will address LID costs and benefits, including reducing polluted runoff, improved water supply and flood control.</div> <div id="_mcePaste" style="position: absolute; left: -10000px; top: 0px; width: 1px; height: 1px; overflow-x: hidden; overflow-y: hidden;">•<span style="white-space: pre;"> </span>Bill Harris, supervising public information officer for the City of San Diego, will answer the questions like why San Diego needs the LID and the outcomes of using LID in our community.</div> <div id="_mcePaste" style="position: absolute; left: -10000px; top: 0px; width: 1px; height: 1px; overflow-x: hidden; overflow-y: hidden;">•<span style="white-space: pre;"> </span>Leslie Ryan, landscape architecture department chair at the NewSchool of Architecture and Design, will explore a real-world low impact development designs to address current problems with stormwater and flooding in the Ocean Beach community.</div> <div id="_mcePaste" style="position: absolute; left: -10000px; top: 0px; width: 1px; height: 1px; overflow-x: hidden; overflow-y: hidden;">To highlight the real-world application of LID in San Diego, Coastkeeper partnered with landscape architecture students from the NewSchool of Architecture and Design and Ocean Beach Mainstreet Association to work on creating innovative urban designs to reduce water pollution in Ocean Beach. The students worked on low impact development design solutions that focus on keeping stormwater on site, infiltrating or capturing it, primarily by harnessing the power of plants. The students will present these low impact design projects at the event.</div> <div id="_mcePaste" style="position: absolute; left: -10000px; top: 0px; width: 1px; height: 1px; overflow-x: hidden; overflow-y: hidden;">The Signs of the Tide is on Dec. 6, 2011, from 6 p.m. – 8 p.m. at Electric Ladyland Art and Music Center at 4944 Newport Ave., San Diego, CA 92107. Coastkeeper will provide light food and refreshments. The coordinators advise the attendees to park along Newport Ave. The participants can also park at The Apple Tree Market, municipal parking at the end of Newport Ave. or a parking lot behind OB Surf and Skate.</div> <div id="_mcePaste" style="position: absolute; left: -10000px; top: 0px; width: 1px; height: 1px; overflow-x: hidden; overflow-y: hidden;">Ocean Beach Mainstreet Association, NewSchool of Architecture and Design and Think Blue San Diego proudly sponsor Signs of the Tide: Put a Lid on Pollution event.</div> <div id="_mcePaste" style="position: absolute; left: -10000px; top: 0px; width: 1px; height: 1px; overflow-x: hidden; overflow-y: hidden;">For more information, please visit localhost/sdcoastkeeper.</div> <div id="_mcePaste" style="position: absolute; left: -10000px; top: 0px; width: 1px; height: 1px; overflow-x: hidden; overflow-y: hidden;">###</div> <div id="_mcePaste" style="position: absolute; left: -10000px; top: 0px; width: 1px; height: 1px; overflow-x: hidden; overflow-y: hidden;">Founded in 1995, San Diego Coastkeeper protects the region's bays, beaches, watersheds and ocean for the people and wildlife that depend on them. We balance community outreach, education, and advocacy to promote stewardship of clean water and a healthy coastal ecosystem. For more information, visit San Diego Coastkeeper online at http://localhost/sdcoastkeeper.</div> <p>SAN DIEGO, Dec. 5, 2011 – For the second year, cities throughout the San Diego region, local community groups, environmental organizations, and the County of San Diego have proclaimed the third Thursday of December as a “Day Without a Bag”. The purpose of the event is to educate and raise awareness of the need to keep communities, waterways, and beaches clean via litter prevention, and to promote a ‘greener’ holiday season through reuse.</p> <p>On Thursday, Dec. 15, 2011, businesses and residents will promote and benefit from using reusable bags for their holiday and regular shopping needs instead of standard single-use plastic and paper bags. “This is a region-wide event to support a habit change that encourages a much wiser use of our resources by reminding shoppers to choose reusable shopping bags over disposables. Reuse is far better than recycling. It prevents waste and helps to aid in overall litter reduction,” stated Regional Coordinator Jacy Bolden.</p> <p>Each year, people in the greater San Diego region use more than 1.7 billion plastic bags, which equates to about 500 bags per person annually.  According to the U.S. EPA, less than five percent of plastic bags are actually recycled, and they are made from non-renewable fossil fuels.  Even though paper bags are easily recycled in curbside programs, supporters of a “Day Without A Bag” stress that a single-use of any type of bag is not the best use of natural resources. During the 2010 event over 28,000 bags were given away at over 150 locations throughout the San Diego region.  Bolden noted that many residents commented that they had bags but had a hard time remembering them. To help their shoppers remember, several grocers such as Albertsons, Trader Joe’s and Vons are providing drawings for $25 gift certificates to those shoppers using a reusable bag in their stores.  “Similar types of positive incentive promotions for reusable bags have proven that shoppers have responded positively and some grocers have indicated a 40-60% decrease in disposable bag usage. Clearly it’s an effective promotion,” stated Bolden.</p> <p>To make the event possible, grocers, retailers, waste haulers, jurisdictions and volunteers anticipate giving away several thousand reusable shopping bags and providing great reward incentives at numerous locations throughout the county.  The major regional sponsors providing financial and in-kind support include San Diego Union Tribune, Think Blue San Diego Region, SeaWorld, and the cities of Carlsbad, Chula Vista, Encinitas, Oceanside, Poway and Solana Beach.  Key organizations coordinating volunteers and promotions countywide include:  San Diego Coastkeeper, I Love A Clean San Diego, Solana Center for Environmental Innovation, and the San Diego Chapter of the Surfrider Foundation.</p> <p>Regionwide grocers and retailers participating include:  99 Cent Only Stores, Albertsons, Jimbo’s…Naturally!, Ralphs, Target, Trader Joe’s, Vons, Whole Foods.  Retailers and volunteers interested in participating can find more information about the event by visiting <a href="http://www.nobagdaySD.org" target="_blank">www.NoBagDaySD.org</a>, which will include a Google map with incentive stores as well as bag giveaway locations and times.</p> <p style="text-align: center;">###</p>]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>December 14  - San Diego Coastkeeper Announces 2011 Water Quality Monitoring Data</title>
		<link>http://localhost/demodata/?p=84</link>
		<pubDate>Thu, 10 Nov 2011 20:17:07 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[saltdevelopment]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://localhost/demodata/?p=84</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<p></p>  <!--more-->  <div style="position: absolute; left: -10000px; top: 0px; width: 1px; height: 1px; overflow-x: hidden; overflow-y: hidden;" id="_mcePaste">SAN DIEGO, Nov. 14, 2011 – Urban runoff, the single biggest threat to San Diego water, continues to impact the region’s water quality of inland and coastal waters. On Dec. 6, San Diego Coastkeeper invites residents to its Signs of the Tide: Put a LID on Pollution event to find out how they can stop the urban runoff and save the region’s waters from pollution.</div> <div style="position: absolute; left: -10000px; top: 0px; width: 1px; height: 1px; overflow-x: hidden; overflow-y: hidden;" id="_mcePaste">Moderated by Robert Santos, a weathercaster and reporter at ABC10 News, the attendees will learn from the various experts about low impact development (LID) and options San Diego has to implement this urban runoff prevention tool.</div> <div style="position: absolute; left: -10000px; top: 0px; width: 1px; height: 1px; overflow-x: hidden; overflow-y: hidden;" id="_mcePaste">The speakers include:</div> <div style="position: absolute; left: -10000px; top: 0px; width: 1px; height: 1px; overflow-x: hidden; overflow-y: hidden;" id="_mcePaste">•<span style="white-space: pre;"> </span>Edward Beldenwill, a US Green Council Boardmember and principal at SCALEgreen LLC, will discuss the major LID features in Southern California. He will address LID costs and benefits, including reducing polluted runoff, improved water supply and flood control.</div> <div style="position: absolute; left: -10000px; top: 0px; width: 1px; height: 1px; overflow-x: hidden; overflow-y: hidden;" id="_mcePaste">•<span style="white-space: pre;"> </span>Bill Harris, supervising public information officer for the City of San Diego, will answer the questions like why San Diego needs the LID and the outcomes of using LID in our community.</div> <div style="position: absolute; left: -10000px; top: 0px; width: 1px; height: 1px; overflow-x: hidden; overflow-y: hidden;" id="_mcePaste">•<span style="white-space: pre;"> </span>Leslie Ryan, landscape architecture department chair at the NewSchool of Architecture and Design, will explore a real-world low impact development designs to address current problems with stormwater and flooding in the Ocean Beach community.</div> <div style="position: absolute; left: -10000px; top: 0px; width: 1px; height: 1px; overflow-x: hidden; overflow-y: hidden;" id="_mcePaste">To highlight the real-world application of LID in San Diego, Coastkeeper partnered with landscape architecture students from the NewSchool of Architecture and Design and Ocean Beach Mainstreet Association to work on creating innovative urban designs to reduce water pollution in Ocean Beach. The students worked on low impact development design solutions that focus on keeping stormwater on site, infiltrating or capturing it, primarily by harnessing the power of plants. The students will present these low impact design projects at the event.</div> <div style="position: absolute; left: -10000px; top: 0px; width: 1px; height: 1px; overflow-x: hidden; overflow-y: hidden;" id="_mcePaste">The Signs of the Tide is on Dec. 6, 2011, from 6 p.m. – 8 p.m. at Electric Ladyland Art and Music Center at 4944 Newport Ave., San Diego, CA 92107. Coastkeeper will provide light food and refreshments. The coordinators advise the attendees to park along Newport Ave. The participants can also park at The Apple Tree Market, municipal parking at the end of Newport Ave. or a parking lot behind OB Surf and Skate.</div> <div style="position: absolute; left: -10000px; top: 0px; width: 1px; height: 1px; overflow-x: hidden; overflow-y: hidden;" id="_mcePaste">Ocean Beach Mainstreet Association, NewSchool of Architecture and Design and Think Blue San Diego proudly sponsor Signs of the Tide: Put a Lid on Pollution event.</div> <div style="position: absolute; left: -10000px; top: 0px; width: 1px; height: 1px; overflow-x: hidden; overflow-y: hidden;" id="_mcePaste">For more information, please visit localhost/sdcoastkeeper.</div> <div style="position: absolute; left: -10000px; top: 0px; width: 1px; height: 1px; overflow-x: hidden; overflow-y: hidden;" id="_mcePaste">###</div> <div style="position: absolute; left: -10000px; top: 0px; width: 1px; height: 1px; overflow-x: hidden; overflow-y: hidden;" id="_mcePaste">Founded in 1995, San Diego Coastkeeper protects the region's bays, beaches, watersheds and ocean for the people and wildlife that depend on them. We balance community outreach, education, and advocacy to promote stewardship of clean water and a healthy coastal ecosystem. For more information, visit San Diego Coastkeeper online at http://localhost/sdcoastkeeper.</div> <p> <p>SAN DIEGO, Dec. 14, 2011- San Diego Coastkeeper’s 2011 Water Quality Monitoring data show minimal improvements of the water conditions throughout San Diego County as compared to 2010 data. Sweetwater Watershed’s water quality score improved by 20 percent and Tijuana and San Dieguito Watersheds’ water conditions worsened.</p> <p>According to Coastkeeper’s scoring methodology for its water quality data, Sweetwater watershed’s score improved 20 percent from 2010. This means that the number of times that contaminants exceeded healthy levels dropped by 50 percent this year, or Coastkeeper detected pollution less often.</p> <p>"We're seeing decreased levels of ammonia and fecal indicator bacteria pollution in this watershed, which we could attribute to a variety of factors," said Travis Pritchard, San Diego Coastkeeper's Water Quality Monitoring Program Manager. "Sampling timing, water flow or urban runoff impacts could be driving the increase in water quality we are seeing. We hope this trend will continue and that the efforts to reduce pollution in this watershed are working."</p> <p>In spite of the improvement, Sweetwater Watershed’s water quality still remains in fair condition.</p> <p>Other watersheds in the county, mainly Los Peñasquitos, Otay, San Luis Rey, San Diego, Pueblos and Carlsbad Watersheds, also showed minimal improvement in the water quality. But all remain in fair condition based on the data collected through the year.</p> <p>Another significant highlight from Coastkeeper’s efforts in 2011 occurred when the organization’s volunteers discovered where the 2.6-million gallon sewage spill settled in the Los Peñasquitos Lagoon. The findings prompted the city to start their cleanup, which required them to restore water quality in the lagoon to the historical standards shown by Coastkeeper’s monthly data. Without Coastkeeper’s Water Quality Monitoring Program’s volunteers, the sewage could have remained in the lagoon for an undetermined amount of time.</p> <p>Another project in 2011 involved the San Dieguito River Park, which sets an example for improving water quality in a watershed. The organization constructed treatment wetlands to treat stormwater from the 313-acre watershed before it goes into the fragile San Dieguito Lagoon. Coastkeeper began monitoring the inflow and outflow of these wetlands in December 2010 and has now completed the first year of monitoring. Coastkeeper’s data show the wetlands successfully filter contaminants out and deliver cleaner water to the lagoon.</p> <p>In the upcoming year, Coastkeeper wants San Diego residents to join them in pursuing its long-term goal for good and excellent water conditions throughout the county.</p> <p>Coastkeeper invites volunteers and funders to get involved by:</p> <ul> <li>Volunteering. Coastkeeper trains new Water Quality Monitoring volunteers every other month and invites people of all ages and backgrounds to help collect samples in the field and run lab analyses. To sign up, perspective participants can email volunteer@localhost/sdcoastkeeper. </li> <li>Checking water quality on Coastkeeper’s website. The organization posts the current beach water quality status, along with the historic beach water quality data in graphs. The watershed information and water quality data can be accessed through Coastkeeper’s site at localhost/sdcoastkeeper. </li> <li>Donating. Coastkeeper wants to expand its capacity to cover more parts of the county and also add more investigatory work like rain event monitoring. Donations will go along way to building capacity.</li> <li>Hiring Coastkeeper. For any water quality monitoring related projects for non-profit or charity organizations, contact San Diego Coastkeeper Water Quality Monitoring Lab Manager Travis Pritchard at travis@localhost/sdcoastkeeper for more information. </li> </ul> <p>The dates for 2012 Water Quality Monitoring include:</p> <ul> <li>Jan. 21: New Volunteers, 8 a.m. - Returning Volunteers, 11 a.m.</li> <li>Feb. 25: Returning Volunteers Only – 9 a.m.</li> <li>March 17: New Volunteers, 8 a.m. - Returning Volunteers, 11 a.m.</li> <li>April 21: Returning Volunteers Only – 9 a.m.</li> <li>May 19: New Volunteers, 8 a.m. - Returning Volunteers, 11 a.m.</li> <li>June 23: Returning Volunteers Only - 9 a.m.</li> <li>July 21: New Volunteers, 8 a.m. - Returning Volunteers, 11 a.m.</li> <li>Aug. 18: Returning Volunteers Only - 9 a.m.</li> <li>Sept. 22: New Volunteers, 8 a.m. - Returning Volunteers, 11 a.m.</li> <li>Oct. 20: Returning Volunteers Only - 9 a.m.</li> <li>Nov. 17: New Volunteers, 8 a.m. - Returning Volunteers, 11 a.m.</li> <li>Dec. 15: Returning Volunteers Only- 9 a.m.</li> </ul> <p>For more information, visit Coastkeeper’s website. To contact San Dieguito River Park, please visit organization’s official website.</p> </p> <p style="text-align: center;">###</p>]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>January 11  - Coastkeeper, Surfrider Announce 2011 San Diego Beach Cleanup Data</title>
		<link>http://localhost/demodata/?p=85</link>
		<pubDate>Thu, 10 Nov 2011 20:17:07 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[saltdevelopment]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://localhost/demodata/?p=85</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<p><em>Volunteers collected more than 100,000 pieces of plastic countywide<br /></em></p>  <!--more-->  <div style="position: absolute; left: -10000px; top: 0px; width: 1px; height: 1px; overflow-x: hidden; overflow-y: hidden;" id="_mcePaste">SAN DIEGO, Nov. 14, 2011 – Urban runoff, the single biggest threat to San Diego water, continues to impact the region’s water quality of inland and coastal waters. On Dec. 6, San Diego Coastkeeper invites residents to its Signs of the Tide: Put a LID on Pollution event to find out how they can stop the urban runoff and save the region’s waters from pollution.</div> <div style="position: absolute; left: -10000px; top: 0px; width: 1px; height: 1px; overflow-x: hidden; overflow-y: hidden;" id="_mcePaste">Moderated by Robert Santos, a weathercaster and reporter at ABC10 News, the attendees will learn from the various experts about low impact development (LID) and options San Diego has to implement this urban runoff prevention tool.</div> <div style="position: absolute; left: -10000px; top: 0px; width: 1px; height: 1px; overflow-x: hidden; overflow-y: hidden;" id="_mcePaste">The speakers include:</div> <div style="position: absolute; left: -10000px; top: 0px; width: 1px; height: 1px; overflow-x: hidden; overflow-y: hidden;" id="_mcePaste">•<span style="white-space: pre;"> </span>Edward Beldenwill, a US Green Council Boardmember and principal at SCALEgreen LLC, will discuss the major LID features in Southern California. He will address LID costs and benefits, including reducing polluted runoff, improved water supply and flood control.</div> <div style="position: absolute; left: -10000px; top: 0px; width: 1px; height: 1px; overflow-x: hidden; overflow-y: hidden;" id="_mcePaste">•<span style="white-space: pre;"> </span>Bill Harris, supervising public information officer for the City of San Diego, will answer the questions like why San Diego needs the LID and the outcomes of using LID in our community.</div> <div style="position: absolute; left: -10000px; top: 0px; width: 1px; height: 1px; overflow-x: hidden; overflow-y: hidden;" id="_mcePaste">•<span style="white-space: pre;"> </span>Leslie Ryan, landscape architecture department chair at the NewSchool of Architecture and Design, will explore a real-world low impact development designs to address current problems with stormwater and flooding in the Ocean Beach community.</div> <div style="position: absolute; left: -10000px; top: 0px; width: 1px; height: 1px; overflow-x: hidden; overflow-y: hidden;" id="_mcePaste">To highlight the real-world application of LID in San Diego, Coastkeeper partnered with landscape architecture students from the NewSchool of Architecture and Design and Ocean Beach Mainstreet Association to work on creating innovative urban designs to reduce water pollution in Ocean Beach. The students worked on low impact development design solutions that focus on keeping stormwater on site, infiltrating or capturing it, primarily by harnessing the power of plants. The students will present these low impact design projects at the event.</div> <div style="position: absolute; left: -10000px; top: 0px; width: 1px; height: 1px; overflow-x: hidden; overflow-y: hidden;" id="_mcePaste">The Signs of the Tide is on Dec. 6, 2011, from 6 p.m. – 8 p.m. at Electric Ladyland Art and Music Center at 4944 Newport Ave., San Diego, CA 92107. Coastkeeper will provide light food and refreshments. The coordinators advise the attendees to park along Newport Ave. The participants can also park at The Apple Tree Market, municipal parking at the end of Newport Ave. or a parking lot behind OB Surf and Skate.</div> <div style="position: absolute; left: -10000px; top: 0px; width: 1px; height: 1px; overflow-x: hidden; overflow-y: hidden;" id="_mcePaste">Ocean Beach Mainstreet Association, NewSchool of Architecture and Design and Think Blue San Diego proudly sponsor Signs of the Tide: Put a Lid on Pollution event.</div> <div style="position: absolute; left: -10000px; top: 0px; width: 1px; height: 1px; overflow-x: hidden; overflow-y: hidden;" id="_mcePaste">For more information, please visit localhost/sdcoastkeeper.</div> <div style="position: absolute; left: -10000px; top: 0px; width: 1px; height: 1px; overflow-x: hidden; overflow-y: hidden;" id="_mcePaste">###</div> <div style="position: absolute; left: -10000px; top: 0px; width: 1px; height: 1px; overflow-x: hidden; overflow-y: hidden;" id="_mcePaste">Founded in 1995, San Diego Coastkeeper protects the region's bays, beaches, watersheds and ocean for the people and wildlife that depend on them. We balance community outreach, education, and advocacy to promote stewardship of clean water and a healthy coastal ecosystem. For more information, visit San Diego Coastkeeper online at http://localhost/sdcoastkeeper.</div> <p>SAN DIEGO, Jan. 12, 2012- Cigarette butts, plastic foam and plastics continue to be the top three most common items found on San Diego County’s beaches, according to data released today by San Diego Coastkeeper and the Surfrider Foundation San Diego Chapter. In partnership since 2003, the environmental organizations conduct twice-monthly beach cleanups throughout the county and ask volunteers to keep detailed records of the debris they remove. The data show that Pacific Beach’s Crystal Pier had the least trash in 2011, while Ocean Beach Pier had the most trash collected per volunteer.</p> <p>“The data help us identify from where trash on our beaches originates,” said Alicia Glassco, San Diego Coastkeeper’s Education and Marine Debris Manager. “For instance, we know that plastic foam tops our list every year, which means we can drastically minimize this pollution source by choosing food containers made of other, more Earth-friendly materials. Or even better, bring your own reusable food container.”</p> <p>Data collection cards from the 2011 cleanups also show:</p> <ul> <li>Six of the top ten category types recorded in 2011 are composed of plastic.</li> <li>We collected 11,000 more cigarette butts than in 2010.</li> <li>Styrofoam pieces are consistently one of the top three items counted.</li> <li>Interesting items found in 2011 included an eight-foot metal rod, carpet, spool of thread, traffic sign, gas pump, yo-yo and pair of safety goggles.</li> </ul> <p>“Plastic poses a serious threat to our marine and coastal ecosystems because it does not biodegrade. Even cigarette filters are made of plastic. The solution starts at home so please help us Rise Above Plastics and if you smoke, please Hold On To Your Butts,” said Surfrider Foundation San Diego Chapter Coordinator Haley Haggerstone. Alicia Glassco and Haggerstone <a href="http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=6_LPwKnvUeQ&amp;feature=youtu.be" target="_blank">explained the impact of the trash in the YouTube video</a>.</p> <p>Coastkeeper and Surfrider have also announced the full 2012 beach cleanup schedule, which rotates locations of popular beaches throughout the county and are open to all volunteers. At each cleanup, organizers anticipate 100 to 500 people. They do supply bags, gloves and water for those who participate, but request that volunteers bring their own gardening gloves, buckets and reusable water bottles to help reduce plastic usage during the pickup.</p> <p>For more information on San Diego beach cleanups, visit Coastkeeper’s website at localhost/sdcoastkeeper or Surfrider’s website at www.surfriderSD.org.</p> <p style="text-align: center;"># # #</p> <p><strong>San Diego Coastkeeper</strong></p> <p>Founded in 1995, San Diego Coastkeeper protects the region’s bays, beaches, watersheds and ocean for the people and wildlife that depend on them.  We balance community outreach, education, and advocacy to promote stewardship of clean water and a healthy coastal ecosystem.</p> <p><strong>Surfrider Foundation San Diego Chapter</strong></p> <p>The Surfrider Foundation is a non-profit grassroots environmental organization dedicated to the protection and enjoyment of oceans, waves and beaches through a powerful activist network. Founded in 1984 by a handful of visionary surfers in Malibu, California, the Surfrider Foundation now maintains over 60,000 members and 100 chapters worldwide.</p>]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>January 17  - San Diego Coastkeeper Hosts 5th Annual Walk the Watershed on March 31</title>
		<link>http://localhost/demodata/?p=86</link>
		<pubDate>Thu, 10 Nov 2011 20:17:07 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[saltdevelopment]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://localhost/demodata/?p=86</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<p><em>Participants will take a fun educational walk through Otay Watershed<br /></em></p>  <!--more-->  <div id="_mcePaste" style="position: absolute; left: -10000px; top: 0px; width: 1px; height: 1px; overflow-x: hidden; overflow-y: hidden;">SAN DIEGO, Nov. 14, 2011 – Urban runoff, the single biggest threat to San Diego water, continues to impact the region’s water quality of inland and coastal waters. On Dec. 6, San Diego Coastkeeper invites residents to its Signs of the Tide: Put a LID on Pollution event to find out how they can stop the urban runoff and save the region’s waters from pollution.</div> <div id="_mcePaste" style="position: absolute; left: -10000px; top: 0px; width: 1px; height: 1px; overflow-x: hidden; overflow-y: hidden;">Moderated by Robert Santos, a weathercaster and reporter at ABC10 News, the attendees will learn from the various experts about low impact development (LID) and options San Diego has to implement this urban runoff prevention tool.</div> <div id="_mcePaste" style="position: absolute; left: -10000px; top: 0px; width: 1px; height: 1px; overflow-x: hidden; overflow-y: hidden;">The speakers include:</div> <div id="_mcePaste" style="position: absolute; left: -10000px; top: 0px; width: 1px; height: 1px; overflow-x: hidden; overflow-y: hidden;">•<span style="white-space: pre;"> </span>Edward Beldenwill, a US Green Council Boardmember and principal at SCALEgreen LLC, will discuss the major LID features in Southern California. He will address LID costs and benefits, including reducing polluted runoff, improved water supply and flood control.</div> <div id="_mcePaste" style="position: absolute; left: -10000px; top: 0px; width: 1px; height: 1px; overflow-x: hidden; overflow-y: hidden;">•<span style="white-space: pre;"> </span>Bill Harris, supervising public information officer for the City of San Diego, will answer the questions like why San Diego needs the LID and the outcomes of using LID in our community.</div> <div id="_mcePaste" style="position: absolute; left: -10000px; top: 0px; width: 1px; height: 1px; overflow-x: hidden; overflow-y: hidden;">•<span style="white-space: pre;"> </span>Leslie Ryan, landscape architecture department chair at the NewSchool of Architecture and Design, will explore a real-world low impact development designs to address current problems with stormwater and flooding in the Ocean Beach community.</div> <div id="_mcePaste" style="position: absolute; left: -10000px; top: 0px; width: 1px; height: 1px; overflow-x: hidden; overflow-y: hidden;">To highlight the real-world application of LID in San Diego, Coastkeeper partnered with landscape architecture students from the NewSchool of Architecture and Design and Ocean Beach Mainstreet Association to work on creating innovative urban designs to reduce water pollution in Ocean Beach. The students worked on low impact development design solutions that focus on keeping stormwater on site, infiltrating or capturing it, primarily by harnessing the power of plants. The students will present these low impact design projects at the event.</div> <div id="_mcePaste" style="position: absolute; left: -10000px; top: 0px; width: 1px; height: 1px; overflow-x: hidden; overflow-y: hidden;">The Signs of the Tide is on Dec. 6, 2011, from 6 p.m. – 8 p.m. at Electric Ladyland Art and Music Center at 4944 Newport Ave., San Diego, CA 92107. Coastkeeper will provide light food and refreshments. The coordinators advise the attendees to park along Newport Ave. The participants can also park at The Apple Tree Market, municipal parking at the end of Newport Ave. or a parking lot behind OB Surf and Skate.</div> <div id="_mcePaste" style="position: absolute; left: -10000px; top: 0px; width: 1px; height: 1px; overflow-x: hidden; overflow-y: hidden;">Ocean Beach Mainstreet Association, NewSchool of Architecture and Design and Think Blue San Diego proudly sponsor Signs of the Tide: Put a Lid on Pollution event.</div> <div id="_mcePaste" style="position: absolute; left: -10000px; top: 0px; width: 1px; height: 1px; overflow-x: hidden; overflow-y: hidden;">For more information, please visit localhost/sdcoastkeeper.</div> <div id="_mcePaste" style="position: absolute; left: -10000px; top: 0px; width: 1px; height: 1px; overflow-x: hidden; overflow-y: hidden;">###</div> <div id="_mcePaste" style="position: absolute; left: -10000px; top: 0px; width: 1px; height: 1px; overflow-x: hidden; overflow-y: hidden;">Founded in 1995, San Diego Coastkeeper protects the region's bays, beaches, watersheds and ocean for the people and wildlife that depend on them. We balance community outreach, education, and advocacy to promote stewardship of clean water and a healthy coastal ecosystem. For more information, visit San Diego Coastkeeper online at http://localhost/sdcoastkeeper.</div> <p>SAN DIEGO, Jan. 17, 2012 – On March 31 from 8:30 a.m. - noon, San Diego Coastkeeper combines education and fun, while hosting its 5th Annual Walk the Watershed event at Otay Valley Regional Park. The free event will engage participants and students with fun activities to restore our watersheds and understand how inland pollution affects our ocean.</p> <p>Walk the Watershed will bring school students of all ages and community members to take a walk through several educational stations consisting of watershed models, introduction to native and invasive plants and wildlife, historical land use, urban runoff and restoration. Participants will also volunteer on restoration projects such as invasive plant removal to restore Otay Watershed.</p> <p>Event organizers expect about 300 students and community members to participate in the event, which concludes with closing ceremonies, food and entertainment.  This event is free and open to the public, but participants must RSVP to outreach@localhost/sdcoastkeeper. Coastkeeper invites everyone to come to Otay Valley Regional Park at Finney Elementary, 3950 Byrd Street, San Diego, CA 92154.</p> <p>Port of San Diego, WiLDCOAST, Elementary Institute of Science, Allied Waste, City of Chula Vista, Otay Valley Regional Park, County of San Diego Parks and Recreation and I Love A Clean San Diego partnered with Coastkeeper to make this event a success.</p> <p>For more information about Walk the Watershed, visit Coastkeeper’s website at localhost/sdcoastkeeper.</p> <p style="text-align: center;"># # #</p> <p><strong>San Diego Coastkeeper</strong></p> <p>Founded in 1995, San Diego Coastkeeper protects the region’s bays, beaches, watersheds and ocean for the people and wildlife that depend on them.  We balance community outreach, education, and advocacy to promote stewardship of clean water and a healthy coastal ecosystem.</p>]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
		<wp:post_id>86</wp:post_id>

		<wp:post_date_gmt><![CDATA[2011-11-10 20:17:07]]></wp:post_date_gmt>

		<wp:post_type><![CDATA[post]]></wp:post_type>

		<wp:is_sticky>0</wp:is_sticky>
		<category domain="category" nicename="import-cate"><![CDATA[import cate]]></category>

	</item>
	<item>
		<title>April 5 - San Diego Coastkeeper Opens Coastal Champions Award Nominations for 2012</title>
		<link>http://localhost/demodata/?p=93</link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 25 Jul 2011 20:33:31 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[saltdevelopment]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://localhost/demodata/?p=93</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<p><em><span style="color: #808080;"><em><span style="font-size: 11pt; font-family: Arial;"> </span></em></span>The organization will hold the awards breakfast on World Oceans Day on June 8</em></p> <p></p>  <!--more-->  <div> <p><strong> </strong></p> <div id="_mcePaste" style="position: absolute; left: -10000px; top: 90px; width: 1px; height: 1px; overflow: hidden;"><strong>s are also available on the website.</strong></div> <div> <div>SAN DIEGO, April 5, 2012 – San Diego Coastkeeper, which protects and restores fishable, swimmable and drinkable waters in San Diego County, announces today that it has opened nominations for its annual awards program, Coastal Champions. The awards celebrate the people, businesses and organizations taking initiative in protecting and restoring San Diego County’s waters. On June 8, 2012, from 7:30 a.m. – 9 a.m., on international World Oceans Day, Coastkeeper will announce seven winners who demonstrated leadership in different areas of water protection.</div> <div></div> <div></div> <br /> <div>The awards include:</div> <div> <ul> <li>Runoff Rockstar. This award is for the actions taken to reduce urban runoff through best practices, including but not limited to, low impact development, pollution prevention and urban waste reduction.</li> <li>Water Wise. The award goes to the achievements through water-friendly landscaping techniques such as water conservation and the use of methods to promote healthy environmental restoration with native plants and natural growth.</li> <li>Marine Conservation. The award recognizes efforts to advocate for, monitor and/or implement ocean conservation programs, techniques and innovations including those dealing with marine protected areas (MPAs) or other conservation areas of concern.</li> <li>Find &amp; Fix. This nomination is for the success in a program, project or idea that first finds a pollution problem and then takes action to fix that pollution problem in the community.</li> <li>Blue Tech. The nomination goes to exceptional innovation in the development and/or use of technology to protect and restore fishable, swimmable, drinkable waters in San Diego County.</li> <li>Lighthouse Award. This award is for a lifetime achievement to advance fishable, swimmable, drinkable waters in San Diego County. This awardee will be selected by San Diego Coastkeeper’s Board of Directors.</li> <li>ASBS Award. San Diego has two recognized Areas of Special Biological Significance (ASBS) or biological hotspots in need of special water quality protections, off the shores of La Jolla. The ASBS Award is special recognition in addition to one of the above awards for effort and achievement to improve the water quality of these ASBS in order to protect the wildlife and natural ecosystems in these precious and fragile areas.</li> </ul> </div> <div>Residents who qualify for any of the awards can nominate themselves or others by <a href="images/stories/pdf/awards/Coastal_Champion_Nomination_Form.pdf" target="_blank">downloading the PDF form</a> on Coastkeeper’s website. Please check Coastkeeper’s <a href="act/green-events-in-san-diego/world-oceans-day-in-san-diego.html" target="_blank">World Oceans Day and Coastal Champions 2012 page</a> for more details on the nominees.</div> <div></div> <div></div> <br /> <div>To sponsor the event, name an award, reserve a table or place a recognition on the nomination materials, please contact San Diego Coastkeeper Development Director Megan Baehrens through email at meganb@localhost/sdcoastkeeper or call at 619-758-7743 ext. 103.</div> <div></div> <div></div> <br /> <div>For more information on the event, please visit localhost/sdcoastkeeper.</div> <div style="font-weight: normal;"></div> <div style="font-weight: normal;"></div> </div> </div> <p><br />###<br /><br />SAN DIEGO COASTKEEPER: Founded in 1995, San Diego Coastkeeper protects and restores fishable, swimmable and drinkable waters in San Diego County. Visit us online at http://localhost/sdcoastkeeper.</p>]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
		<wp:post_id>93</wp:post_id>
