	<item>
		<title>April 16 - San Diego Coastkeeper Approves Its 2012 - 2015 Strategic Plan</title>
		<link>http://localhost/demodata/?p=95</link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 25 Jul 2011 20:33:31 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[saltdevelopment]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://localhost/demodata/?p=95</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<p><em><span style="color: #808080;"><em><span style="font-size: 11pt; font-family: Arial;"> </span></em></span>The organization also welcomes four board of directors to its leadership team</em></p> <p></p>  <!--more-->  <div> <p><strong> </strong></p> <div style="position: absolute; left: -10000px; top: 90px; width: 1px; height: 1px; overflow: hidden;" id="_mcePaste"><strong>s are also available on the website.</strong></div> <div> <div>SAN DIEGO, April 16, 2012 – San Diego Coastkeeper, the region’s water quality watchdog, announced today that the board of directors has approved a<a target="_blank" href="http://localhost/demodata/wp-content/uploads/2011/07/San_Diego_Coastkeeper_Strategic_Plan_2012_2015.pdf"> three-year strategic plan</a> and the addition of four new board members. The 2012 - 2015 plan details a renewed focus on the Waterkeeper Alliance’s core mission of ensuring the enforcement of laws that protect and restore fishable, swimmable and drinkable waters in San Diego County.</div> <div></div> <br /> <div>“San Diego Coastkeeper’s legal clinic, water quality laboratory, high-tech committee and education activities will drive the organization toward water quality victories in this region,” said David Welborn, San Diego Coastkeeper’s board president. “This plan acknowledges Coastkeeper’s traditional strong suits in education, collaboration and advocacy while infusing high-tech innovation and a focus on the core mission of the global alliance.”</div> <div></div> <br /> <div>Coastkeeper’s new strategic plan, which is available online, identifies four goals for the three-year time frame:</div> <div> <ul> <li>Engage the community and use internal mechanisms to find and fix six significant water quality problems in San Diego County. </li> <li>Build a coalition and create an enforcement framework for marine protected areas. </li> <li>Reduce sewage discharge into the ocean by supporting wastewater recycling in the City of San Diego. </li> <li>Fund the organization’s programs fully and build at least a three-month cash reserve.</li> </ul> </div> <br /> <div>The 2012 - 2015 plan also includes the organization’s new mission “To protect and restore fishable, swimmable and drinkable waters in San Diego County” and the vision of “Swimmable, fishable and drinkable waters in San Diego County.”</div> <div></div> <br /> <div>“A recent report by the EPA shows that improved monitoring statewide has led to more waters identified as polluted in California,” said Coastkeeper Executive Director Gale Filter. “With this plan, Coastkeeper will rely on a community-based model to collect and analyze evidence to help us target polluters and restore and protect and your waters here in San Diego.”</div> <div></div> <br /> <div>In addition to sharing its new strategic plan, the board of directors also announced four new board members, who participated in the strategic plan approval process.</div> <div></div> <br /> <div>Joining Coastkeeper’s six other board members are:</div> <div> <ul> <li>Harriet Lazer, a founder, partner and CFO of Walker Group, a human resource consulting firm based in Phoenix, Arizona and later in San Diego. </li> <li>Micah Mitrosky, an environmental organizer with IBEW Local 569, who works to ensure San Diego and Imperial County’s green economy creates good, middle-class jobs that are sustainable for local workers and for the environment.</li> <li>Eleanor Musick, an attorney at Procopio, who specializes in patent prosecution in areas such as telecommunications, computer software, geophysics and oceanography, trademark and copyright prosecution and intellectual property licensing.</li> <li>Gregg Sadowsky, a senior vice president and senior market officer of RegencyCenters, a nationwide real estate investment trust (REIT) that specializes in grocery-anchored shopping centers and whose innovative sustainability practices significantly reduce the use of natural resources and increase operating efficiency.</li> </ul> <br /> For more information on San Diego Coastkeeper, its strategic plan and its board of directors, please visit http://localhost/sdcoastkeeper."</div> </div> </div> <p> </p> <p>###<br /><br />SAN DIEGO COASTKEEPER: Founded in 1995, San Diego Coastkeeper protects and restores fishable, swimmable and drinkable waters in San Diego County. Visit us online at http://localhost/sdcoastkeeper.</p>]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>April 26 - Coastkeeper Ranks in the Nation’s Top 100 Recipients of 1% for the Planet</title>
		<link>http://localhost/demodata/?p=96</link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 25 Jul 2011 20:33:31 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[saltdevelopment]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://localhost/demodata/?p=96</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<p><em><span style="color: #808080;"><em><span style="font-size: 11pt; font-family: Arial;"> </span></em></span>Cali Bamboo tops Coastkeeper’s biggest 1% for the Planet donors from 2008 - 2010</em></p> <p></p>  <!--more-->  <div> <p><strong> </strong></p> <div style="position: absolute; left: -10000px; top: 90px; width: 1px; height: 1px; overflow: hidden;" id="_mcePaste"><strong>s are also available on the website.</strong></div> <div> <div>SAN DIEGO, April 26, 2012 – <a>San Diego Coastkeeper</a>, a local organization that protects and restores fishable, swimmable and drinkable waters in San Diego County, has made 1% for the Planet’s list of top 100 nonprofit recipients worldwide from 2008 to 2010.</div> <div></div> <br /> <div>As part of the global alliance of businesses committed to a healthier environment, participants in the 1% for the Planet program donate one percent of their gross annual revenue directly to nonprofit partners of their choice. Through this program, the San Diego-based company Cali Bamboo, which promotes the use of bamboo as a <a target="_blank" href="http://www.calibamboo.com/">green construction material</a>, contributed the most funds to Coastkeeper -- giving $21,500 over the three year time span.</div> <div></div> <br /> <div>A portion of this donation funded Coastkeeper's Water Quality Monitoring Program. Each month staff and volunteers collect and analyze water samples from nine of San Diego's 11 watersheds. Water is tested for basic chemistry, nutrients, bacteria, and toxicity, and results are then shared with government regulators who use the data to make more effective decisions on how to reduce sources of pollution.</div> <div></div> <br /> <div>“Cali Bamboo takes the prize as an ideal business partner for San Diego Coastkeeper,” said Megan Baehrens, Coastkeeper’s development director. “The local business leads by example in choosing to sell environmentally friendly products. And it extends this basic belief into the community by sharing its profits with organizations like Coastkeeper, which make San Diego better for everyone.”</div> <div></div> <br /> <div>Many of Cali Bamboo’s customers show appreciation for the business model and opt for the bamboo products not only for their innate sustainability but because the company supports the local community through donations and volunteerism.</div> <div></div> <br /> <div>“Being based in Southern California, our company understands the precarious relationship between coastal communities and the quality of our water systems," says Laura Kaplan-Nieto communications director at Cali Bamboo. “Coastkeeper's work falls in line with Cali Bamboo's mission to protect the environment, especially regarding the health of the ecosystems in and surrounding our oceans.”</div> <div></div> <br /> <div>In 2011, San Diego Coastkeeper received more than $42,000 through the 1% for the Planet donor program. Other 1% for the Planet participants donating to Coastkeeper include Drew George &amp; Partners, Patagonia and Bambooki.</div> <div></div> <br /> <div>For more information on 1% for the Planet please visit http://www.onepercentfortheplanet.org, for San Diego Coastkeeper visit http://localhost/sdcoastkeeper, and for Cali Bamboo visit http://www.calibamboo.com.</div> <div></div> <br /> <div>###</div> <div></div> <br /> <div>SAN DIEGO COASTKEEPER: Founded in 1995, San Diego Coastkeeper protects and restores fishable, swimmable and drinkable waters in San Diego County. Learn more at http://localhost/sdcoastkeeper.</div> <div></div> <br /> <div>CALI BAMBOO: Based in San Diego, Cali Bamboo manufactures green construction materials for residential and commercial projects made primarily from bamboo -- one of the world’s most durable and renewable materials. Founded in 2004, the company has become a model of how individuals, businesses and communities can implement modern design while maintaining structural strength and environmental integrity. Cali Bamboo’s wide range of products includes bamboo flooring, fencing, composite decking, plywood and more.</div> </div> </div>]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>May 2 - San Diego Native “Bird” Huffman Launches “The Breaks” T-shirt Collection</title>
		<link>http://localhost/demodata/?p=97</link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 25 Jul 2011 20:33:31 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[saltdevelopment]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://localhost/demodata/?p=97</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<p><em><span style="color: #808080;"><em><span style="font-size: 11pt; font-family: Arial;"> </span></em></span>Huffman donates a portion of the proceeds, creates one-time contest with Coastkeeper</em></p> <p></p>  <!--more-->  <div> <p><strong> </strong></p> <div style="position: absolute; left: -10000px; top: 90px; width: 1px; height: 1px; overflow: hidden;" id="_mcePaste"><strong>s are also available on the website.</strong></div> <div> <div>SAN DIEGO, May 1, 2012 – Bird’s Surf Shed teamed up with San Diego Coastkeeper on a limited-edition “The Breaks” t-shirt collection. Available for sale at Bird’s Surf Shed, a portion of the proceeds from the shirts will go directly to Coastkeeper, a nonprofit organization that protects and restores fishable, swimmable and drinkable waters in San Diego County.</div> <div></div> <br /> <div>Designed by local agency <a href="http://miresball.com/" target="_blank">MiresBall</a>, the collection currently includes shirts for six breaks—Blacks, Cliffs, Jetty, Scripps, Tourmo and Windansea—with plans for more to be added by demand.</div> <div></div> <br /> <div>“These shirts are a great way to show the pride we have in the breaks we love to surf, while helping to protect those spots for the future,” said Eric “Bird” Huffman, owner of Bird’s Surf Shed. “We partnered with Coastkeeper because they help keep our breaks clean and beautiful.”</div> <div></div> <br /> <div>To promote the collection’s launch, Huffman created a one-time-only contest with Coastkeeper. The first ten people to donate $100 to Coastkeeper by midnight Saturday, May 5, 2012 will be entered for a chance to win a free surf session with Huffman to go on the hunt for the best waves in town. Six winners will be chosen, with each donor also receiving one of “The Breaks” T-shirts. To donate, please <a href="https://app.etapestry.com/cart/SanDiegoCoastkeeper/default/item.php?ref=1841.0.402710681" target="_blank">click here</a>.</div> <div></div> <br /> <div>“The best way to celebrate local surf breaks is by protecting the water quality at each of those beaches,” said Gale Filter, Coastkeeper’s executive director. “Bird’s Surf Shed serves as a shining example of how businesses can invest in local efforts to protect those resources we depend on for a strong economy.”</div> <div></div> <br /> <div>Huffman brought surf culture and local pride to San Diego for 40 years before opening Bird’s Surf Shed in Linda Vista in 2011. The “Shed,” housed in a Quonset Hut on West Morena Blvd, provides gear and information to local surfers, from boards to tide charts and local surf conditions.</div> <div></div> <br /> <div>For more information about Bird’s Surf Shed, visit www.birdssurfshed.com. To learn more about San Diego Coastkeeper, please visit localhost/sdcoastkeeper. Read more about the partnership and contest and see images of the tees <a href="blog/other-green-thoughts/item/256-buy-your-local-break-tee-and-win-free-surf-session.html" target="_blank">here</a>.</div> <div></div> <br /> <div>###</div> <div></div> <br /> <div>ABOUT SAN DIEGO COASTKEEPER: Founded in 1995, San Diego Coastkeeper protects and restores fishable, swimmable and drinkable waters in San Diego County. Learn more at http://localhost/sdcoastkeeper.</div> <div></div> <br /> <div>ABOUT BIRD’S SURF SHED: Bird’s Surf Shed was founded in 2011 by Eric “Bird” Huffman, a San Diego native who’s been known for his surfing passion and expertise for more than 40 years. For everyone from pro surfers to those just starting out, the Shed provides all the gear and information needed for surfing San Diego. But it is much more than a typical surf shop; it’s a living gallery of surf history and memorabilia. For more information, visit www.birdssurfshed.com.</div> </div> </div>]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>May 30 - Coastkeeper Launches Smart Phone App to Help Beachgoers Find Healthy Beaches in San Diego County</title>
		<link>http://localhost/demodata/?p=98</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 30 May 2012 16:02:02 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[saltdevelopment]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://localhost/demodata/?p=98</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<p><span style="font-size: 15px; font-family: Arial; color: #000000; background-color: transparent; font-weight: bold; font-style: normal; font-variant: normal; text-decoration: none; vertical-align: baseline;" id="internal-source-marker_0.09332968097905958"></span><span style="font-size: 17px; font-family: Arial; color: #000000; background-color: transparent; font-weight: bold; font-style: normal; font-variant: normal; text-decoration: none; vertical-align: baseline;"></span><em>New Swim Guide also shares water quality at more than 300 beaches statewide</em><br /></p>  <!--more-->  <p>SAN DIEGO, May 30, 2012 – Today San Diego Coastkeeper launched San Diego County’s version of the interactive Swim Guide, an online and smart phone app to help beachgoers, swimmers, surfers and boaters find healthy stretches of sand and coastal waters along the region’s coastline. The new app also includes access to water quality data for more than 300 beaches in California and more than 1,300 beaches in North America.</p> <p>For several years, San Diego Coastkeeper has displayed water quality data in interactive maps for more than 80 beaches extending from Camp Pendleton to US/Mexico border. Coastkeeper receives daily beach status information from County of San Diego, Department of Environmental Health, which sometimes--but not always--posts warning signs at polluted beaches. Coastkeeper inputs the county’s data into an interactive map that digests beach status into easily understandable green, red and yellow color-coded formats. With the launch of Swim Guide, beachgoers can now access this information, as well as similar information at beaches across the nation and in Canada, on their smart phones.</p> <p>“Our economy and cultural identity depend on safe beaches in which we can swim, fish and play,” said Travis Pritchard, San Diego Coastkeeper’s water quality lab manager. “San Diego County beaches are generally pretty healthy, but when the county closes a beach due to a sewage spill or bacteria pollution--you want to know. With Swim Guide, it is easier than ever for beachgoers to know before they go into the ocean.”</p> <p>Currently, Swim Guide is available from App Store, Google Play, or www.theswimguide.org, and San Diego County’s water quality data can also be viewed on San Diego Coastkeeper’s website at http://localhost/sdcoastkeeper/learn/san-diegos-waters/coastal-water.html.</p> <p>Provided and managed by member groups within the Waterkeeper Alliance, a network of 200 water protection groups worldwide, Swim Guide helps users get directions, view photos, learn about recreation options, and share the whole adventure with friends and family on their social networks. The guide also allows the user to report pollution immediately to their local Waterkeeper organization.</p> <p>“Every year, millions of people get sick from coming into contact with polluted water at their local beaches,” said Pete Nichols, Western Director for the Waterkeeper Alliance.  “The Swim Guide provides a free, easy to use, way for beach goers to find a beach where their families can swim and enjoy the beach safely.”</p> <p>The app originates with a team from the Lake Ontario Waterkeeper, which set out to determine if it was safe to swim in Lake Ontario.  Seven years later, with input from more than 100 different beach monitoring sources covering over 1,300 beaches a day and more than 128,000 points of data, people can now check the status and cleanliness of their local beaches in real time.</p> <p>Swim Guide includes descriptions and photographs of nearly 1,300 beaches in California and across North America, including Miami, FL; Mobile, AL; the Great Lakes; British Columbia and Alberta.  Swim Guide will continue to expand until it covers beaches in every major beach community in North America.</p> <p>For more information on Swim Guide, visit www.theswimguide.org. For more information about San Diego County’s version of Swim Guide, visit localhost/sdcoastkeeper.</p> <p>###</p> <p>ABOUT SAN DIEGO COASTKEEPER: Founded in 1995, San Diego Coastkeeper protects and restores fishable, swimmable and drinkable waters in San Diego County. Learn more at http://localhost/sdcoastkeeper.</p>]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
		<wp:post_id>98</wp:post_id>
		<wp:post_date><![CDATA[2012-05-30 16:02:02]]></wp:post_date>
		<wp:post_date_gmt><![CDATA[2012-05-30 16:02:02]]></wp:post_date_gmt>
		<wp:comment_status><![CDATA[open]]></wp:comment_status>
		<wp:ping_status><![CDATA[open]]></wp:ping_status>
		<wp:post_name><![CDATA[may-30-coastkeeper-launches-smart-phone-app-to-help-beachgoers-find-healthy-beaches-in-san-diego-county]]></wp:post_name>
		<wp:status><![CDATA[publish]]></wp:status>
		<wp:post_parent>0</wp:post_parent>
		<wp:menu_order>118</wp:menu_order>
		<wp:post_type><![CDATA[post]]></wp:post_type>
		<wp:post_password><![CDATA[]]></wp:post_password>
		<wp:is_sticky>0</wp:is_sticky>
		<category domain="category" nicename="import-cate"><![CDATA[import cate]]></category>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_fgj2wp_old_id]]></wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[356]]></wp:meta_value>

	</item>
	<item>
		<title>May 30 - Coastkeeper to Honor Coastal Champions on World Oceans Day</title>
		<link>http://localhost/demodata/?p=99</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 30 May 2012 21:41:13 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[saltdevelopment]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://localhost/demodata/?p=99</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<p><em>June 8 event at Birch Aquarium is now free thanks to generous support from event sponsors<br /></em></p>  <!--more-->  <p>SAN DIEGO, May 30, 2012 – On Friday, June 8, San Diego Coastkeeper invites the community to join the World Oceans Day presentation honoring this year’s Coastal Champions--the people, businesses and organizations taking initiative to protect and restore fishable, swimmable and drinkable waters in San Diego County.</p> <p>Thanks to the generous support of event sponsors and partners, the event at Birch Aquarium is now free. From 7:30 a.m. - 9 a.m. on June 8, which is International World Oceans Day, Coastkeeper will honor six environmental leaders and their accomplishments in the community. The morning event comes complete with a light breakfast by Behind The Scenes Catering &amp; Events. (Your thoughtful donation to San Diego Coastkeeper when you arrive would help underwrite the meal.) Participants must RSVP to give@localhost/sdcoastkeeper</p> <p>At the event, Coastkeeper will honor businesses, organizations and individuals in six categories including:</p> <p>●      <strong>Runoff Rockstar</strong>, for actions taken to reduce urban runoff through low impact development, pollution prevention and urban waste reduction.</p> <p>●      <strong>Water Wise</strong>, for achievements through water-friendly landscaping techniques such as water conservation and the use of methods to promote healthy environmental restoration with native plants and natural growth.</p> <p>●      <strong>Marine Conservation</strong>, for efforts to advocate for, monitor and/or implement ocean conservation programs, techniques and innovations including those dealing with marine protected areas or other conservation areas of concern.</p> <p>●      <strong>Find &amp; Fix</strong>, for success in a program, project or idea that finds a pollution problem and takes action to fix that problem in the community.</p> <p>●      <strong>Blue Tech</strong>, for exceptional innovation in the development and/or use of technology to protect and restore fishable, swimmable, drinkable waters in San Diego County.</p> <p>●      <strong>Lighthouse Award</strong>, for lifetime achievement to advance fishable, swimmable, drinkable waters in San Diego County, selected by San Diego Coastkeeper’s Board of Directors.</p> <p><strong> </strong></p> <p>A special <strong>ASBS Recognition </strong>will be presented to one award winner for their effort and achievement to improve the water quality of the La Jolla <a href="learn/marine-conservation/san-diegos-areas-of-special-biological-significance.html">ASBS</a><a href="learn/marine-conservation/san-diegos-areas-of-special-biological-significance.html"> (</a><a href="learn/marine-conservation/san-diegos-areas-of-special-biological-significance.html">Areas</a><a href="learn/marine-conservation/san-diegos-areas-of-special-biological-significance.html"> </a><a href="learn/marine-conservation/san-diegos-areas-of-special-biological-significance.html">of</a><a href="learn/marine-conservation/san-diegos-areas-of-special-biological-significance.html"> </a><a href="learn/marine-conservation/san-diegos-areas-of-special-biological-significance.html">Special</a><a href="learn/marine-conservation/san-diegos-areas-of-special-biological-significance.html"> </a><a href="learn/marine-conservation/san-diegos-areas-of-special-biological-significance.html">Biological</a><a href="learn/marine-conservation/san-diegos-areas-of-special-biological-significance.html"> </a><a href="learn/marine-conservation/san-diegos-areas-of-special-biological-significance.html">Significance</a><a href="learn/marine-conservation/san-diegos-areas-of-special-biological-significance.html">)</a> in order to protect the wildlife and natural ecosystems in these precious and fragile areas.</p> <p>All award winners will receive a hand-made glass sculpture depicting one of the beautiful sea creatures that their work helps protect. James Stone of <a href="http://www.stoneandglass.com/">Stone and Glass</a> designed, created and generously donated these awards to commemorate his dedication to our ocean and he and his wife will join us at the event.</p> <p>Generous contributions from Birch Aquarium at Scripps; Hunter Industries; International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers, Local 569; Stone and Glass; The Safe Drinking Water, Water Quality and Supply, Flood Control, River and Coastal Protection Bond Act of 2006, administered by the California State Water Resources Control Board; and support from the City of San Diego, Think Blue make this event possible.</p> <p>For more information on the event, please visit <a href="undefined/">www</a><a href="undefined/">.</a><a href="undefined/">sdcoastkeeper</a><a href="undefined/">.</a><a href="undefined/">org</a> and to RSVP email give@localhost/sdcoastkeeper.</p> <p align="center">###</p> <p>SAN DIEGO COASTKEEPER: Founded in 1995, San Diego Coastkeeper protects and restores fishable, swimmable and drinkable waters in San Diego County. Visit us online at http://localhost/sdcoastkeeper.</p>]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
		<wp:post_id>99</wp:post_id>

	<item>
		<title>May 7 - Governor&#039;s Plan to Consolidate Water Boards Could Harm Water Quality in San Diego</title>
		<link>http://localhost/demodata/?p=100</link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 25 Jul 2011 20:33:31 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[saltdevelopment]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://localhost/demodata/?p=100</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<p><em>Environmental groups oppose the move that would limit local representation, public participation at important hearings</em></p> <p></p>  <!--more-->  <div> <p><strong> </strong></p> <div id="_mcePaste" style="position: absolute; left: -10000px; top: 90px; width: 1px; height: 1px; overflow: hidden;"><strong>s are also available on the website.</strong></div> <div> <div>SAN DIEGO, May 7, 2012— WiLDCOAST, San Diego Coastkeeper, and Environmental Health Coalition announced today their opposition to Governor Brown’s proposed plan to consolidate the Colorado River Basin and San Diego Regional Water Quality Control Boards.</div> <div></div> <p> </p> <div>As they operate now, these regional boards protect and enforce water quality standards and regulate polluters throughout the state. The governor’s plan would create a single, 23,900-square-mile regulatory region out of two distinctly different water basins. It would also require the public to travel to board meetings at locations alternating in San Diego, Orange, Riverside and Imperial counties.</div> <div></div> <p> </p> <div>On April 25, the state senate’s Subcommittee on Resources, Environmental Protection, Energy and Transportation voted to continue reviewing the governor’s proposal to consolidate the regional boards. They are expected to take action at their May 9 meeting in Sacramento.</div> <div></div> <p> </p> <div>“This proposal would severely hinder public participation in meetings,” says Jill Witkowski, San Diego Coastkeeper’s legal clinic director. “It’s already challenging enough for the San Diego public to attend hearings in Kearny Mesa, with the lack of public transportation to the offices. The sheer size of the area that the combined regional board would cover would prevent interested people and groups from standing before the board members to have their concerns heard.”</div> <div></div> <p> </p> <div>San Diego’s regional board focuses on the needs of its mainly urban coastal communities such as sewage treatment, cleaning up toxic contamination in San Diego Bay, and improving stormwater regulations to reduce pollution in the ocean. The Colorado River’s regional water board focuses on addressing the issues of its rural desert communities such as regulating agricultural runoff and replacing septic tanks.</div> <div></div> <p> </p> <div>“The governor’s plan would mean that San Diego’s clean water priorities, like addressing sewage spills onto our beaches or cleaning up the Tijuana River and San Diego Bay, will receive less of the board’s attention. This is unacceptable,” said WiLDCOAST Conservation Director Ben McCue. “It’s nearly impossible to select a single board to represent such diverse regions and communities.”</div> <div></div> <p> </p> <div>The proposal will also eliminate two regional water board seats, further limiting attention to San Diego’s key regional water quality concerns including cleanup and abatement, sewage treatment plant compliance, identification and restoration of polluted waters and municipal stormwater permitting.</div> <div></div> <p> </p> <div>“The San Diego Regional Board just recently ordered polluters to cleanup the contamination in San Diego Bay. This is a significant achievement for the protection of San Diego Bay and will boost our region’s economy and health,” said Environmental Health Coalition’s Laura Hunter. “With a consolidated board, it is inevitable that there will be delays and inadequate attention given to these important regulatory decisions.”</div> <div></div> <p> </p> <div>According to the environmental groups, the move is also counter to the environmental justice guidelines of the state. The consolidation will make it increasingly difficult for environmental justice communities to participate in important issues before the board and would further limit public participation in water quality hearings. The commutes to meetings could exceed three hours for some stakeholders.</div> <div></div> <p> </p> <div>The environmental groups expressed their concerns in a letter written to Senator Joe Simitian, the Chair of the Senate Subcommittee on Resources, Environmental Protection, Energy and Transportation.</div> <div></div> <p> </p> <div>###</div> <div></div> <p> </p> <div>ABOUT WiLDCOASTWiLDCOAST is an international conservation team that works to conserve coastal and marine ecosystems www.wildcoast.net</div> <div></div> <p> </p> <div>ABOUT SAN DIEGO COASTKEEPER: Founded in 1995, San Diego Coastkeeper protects and restores fishable, swimmable and drinkable waters in San Diego County. Learn more at http://localhost/sdcoastkeeper.</div> <div></div> <p> </p> <div>ABOUT ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH COALITION: Founded in 1980, Environmental Health Coalition (EHC) builds grassroots campaigns to confront the unjust consequences of toxic pollution, discriminatory land use, and unsustainable energy policies. Visit us online at http://www.environmentalhealth.org.</div> </div> </div>]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>June 8 - Coastkeeper Honors Eight Coastal Champions This Morning</title>
		<link>http://localhost/demodata/?p=101</link>
		<pubDate>Fri, 08 Jun 2012 19:38:46 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[saltdevelopment]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://localhost/demodata/?p=101</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<p><em>Supervisor Slater-Price honored with Lighthouse Lifetime Achievement Award</em></p> <p><em></em></p>  <!--more-->  <p>SAN DIEGO, June 8, 2012 – This morning, San Diego Coastkeeper presented Coastal Champion awards to eight environmental leaders across San Diego County for their efforts to protect fishable, swimmable and drinkable waters. Hosted at Birch Aquarium on World Oceans Day, Coastkeeper’s yearly awards program honored individuals and organizations for their contributions in the categories of Runoff Rockstar, Find &amp; Fix, Marine Conservation, Water Wise, Blue Tech, Lighthouse Lifetime Achievement, Volunteer of the Year and ASBS Special Recognition.</p> <p>The 2012 Coastal Champions include:</p> <p>●      <strong>County Supervisor Pam Slater-Price</strong>, <em>Lighthouse Lifetime Achievement</em>: for her commitment to clean water throughout a long-standing career in public office, Slater-Price secured nearly $10 million in funding for environmental projects in San Diego and allocated a $112,000 grant for the foundation of open-air classrooms at San Dieguito River Park. Throughout the years, she has supported stormwater regulation, water quality testing and posting of contamination warnings, restoration of the San Dieguito wetlands, land acquisitions and construction of the San Elijo Lagoon visitors’ center.</p> <p>●      <strong>Oscar Romo</strong> of <a href="http://trnerr.org/">Tijuana</a><a href="http://trnerr.org/"> </a><a href="http://trnerr.org/">River</a><a href="http://trnerr.org/"> </a><a href="http://trnerr.org/">National</a><a href="http://trnerr.org/"> </a><a href="http://trnerr.org/">Estuarine</a><a href="http://trnerr.org/"> </a><a href="http://trnerr.org/">Research</a><a href="http://trnerr.org/"> </a><a href="http://trnerr.org/">Reserve</a><strong>, </strong><em>Runoff Rockstar</em>: for spearheading restoration and preservation projects throughout the Tijuana River watershed that reduce the cross-border flows of sediment, sewage and trash that pollute San Diego County coastal wetland ecosystems.</p> <p>●      <a href="http://www.hikebikekayak.com/"><strong>Hike</strong></a><a href="http://www.hikebikekayak.com/"><strong> </strong></a><a href="http://www.hikebikekayak.com/"><strong>Bike</strong></a><a href="http://www.hikebikekayak.com/"><strong> </strong></a><a href="http://www.hikebikekayak.com/"><strong>Kayak</strong></a>, <em>Marine Conservation and ASBS Special Recognition: </em>for building a tourism business that combines recreational activity with education about San Diego’s unique marine ecosystems. Hike Bike Kayak also received the ASBS Special Recognition for its contribution to protecting one of the most pristine and biologically unique coastal areas in our state, the ASBS (Areas of Significant Biological Significance) located off La Jolla’s shoreline.</p> <p>●      <a href="http://escondidocreek.org/"><strong>The</strong></a><a href="http://escondidocreek.org/"><strong> </strong></a><a href="http://escondidocreek.org/"><strong>Escondido</strong></a><a href="http://escondidocreek.org/"><strong> </strong></a><a href="http://escondidocreek.org/"><strong>Creek</strong></a><a href="http://escondidocreek.org/"><strong> </strong></a><a href="http://escondidocreek.org/"><strong>Conservancy</strong></a>, <em>Find &amp; Fix</em><strong>: </strong>for identifying abandoned cars in the Escondido Creek and acting decisively to fix the problem. TECC brought together volunteers and built partnerships with local businesses, municipal agencies and the fire department to prepare the sites for removal of the vehicles from a threatened environment.</p> <p>●      <strong>Carlos Zamora</strong> of <a href="http://www.zdatasolutions.net/">Z</a><a href="http://www.zdatasolutions.net/"> </a><a href="http://www.zdatasolutions.net/">Data</a><a href="http://www.zdatasolutions.net/"> </a><a href="http://www.zdatasolutions.net/">Solution</a><a href="http://www.zdatasolutions.net/">s</a>, <em>Blue Tech</em><strong>: </strong>for exceptional innovation in the development of a crowd-sourcing application and website to empower community members, organizations and agencies to track and reduce pollution in San Diego County.</p> <p>●      <strong>City of San Diego Public Utilities Department’s </strong><a href="http://www.sandiego.gov/water/conservation/"><strong>Residential</strong></a><a href="http://www.sandiego.gov/water/conservation/"><strong> </strong></a><a href="http://www.sandiego.gov/water/conservation/"><strong>Outdoor</strong></a><a href="http://www.sandiego.gov/water/conservation/"><strong> </strong></a><a href="http://www.sandiego.gov/water/conservation/"><strong>Water</strong></a><a href="http://www.sandiego.gov/water/conservation/"><strong> </strong></a><a href="http://www.sandiego.gov/water/conservation/"><strong>Conservation</strong></a><a href="http://www.sandiego.gov/water/conservation/"><strong> </strong></a><a href="http://www.sandiego.gov/water/conservation/"><strong>Rebate</strong></a><a href="http://www.sandiego.gov/water/conservation/"><strong> </strong></a><a href="http://www.sandiego.gov/water/conservation/"><strong>Program</strong></a>, <em>Water Wise</em><strong>: </strong>for helping over 300 customers conserve 61.8-million gallons of water over ten years by offering rebates for smart controllers, micro-irrigation, turf replacement and rain barrels.</p> <p>●      <strong>Beth and Bruce Hendershot</strong>, Coastkeeper’s <em>Volunteers of the Year 2012</em>: nominated for relentlessly donating their time to Coastkeeper’s water quality monitoring lab. For several years, the married duo who live in Del Mar, dedicate at least one weekend a month to gathering, delivering and analyzing water quality samples in North County.</p> <p><strong> </strong></p> <p>The award winners received a hand-made glass sculpture depicting one of the beautiful<br /> sea creatures that their work helps to protect. James Stone of Stone and Glass designed, created and generously donated the award sculptures to commemorate his dedication to the ocean.</p> <p>Generous contributions from Birch Aquarium at Scripps; Hunter Industries; International<br /> Brotherhood of Electrical Workers, Local 569; Stone and Glass; The Safe Drinking<br /> Water, Water Quality and Supply, Flood Control, River and Coastal Protection Bond<br /> Act of 2006, administered by the California State Water Resources Control Board; and<br /> support from Think Blue, City of San Diego made the event possible.<br /> <br /> For more information about San Diego Coastkeeper and the event, please visit <a href="undefined/">www</a><a href="undefined/">.</a><a href="undefined/">sdcoastkeeper</a><a href="undefined/">.</a><a href="undefined/">org</a>.</p> <p>###</p> <p>SAN DIEGO COASTKEEPER: Founded in 1995, San Diego Coastkeeper protects and<br /> restores fishable, swimmable and drinkable waters in San Diego County. Visit us online<br /> at http://localhost/sdcoastkeeper.</p>]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>June 11 - Regional Board Denies Polluters’ Request for Deadline Extension in the Planning Process for the San Diego Bay Cleanup Order</title>
		<link>http://localhost/demodata/?p=102</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 13 Jun 2012 18:25:15 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[saltdevelopment]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://localhost/demodata/?p=102</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<p><em>Decision signals the governing body’s commitment to an expeditious process</em></p> <p></p>  <!--more-->  <p>SAN DIEGO, June 11, 2012 – Late last week, San Diego Regional Water Quality Control Board (Regional Board) denied a request by NASSCO, BAE and other responsible parties to push back deadlines for submitting the San Diego Bay cleanup blueprint and monitoring plan. According to San Diego Coastkeeper and Environmental Health Coalition, this decision by the Regional Board signals that it’s in the public interest to ensure the board’s March 14 bay cleanup order continue moving forward expeditiously.</p> <p>“The Regional Board knows that a San Diego Bay cleanup is necessary to protect those residents who feed fish to their families and those companies that rely on tourism for business,” said Jill Witkowski, legal clinic director at San Diego Coastkeeper. “It has taken more than 20 years to reach this cleanup order, and we applaud the Regional Board’s decision to push forward despite more delay tactics from the polluters.”</p> <p>Shortly after the Regional Board’s March 14 order to cleanup 143,400 cubic yards of toxic sediments from the bottom of San Diego Bay, the responsible parties appealed the decision to the State Water Resources Control Board (State Board). According to state law, the responsible parties must continue their work on the cleanup order unless the State Board “stays” the cleanup order with specific allowances for the responsible parties to stop work during the appeal process. NASSCO, BAE and the City of San Diego asked the state for permission to stop the cleanup planning process while the appeals are pending, but the state has not yet responded to that request.</p> <p>And, despite the fact that the planning timelines had been proposed since December 2009 without objections, the responsible parties also asked the Regional Board for more time to meet their obligations with planning the cleanup details. The Regional Board denied the responsible parties’ request for more time, noting that the responsible parties did not provide reasonable explanation for needing the delay and that public interest in the monitoring plan does not justify a delay.</p> <p>“We are not surprised by the polluters’ most recent delay tactics—they’ve been doing this for more than 20 years,” said Environmental Health Coalition’s Laura Hunter. “We’re thankful the Regional Board followed its historic cleanup order with another strong decision to push the process forward because our communities deserve to finally get a clean San Diego Bay.”</p> <p>San Diego Bay is listed under the federal Clean Water Act for 20 separate pollutants including sediment toxicity, copper, mercury, PAHs, PCBs, zinc, chlordane and benthic community effects. Due to the fish contamination from the pollutants, the Port of San Diego posted all piers along San Diego Bay with fish consumption advisories. However, because residents still catch and eat fish from the bay, they continue to be exposed to serious human health risks. The bay also plays a major role in San Diego County’s tourism economy, which depends on clean and safe coastal waters to attract visitors.</p> <p>Coastkeeper and EHC will continue to monitor the process to ensure that the bay is cleaned and the cleanup plan is executed in a manner that reduces impacts to communities. Both organizations suggested steps to the Regional Board that it can enact to protect the community during the cleanup process while it achieves safe cleanup levels.</p> <p>To find out more about San Diego Bay, Coastkeeper and EHC’s work on the cleanup, visit Coastkeeper’s website localhost/sdcoastkeeper.</p> <p>###</p> <p>SAN DIEGO COASTKEEPER: Founded in 1995, San Diego Coastkeeper protects and restores fishable, swimmable and drinkable waters in San Diego County. Visit us online at http://localhost/sdcoastkeeper.</p> <p>ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH COALITION: Founded in 1980, Environmental Health Coalition (EHC) builds grassroots campaigns to confront the unjust consequences of toxic pollution, discriminatory land use, and unsustainable energy policies. Visit us online at http://www.environmentalhealth.org/.</p>]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
		<wp:post_id>102</wp:post_id>

		<wp:status><![CDATA[publish]]></wp:status>

	<item>
		<title>June 26 - San Diego Coastkeeper Announces Change in Leadership</title>
		<link>http://localhost/demodata/?p=103</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 13 Jun 2012 18:25:15 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[saltdevelopment]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://localhost/demodata/?p=103</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<p><em>Organization on track to achieve its 2012- 2015 strategic plan finalized this year</em></p> <p></p>  <!--more-->  <p>SAN DIEGO (June 26, 2012) - San Diego Coastkeeper’s board of directors announced today new leadership spearheaded by Megan Baehrens as executive director and Jill Witkowski as waterkeeper, a common structure in the global Waterkeeper Alliance. Baehrens will direct administrative, fundraising and managerial aspects and Witkowski will provide policy and legal direction.</p> <p>Both assume their respective roles today following the departure of former executive director Gale Filter, who resigned on Friday, June 22, citing personal reasons. Filter described his time with the organization as “an excellent experience and truly rewarding.”</p> <p>“We thank Gale for his strategic leadership and contributions to Coastkeeper and wish him well in the future,” said David Welborn, president of Coastkeeper’s board of directors. “Our board and staff are committed to executing the strategic plan that is now in place. We know that Jill and Megan’s passion and leadership will inspire our staff and volunteers to continue their important service to our community.”</p> <p>Baehrens, previously development director, joined Coastkeeper in April 2009, and Witkowski, previously legal director, joined the organization in January 2010. Both have worked directly with the executive director and organizational leadership for the past several years.</p> <p>###</p> <p>SAN DIEGO COASTKEEPER: Founded in 1995, San Diego Coastkeeper protects and restores fishable, swimmable and drinkable waters in San Diego County. Visit us online at http://localhost/sdcoastkeeper.</p>]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
		<wp:post_id>103</wp:post_id>
		<wp:post_date><![CDATA[2012-06-13 18:25:15]]></wp:post_date>
		<wp:post_date_gmt><![CDATA[2012-06-13 18:25:15]]></wp:post_date_gmt>

	<item>
		<title>July 10 - Coastkeeper Breaks Down Info in San Diego’s Annual Drinking Water Quality Report</title>
		<link>http://localhost/demodata/?p=104</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 13 Jun 2012 18:25:15 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[saltdevelopment]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://localhost/demodata/?p=104</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<p><em>Organization encourages residents to visit its blog for a full scoop on the results</em></p> <p></p>  <!--more-->  <div id="_mcePaste" style="position: absolute; left: -10000px; top: 49px; width: 1px; height: 1px; overflow: hidden;">SAN DIEGO, July 9, 2012 – To aid understanding of San Diego’s drinking water quality</div> <div id="_mcePaste" style="position: absolute; left: -10000px; top: 49px; width: 1px; height: 1px; overflow: hidden;">standards, Coastkeeper published a “how to read” guide explaining information found in the</div> <div id="_mcePaste" style="position: absolute; left: -10000px; top: 49px; width: 1px; height: 1px; overflow: hidden;">recently mailed Annual Drinking Water Quality Report from the City of San Diego. The guide</div> <div id="_mcePaste" style="position: absolute; left: -10000px; top: 49px; width: 1px; height: 1px; overflow: hidden;">is located at: http://localhost/sdcoastkeeper/blog/san-diego-water-supply/item/267-is-my-tap-</div> <div id="_mcePaste" style="position: absolute; left: -10000px; top: 49px; width: 1px; height: 1px; overflow: hidden;">water-safe-to-drink?.html</div> <div id="_mcePaste" style="position: absolute; left: -10000px; top: 49px; width: 1px; height: 1px; overflow: hidden;"></div> <div id="_mcePaste" style="position: absolute; left: -10000px; top: 49px; width: 1px; height: 1px; overflow: hidden;">Coastkeeper has no formal involvement in drinking water quality standards.</div> <div id="_mcePaste" style="position: absolute; left: -10000px; top: 49px; width: 1px; height: 1px; overflow: hidden;"></div> <div id="_mcePaste" style="position: absolute; left: -10000px; top: 49px; width: 1px; height: 1px; overflow: hidden;">“When Coastkeeper’s staff started asking me what the report meant, I thought why not put</div> <div id="_mcePaste" style="position: absolute; left: -10000px; top: 49px; width: 1px; height: 1px; overflow: hidden;">this information together and share it with the larger public?” said Coastkeeper’s water quality</div> <div id="_mcePaste" style="position: absolute; left: -10000px; top: 49px; width: 1px; height: 1px; overflow: hidden;">lab manager Travis Pritchard. “These are technical terms and measurements, but with a little</div> <div id="_mcePaste" style="position: absolute; left: -10000px; top: 49px; width: 1px; height: 1px; overflow: hidden;">guidance from Coastkeeper, even my 10-year-old neighbor can understand the health of the</div> <div id="_mcePaste" style="position: absolute; left: -10000px; top: 49px; width: 1px; height: 1px; overflow: hidden;">water pouring from his faucets.”</div> <div id="_mcePaste" style="position: absolute; left: -10000px; top: 49px; width: 1px; height: 1px; overflow: hidden;"></div> <div id="_mcePaste" style="position: absolute; left: -10000px; top: 49px; width: 1px; height: 1px; overflow: hidden;">According to Pritchard, Coastkeeper’s blog highlights the most important information found in</div> <div id="_mcePaste" style="position: absolute; left: -10000px; top: 49px; width: 1px; height: 1px; overflow: hidden;">the Annual Drinking Water Quality Report, interprets the technical terms and uses anecdotal</div> <div id="_mcePaste" style="position: absolute; left: -10000px; top: 49px; width: 1px; height: 1px; overflow: hidden;">information to further aid understanding. “Tap water in San Diego goes through an extensive</div> <div id="_mcePaste" style="position: absolute; left: -10000px; top: 49px; width: 1px; height: 1px; overflow: hidden;">treatment process.” said Pritchard. “People should realize that drinking tap water is safe,</div> <div id="_mcePaste" style="position: absolute; left: -10000px; top: 49px; width: 1px; height: 1px; overflow: hidden;">economical and eco-groovy.”</div> <div id="_mcePaste" style="position: absolute; left: -10000px; top: 49px; width: 1px; height: 1px; overflow: hidden;"></div> <div id="_mcePaste" style="position: absolute; left: -10000px; top: 49px; width: 1px; height: 1px; overflow: hidden;">In addition, and unrelated to drinking water quality standards, the organization updates the</div> <div id="_mcePaste" style="position: absolute; left: -10000px; top: 49px; width: 1px; height: 1px; overflow: hidden;">county’s beach status web page to inform the residents about their favorite beaches. To check</div> <div id="_mcePaste" style="position: absolute; left: -10000px; top: 49px; width: 1px; height: 1px; overflow: hidden;">for current beach advisories and warnings, visit Coastkeeper’s website or download its Swim</div> <div id="_mcePaste" style="position: absolute; left: -10000px; top: 49px; width: 1px; height: 1px; overflow: hidden;">Guide app for beachgoers on the go.</div> <div id="_mcePaste" style="position: absolute; left: -10000px; top: 49px; width: 1px; height: 1px; overflow: hidden;"></div> <div id="_mcePaste" style="position: absolute; left: -10000px; top: 49px; width: 1px; height: 1px; overflow: hidden;">Coastkeeper also conducts monthly water quality monitoring and testing to collect data and</div> <div id="_mcePaste" style="position: absolute; left: -10000px; top: 49px; width: 1px; height: 1px; overflow: hidden;">establish water quality trends in the county’s inland waters. The organization shares this</div> <div id="_mcePaste" style="position: absolute; left: -10000px; top: 49px; width: 1px; height: 1px; overflow: hidden;">information with the public, agencies and community organizations to help the region identify</div> <div id="_mcePaste" style="position: absolute; left: -10000px; top: 49px; width: 1px; height: 1px; overflow: hidden;">and restore polluted waters.</div> <p>SAN DIEGO, July 10, 2012 – To aid understanding of San Diego’s drinking water quality standards, Coastkeeper published a “how to read” guide explaining information found in the recently mailed Annual Drinking Water Quality Report from the City of San Diego. The guide is located at: http://localhost/sdcoastkeeper/blog/san-diego-water-supply/item/267-is-my-tap-water-safe-to-drink?.html</p> <p>Coastkeeper has no formal involvement in drinking water quality standards.</p> <p>“When Coastkeeper’s staff started asking me what the report meant, I thought why not put this information together and share it with the larger public?” said Coastkeeper’s water quality lab manager Travis Pritchard. “These are technical terms and measurements, but with a little guidance from Coastkeeper, even my 10-year-old neighbor can understand the health of the water pouring from his faucets.”</p> <p>According to Pritchard, Coastkeeper’s blog highlights the most important information found in the Annual Drinking Water Quality Report, interprets the technical terms and uses anecdotal information to further aid understanding. “Tap water in San Diego goes through an extensive treatment process.” said Pritchard. “People should realize that drinking tap water is safe, economical and eco-groovy.”</p> <p>In addition, and unrelated to drinking water quality standards, the organization updates the county’s beach status web page to inform the residents about their favorite beaches. To check for current beach advisories and warnings, visit Coastkeeper’s website or download its Swim Guide app for beachgoers on the go.</p> <p>Coastkeeper also conducts monthly water quality monitoring and testing to collect data and establish water quality trends in the county’s inland waters. The organization shares this information with the public, agencies and community organizations to help the region identify and restore polluted waters.</p> <p>###</p> <p>SAN DIEGO COASTKEEPER: Founded in 1995, San Diego Coastkeeper protects and restores fishable, swimmable and drinkable waters in San Diego County. Visit us online at http://localhost/sdcoastkeeper.</p>]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>July 25 - Conservationists, Fiscal Conservatives Gather on ‘Colorado River Day’ to Promote Water Conservation, Cost-Efficiency in San Diego</title>
		<link>http://localhost/demodata/?p=106</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 25 Jul 2012 21:18:17 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[saltdevelopment]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://localhost/demodata/?p=106</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<p><em>Smarter water use needed to meet future demands on diminishing Colorado River, which provides over half of local water supply<br /></em><br /></p>  <!--more-->  <div><img class=" alignright size-full wp-image-105" style="float: right; border: 7px solid #ffffff;" alt="Save_Colorado" src="http://localhost/demodata/wp-content/uploads/2012/07/Save_Colorado.jpg" height="258" width="432" width="432" height="258" />SAN DIEGO, July 25, 2012 – Today, Save the Colorado, San Diego Coastkeeper and San Diego County Taxpayers Association hosted an event at Mission Bay Park to highlight the need for water conservation and efficiency to help the region meet its water needs. They highlighted a letter they will send to state and federal officials – U.S. Secretary of the Interior Ken Salazar, Bureau of Reclamation Director Mike Connor and the Governors in the Colorado River basin (including California Governor Jerry Brown) – insisting they implement common sense solutions like conservation and efficiency to meet the region’s future water demand.</div> <p>Currently, the Bureau of Reclamation is considering a number of options to meet future increased demand, which include unrealistic proposals like diverting the Mississippi River or shipping icebergs from Alaska.</p> <p>“Extracting all the value we can from each drop of water we already have is in the best interest of ratepayers,” stated Lani Lutar, president and CEO of the San Diego County Taxpayers Association. “Every water agency should maximize available technologies and incentives for conservation to help save the ratepayers money.”</p> <p>Many San Diegans have reduced water use in the past few years, but preliminary research from Equinox Center, a regional think tank, suggests there is still low-hanging fruit to be plucked when it comes to water efficiency in the San Diego region.</p> <p>Ann Tartre, Equinox Center executive director said, “Our initial estimates, which are conservative, show that single-family homes in San Diego could use 20-30% less than projected demand by using technologies already in existence and with no major impact on quality of life.”  Equinox plans to release its full analysis in September.</p> <p>The groups believe that Colorado River supplies should be valued as a critical natural resource in the region. San Diego imports more than 70 percent of its water from outside of the region, and a large percent of that comes from the Colorado River.</p> <p>“It’s basic math – the less water we use, the less supply we’ll need from the Colorado,” said Megan Baehrens, executive director of San Diego Coastkeeper. “San Diego’s water leaders are taking steps to increase local water supplies through water recycling. But we all have an individual responsibility to conserve more to help meet future demands for our growing population and to protect the health of the Colorado River.”</p> <p>San Diego isn’t the only area relying on the shrinking Colorado River. Over 30 million people in the Southwest U.S. rely on it to supply water for drinking, agriculture and business. The U.S. Bureau of Reclamation is working on the Colorado River Basin Study to identify ways to balance supply and future increased demand. Save the Colorado wants San Diego to start the drumbeat to ensure that conservation and cost-efficiency are top priorities in any action resulting from the study.</p> <p>“The river is an economic and ecological engine for the entire Southwest United States,” said Gary Wockner from Save the Colorado. “Businesses, citizens and nature rely on it to survive. If it continues to dry up, we’re sure to see tragic consequences in the future. I believe we can collectively work to meet future demands and keep the Colorado healthy with conservation and cost-efficiency.”</p> <p>About 50 people attended today’s event sponsored by Save the Colorado, which chose to honor the river on July 25 because the river officially received its “Colorado” name from Congress on this day in 1921. San Diego Coastkeeper, San Diego County Taxpayers Association, Surfrider Foundation San Diego and Resonance North Park, LLC signed on to the letter along with organizations and businesses from across the U.S. The Center on Policy Initiatives, Equinox Center and San Diego Chapter of the U.S. Green Building Council supported the event.</p> <p>For more information on the letter to Secretary Salazar and Governor Brown, or Colorado River Day, visit www.coloradoriverday.org.</p> <p>###</p> <p>SAVE THE COLORADO: The Save the Colorado River Campaign is a coalition of progressive companies and foundations that support non-profit environmental groups that are working to protect and restore the Colorado River and its tributaries. Visit us online at www.savethecolorado.org.</p> <p>SAN DIEGO COASTKEEPER: Founded in 1995, San Diego Coastkeeper protects and restores fishable, swimmable and drinkable waters in San Diego County. Visit us online at localhost/sdcoastkeeper.</p> <p>SAN DIEGO COUNTY TAXPAYERS ASSOCIATION: The San Diego County Taxpayers Association is a non-profit, non-partisan organization, dedicated to promoting accountable, cost-effective and efficient government and opposing unnecessary taxes and fees. Visit us online at www.sdcta.org.</p> <p> </p> <p> </p> <div></div>]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>July 26 - San Diego Coastkeeper Hires Education, Community Engagement Coordinators</title>
		<link>http://localhost/demodata/?p=107</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 25 Jul 2012 21:18:17 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[saltdevelopment]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://localhost/demodata/?p=107</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<p><em>Organization’s waterkeeper also invited to mentor Harvard law students this October<br /></em><br /></p>  <!--more-->  <div>SAN DIEGO, July 26, 2012 – This week, San Diego Coastkeeper announced two new staff members joining the organization to protect and restore swimmable, fishable and drinkable waters in San Diego County. Mallory Watson starts as a community engagement coordinator and Nia Gipson as education coordinator. Also, Waterkeeper Jill Witkowski accepted a special invitation to participate in Harvard’s Wasserstein Public Interest Fellows program.</div> <p> </p> <div>Mallory Watson received her master of science in marine affairs and policy from the University of Miami Rosenstiel School of Marine and Atmospheric Science. Working with commercial fishermen and Florida Sea Grant, her research focused on marine debris and recovering lost fishing gear along the Florida Keys Reef Tract.</div> <p> </p> <div>Prior to graduate school, Watson’s career has taken her from coast to coast in marine science research, outreach and education. From studying Hawaiian monk seals to teaching students on Catalina, in San Diego and Miami, she developed a passion for motivating communities to become leaders in responsible environmental stewardship.</div> <p> </p> <div>Nia Gipson joined San Diego Coastkeeper to oversee the implementation of education programs, especially Project SWELL (Stewardship: Water Education for Lifelong Leadership). In partnership with the City of San Diego and San Diego and Oceanside Unified School Districts, Project SWELL provides a comprehensive and hands-on water quality and pollution prevention curricula to students in the district.</div> <p> </p> <div>In Gipson’s previous rolls, she was an instructor and program assistant at the Elementary Institute of Science, a science enrichment summer camp and afterschool program that promotes hands-on learning and scientific inquiry. She also served as the education coordinator at BIOCOM Institute where she coordinated speaking opportunities for local scientists in middle and high school classrooms.</div> <p> </p> <div>Meanwhile, Jill Witkowski, the newly announced waterkeeper at San Diego Coastkeeper, was invited by Wasserstein Public Interest Fellows program of Harvard Law School as a speaker. The program invites about 20 advocate leaders from the United States each year. Witkowski says she’s honored to receive this special recognition and place San Diego Coastkeeper’s work in the national public interest arena.</div> <p> </p> <div>At the fellowship two-day event, Witkowski aspires to encourage young graduates to pursue their passion in public interest legal careers despite the bleak job forecasts and attract students to pursue a law internship with Coastkeeper.For more information, please visit San Diego Coastkeeper’s official website at localhost/sdcoastkeeper.</div> <p> </p> <div>###</div> <p> </p> <div>SAN DIEGO COASTKEEPER: Founded in 1995, San Diego Coastkeeper protects and restores fishable, swimmable and drinkable waters in San Diego County. Visit us online at http://localhost/sdcoastkeeper.</div> <div></div>]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
		<wp:post_id>107</wp:post_id>

	<item>
		<title>July 31 - Coastkeeper Celebrates Clean Water Act, Healthy Waters at Clear Blue 2012 on Aug. 5</title>
		<link>http://localhost/demodata/?p=108</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 25 Jul 2012 21:18:17 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[saltdevelopment]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://localhost/demodata/?p=108</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<p><em>Residents invited to free event to swim, kayak, jive to music in Mission Bay Park<br /></em><br /></p>  <!--more-->  <div>SAN DIEGO, July 31, 2012—On August 5, San Diego Coastkeeper hosts Clear Blue 2012 to celebrate swimmable, fishable and drinkable waters in San Diego County and the 40th anniversary of the Clean Water Act.</div> <div></div> <p> </p> <div>At the free event from noon - 5 p.m. at Ventura Cove on Mission Bay, participants can enjoy kayak racing from <a target="_blank" href="http://www.google.com/url?q=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.hikebikekayak.com&amp;sa=D&amp;sntz=1&amp;usg=AFQjCNHqolpvkut-p0I1M9KwHC_77xMdrg">Hike Bike Kayak</a>, music from DJ Electrichead, water games and food in sunny San Diego weather.</div> <div></div><p> </p> <div>The Clean Water Act was established as the basic structure to monitor the discharges of pollution into American creeks, rivers, lakes and ocean and then regulate the quality standards for those bodies of water. Clean Blue 2012 will help San Diego Coastkeeper spread awareness of water quality issues in San Diego, while enjoying the county’s aquatic playground that drives the tourism economy.</div> <div></div><p> </p> <div>Clear Blue 2012 will take place on Mission Bay’s Ventura Cove (just north east of the restroom) from noon until 5 p.m. on Sunday, August 5. Along with music and fun water activities, the event will feature free food and good company.</div> <div></div><p> </p> <div>DJ Electrichead from East Village San Diego, known for the freshest in nu-disco, house and spacey jams, will entertain the crowd with his latest musical creations. Check out his mashups on his <a target="_blank" href="http://soundcloud.com/electrichead">SoundCloud account</a>.</div> <div></div><p> </p> <div>Participants can also compete in friendly kayak and swimming races to win fun prizes. All of the event’s donations will go to protect and restore San Diego’s swimmable, fishable and drinkable waters.</div> <div></div><p> </p> <div>Coastkeeper thanks <a target="_blank" href="http://www.keenfootwear.com/us/en/">KEEN Footware</a>, <a target="_blank" href="http://www.ralphs.com/Pages/default.aspx">Ralphs</a>, <a target="_blank" href="http://www.traderjoes.com ">Trader Joe's</a>, <a target="_blank" href="http://www.hikebikekayak.com">Hike Bike Kayak</a> and <a target="_blank" href="http://www.sprouts.com">Sprouts</a> for making the event possible.The event is free and open to the public.</div> <div></div><p> </p> <div>For more information, San Diego Coastkeeper’s website at localhost/sdcoastkeeper.</div> <div></div><p> </p> <div>###</div> <div></div><p> </p> <div>SAN DIEGO COASTKEEPER: Founded in 1995, San Diego Coastkeeper protects and restores fishable, swimmable and drinkable waters in San Diego County. Visit us online at http://localhost/sdcoastkeeper.</div> <div></div>]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
		<wp:post_id>108</wp:post_id>
		<wp:post_date><![CDATA[2012-07-25 21:18:17]]></wp:post_date>
		<wp:post_date_gmt><![CDATA[2012-07-25 21:18:17]]></wp:post_date_gmt>
		<wp:comment_status><![CDATA[open]]></wp:comment_status>
		<wp:ping_status><![CDATA[open]]></wp:ping_status>
		<wp:post_name><![CDATA[july-31-coastkeeper-celebrates-clean-water-act-healthy-waters-at-clear-blue-2012-on-aug-5]]></wp:post_name>
		<wp:status><![CDATA[publish]]></wp:status>
		<wp:post_parent>0</wp:post_parent>
		<wp:menu_order>102</wp:menu_order>
		<wp:post_type><![CDATA[post]]></wp:post_type>
		<wp:post_password><![CDATA[]]></wp:post_password>
		<wp:is_sticky>0</wp:is_sticky>

	</item>
	<item>
		<title>July 31 - Coastkeeper’s Signs of the Tide Invites Community to Develop Advocacy Skills</title>
		<link>http://localhost/demodata/?p=109</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 25 Jul 2012 21:18:17 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[saltdevelopment]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://localhost/demodata/?p=109</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<p><em>Former City Councilmember Donna Frye will lead a panel of policy insiders who will share ideas for effective strategies to reach, influence decisionmakers<br /></em><br /></p>  <!--more-->  <div>SAN DIEGO, July 31, 2012— On August 7, San Diego Coastkeeper invites San Diegans to develop stronger voices and become better advocates for their communities. Donna Frye, a former City Councilmember, will join three other experts on environmental advocacy and regulatory decision-making at University of San Diego Law School from 6 p.m. – 8 p.m. to empower participants to influence policy. Community advocates from any industry will benefit from this free public forum.</div> <div></div> <p> </p> <div>Frye--who is known for her commitment to environmental leadership during her service as a councilmember--will share her own tips for influential advocacy as well as moderate the panel of presenters including:</div> <div></div> <p> </p> <div> <ul> <li><strong>Sara Wan</strong>, a former Coastal Commissioner and a coastal advocate, will share her perspective as an experienced and successful environmental activist. Wan will provide her expertise as a coastal activist supporting the protection of environmental and coastal resources.</li> <li><strong>Arthur Coe</strong>, a former staff member at Regional Water Quality Control Board, will share an inside view of regulatory decision-making and what makes effective regional board advocacy. Coe will also provide an insight on his earlier career experience while participating in water quality studies at the California Department of Water Resources.</li> <li><strong>Tony Young, </strong>San Diego City Council President, will provide an inside view of decision-making as an elected representative.</li> </ul> </div> <div></div> <p> </p> <div>Clear Blue 2012 will take place on Mission Bay’s Ventura Cove (just north east of the restroom) from noon until 5 p.m. on Sunday, August 5. Along with music and fun water activities, the event will feature free food and good company.</div> <div></div> <p> </p> <div>Along with the interactive dialogue, the participants will enjoy light food and refreshments provided by San Diego Coastkeeper.</div> <div></div> <p> </p> <div>Everyone is welcome at USD School of Law in Warren Hall, Room A3 at 5998 Alcala Park, San Diego, CA 92110 on Tuesday, Aug. 7. Parking is available in the lot adjacent to the law school or the Mission parking area. (Please <a href="http://www.google.com/url?q=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.sdchamber-members.org%2FEvents%2Fdocuments%2Fusd_campus_map.pdf&amp;sa=D&amp;sntz=1&amp;usg=AFQjCNHsX_5SdU8DbSYVTWgebNlIji4gpg" target="_blank">see campus map here</a>.) The free event runs from 6 - 8 p.m.</div> <div></div> <p> </p> <div>Visit Coastkeeper’s official website at localhost/sdcoastkeeper for more information on Signs of the Tide.</div> <div></div> <p> </p> <div>For more information, San Diego Coastkeeper’s website at localhost/sdcoastkeeper.</div> <div></div> <p> </p> <div>###</div> <div></div> <p> </p> <div>SAN DIEGO COASTKEEPER: Founded in 1995, San Diego Coastkeeper protects and restores fishable, swimmable and drinkable waters in San Diego County. Visit us online at http://localhost/sdcoastkeeper.</div> <div></div>]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>August 8 - San Diego Coastkeeper Launches Community Advisory Council at Signs of the Tide</title>
		<link>http://localhost/demodata/?p=110</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 25 Jul 2012 21:18:17 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[saltdevelopment]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://localhost/demodata/?p=110</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<p><em>Tuesday’s public forum also imparts effective advocacy advice from elected officials, advocates<br /></em><br /></p>  <!--more-->  <p>SAN DIEGO, Aug. 8, 2012—At Tuesday’s Signs of the Tide, San Diego Coastkeeper announced its search for founding members of its new Community Advisory Council, a group that will help Coastkeeper find and fix water quality issues that San Diego County communities face. The announcement followed a formal presentation by elected officials and advocates aimed at helping attendees to become more effective activists.</p> <p> </p> <div>According to Coastkeeper’s Waterkeeper Jill Witkowski, the founding members of the Community Advisory Council will represent different communities from across the county. The goal of the new advisory group is to help Coastkeeper identify water quality problems impacting</div> <div>neighborhoods in the county and collaborate on ways to solve those problems.</div> <p> </p> <div>“It’s part of our new find and fix philosophy grounded in building relationships with individuals in our communities,” said Witkowski. “After hearing advocacy advice from tonight’s panel of experts, I know this group’s passion and community leadership paired with our insider connections and legal expertise will greatly improve fishable, swimmable and drinkable waters in San Diego County.”</div> <p> </p> <div>Experts speaking at Signs of the Tide included event moderator and former Councilmember Donna Frye leading a Q&amp;A-style session with San Diego City Council President Tony Young, former staff member at San Diego Regional Water Quality Control Board Art Coe and former</div> <div>Coastal Commissioner Sara Wan.</div> <p> </p> <div>Without exception, all four speakers suggested that an individual must build credibility to become an effective advocate for the community. According to the speakers, building credibility means advocates must understand the other side, ensure accuracy, know the law that applies</div> <div>to the issue and build relationships.</div> <p> </p> <div>“Don’t only meet with me when you need something,” said Young. “Stop in to introduce yourself, who you are and what you do.” Young is the only councilmember who holds open office hours once a week.</div> <p> </p> <div>Wan added that she recommends calling or emailing decision makers to thank them for taking leadership on particular issues, even it’s not an issue that an activist is actively pushing. Because, as Frye said, “It’s all about building relationships.”</div> <p> </p> <div>One final theme throughout the evening revolved around respect—for the other side, the decision makers and the process.</div> <p> </p> <div>“Build bridges, not barriers to the other advocates because you’ll run into the same people time and time again,” said Coe.</div> <p> </p> <div>To help San Diego County activists access contact information and hearing schedules and agendas for decision-making bodies in San Diego County, Coastkeeper published a website listing all of the essential information. (http://localhost/sdcoastkeeper/act/speak-up/contact-your-representative.html)</div> <p> </p> <div>To learn more about the Community Advisory Council, please read about the group online. San Diego County residents can apply to become a Community Advisory Council member today downloading this application form. Coastkeeper will accept applications until Aug. 31, 2012. The</div> <div>nonprofit will notify selected individuals to join the council for the 2012-2013 year by October 1, 2012.</div> <p> </p> <div>For more information, please visit localhost/sdcoastkeeper.</div> <p> </p> <div>###</div> <p> </p> <div>SAN DIEGO COASTKEEPER: Founded in 1995, San Diego Coastkeeper protects and restores fishable, swimmable and drinkable waters in San Diego County. Visit us online at http://</div> <div>localhost/sdcoastkeeper.</div> <p> </p> <p> </p> <div></div>]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>August 23 - Coastkeeper Releases App to Give Residents On-The-Go Access to Events, News</title>
		<link>http://localhost/demodata/?p=111</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 25 Jul 2012 21:18:17 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[saltdevelopment]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://localhost/demodata/?p=111</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<p><em>Local smartphone technology provider, Roovy, developed iPhone app for nonprofit<br /></em><br /></p>  <!--more-->  <p>SAN DIEGO, Aug. 23, 2012 – Today, San Diego Coastkeeper, the region’s watchdog for swimmable, fishable and drinkable waters, introduces its second smartphone application. Coastkeeper worked with Roovy, Inc., a local mobile app technology provider, to create an easy way for residents to receive Coastkeeper’s latest news, updates, events, photos and more.</p> <p>“As people increasingly rely on smartphones to access news and information while on the go, Coastkeeper turned to Roovy to keep pace with these trends and ensure San Diegans have the technology they need to protect, restore and enjoy our waters,” said Megan Baehrens, Coastkeeper’s executive director.Through the app, users have a single source to access Coastkeeper’s blog, event calendar, Twitter feed, YouTube channel, photo gallery, Facebook page and more. Further enhancements, as well as an Android friendly app, are expected to be made available later this year.</p> <p>“We are confident our technology, which enables users to develop their own mobile apps without programming, will enhance Coastkeeper’s valuable efforts to inform and educate the San Diego community on safeguarding our local waterways,” said Touradj Barman, CEO of Roovy, Inc. “Coastkeeper’s app is a great demonstration of the power of the Roovy technology.”</p> <p>According to Baehrens, Roovy’s technology saves the organization the cost and inefficiency of relying on an outside developer and offers it an easy-to-use, in-house solution for creating, maintaining and updating its smartphone app. She said, “The Roovy solution is perfect for organizations like ours where resources must be focused on the core mission, but real-time communication of news and developments is also critical.”</p> <p>Along with the Coastkeeper app, the organization also has a Swim Guide, a smartphone application that shows beachgoers water quality at more than 300 beaches statewide. Both apps are free. Swim Guide is available for both <a target="_blank" href="http://itunes.apple.com/us/app/swim-guide/id435811871?mt=8&amp;ls=1">iPhone</a> and <a target="_parent" href="https://play.google.com/store/apps/details?id=ca.waterkeeper.android.swimguide">Android</a>. The official Coastkeeper app can be downloaded at the <a target="_blank" href="https://play.google.com/store/apps/details?id=ca.waterkeeper.android.swimguide">App Store</a>.</p> <p>For more information on San Diego Coastkeeper, please visit localhost/sdcoastkeeper. Please visit www.roovy.com for the information on Roovy, Inc.</p> <p>###</p> <p>SAN DIEGO COASTKEEPER: Founded in 1995, San Diego Coastkeeper protects and restores fishable, swimmable and drinkable water in San Diego County. Visit us online at http://localhost/sdcoastkeeper</p> <p>ROOVY, INC: Roovy, Inc. is a San Diego-based smartphone technology provider that enables users with no programming knowledge to create, maintain and update their own smartphone apps and aggregate all manner of digital content into a single multimedia album called a pod. Pods can be created at Roovy’s website and accessed using the Roovy iPhone and iPad app. Users can also publish their pods as stand-alone iPhone, iPad or Android apps. Visit Roovy online at http://www.roovy.com</p> <div></div>]]></content:encoded>
