	<item>
		<title>August 23 - Liquid Aloha Music Festival Brings San Diego Live Music, Cold Beer, Clean Water</title>
		<link>http://localhost/demodata/?p=112</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 25 Jul 2012 21:18:17 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[saltdevelopment]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://localhost/demodata/?p=112</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<p><em>San Diego Coastkeeper to benefit from Sept. 1 concert featuring The Expendables<br /></em><br /></p>  <!--more-->  <p>SAN DIEGO, Aug. 23, 2012 – San Diego Coastkeeper and Kona Brewing Company invite fun seekers to start Labor Day weekend with tasty beers and reggae rock sounds at Liquid Aloha Music Festival. The annual event returns to San Diego on Saturday, Sept. 1 at the Ingram Plaza, NTC at Liberty Station from 3 p.m. – 9 p.m. Kona Brewing will donate ten percent of the ticket sales to Coastkeeper to protect and restore swimmable, fishable and drinkable waters in San Diego County.</p> <p>Kona Brewing will serve Big Wave Golden Ale, its new year-round launch to the mainland, as well as Longboard Island Lager, Fire Rock Pale Ale and Wailua Wheat, all on draught.Music kicks off at 3:30 p.m. with Arden Park Roots, Natural Heights, Hi Roots, The Simpkin Project, Nervous Wreckords. Headliner, The Expendables, will take the stage at 8 p.m.</p> <p>This year’s festival will aim to have a small carbon footprint by using biodegradable cups and minimizing trash through numerous recycling stations.</p> <p>The 21-and-up tickets are available for $15 at <a target="_blank" href="http://www.brownpapertickets.com/event/262449">Brown Paper Tickets</a> and will be $20 at the door. Festival-goers also have the chance to buy a discounted membership to San Diego Coastkeeper for $40, which includes entry to Liquid Aloha Music Festival. By buying the ticket-plus-membership option or signing up for Coastkeeper membership at the event, the participants can enter to win a Kona Brewing cruiser bike and other giveaways. Festival guests will have free parking available near the gates.</p> <p>The partnership between Kona Brewing Company and San Diego Coastkeeper began in 2010. Since then, Kona Brewing has provided monetary and in-kind support to fund ongoing Coastkeeper programs. Last year, Kona Brewing raised $18,221 in gross revenue for Coastkeeper at Liquid Aloha Music Festival.</p> <p>To learn more about Kona Brewing Company, please visit http://konabrewingco.com/. Please visit localhost/sdcoastkeeper to learn more about San Diego Coastkeeper.</p> <p>###</p> <p>KONA BREWING COMPANY was started in the spring of 1994 by father and son team Cameron Healy and Spoon Khalsa, who had a dream to create fresh, local island brews made with spirit, passion and quality. It is a Hawaii-born and Hawaii-based craft brewery that prides itself on brewing the freshest beer of exceptional quality, closest to market. This helps to minimize its carbon footprint by reducing shipping of raw materials, finished beer and wasteful packaging materials. The brewery is headquartered where it began, in Kailua-Kona on Hawaii’s Big Island. It has grown into Hawaii’s largest brewery, has three restaurant sites in Hawaii and beer distribution reaching 30 states and Japan. It is the 13th largest craft brewery in the country. For more information call 808-334-BREW or www.KonaBrewingCo.com.</p> <p>SAN DIEGO COASTKEEPER: Founded in 1995, San Diego Coastkeeper protects and restores fishable, swimmable and drinkable water in San Diego County. Visit us online at http://localhost/sdcoastkeeper</p> <div></div>]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>September 11 - Save the Date for San Diego Coastkeeper’s Seaside Soiree on Nov. 15</title>
		<link>http://localhost/demodata/?p=113</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 25 Jul 2012 21:18:17 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[saltdevelopment]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://localhost/demodata/?p=113</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<p><em>Nonprofit to hold fundraising cocktail party at Del Mar Powerhouse Community Center<br /></em><br /></p>  <!--more-->  <p>SAN DIEGO, Sept. 11, 2012—On November 15, San Diego Coastkeeper will gather its supporters, donors, staff and board members to celebrate swimmable, fishable and drinkable waters during its Seaside Soiree.</p> <p>This year Coastkeeper will hold its annual fundraiser at Del Mar Powerhouse Community Center, an outside venue adjacent to the ocean. Participants will enjoy coastal sunsets, cocktails, a roaming dinner, entertainment and one-on-one access to Coastkeeper staff and board members.</p> <p>The Seaside Soiree is a fresh take on Coastkeeper’s Ocean Gala, a more traditional event that the organization had hosted for 15 years.</p> <p>Early-bird tickets for the Seaside Soiree are available for $150 until Sept. 25. VIP tickets are $250 and include hosted drinks and valet parking. Attendees can <a target="_blank" href="https://app.etapestry.com/cart/SanDiegoCoastkeeper/default/category.php?ref=1841.0.227472469">buy tickets here</a>.</p> <p>For sponsorship opportunities, contact Megan Baehrens at meganb@localhost/sdcoastkeeper or call 619-758-7743 ext. 103.</p> <p>For more information on the event and San Diego Coastkeeper, please visit localhost/sdcoastkeeper.</p> <p>###</p> <p>SAN DIEGO COASTKEEPER: Founded in 1995, San Diego Coastkeeper protects and restores fishable, swimmable and drinkable water in San Diego County. Visit us online at http://localhost/sdcoastkeeper</p> <div></div>]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
		<wp:post_id>113</wp:post_id>

	<item>
		<title>September 20 - San Diego Coastkeeper’s Water Quality Report Provides Critical Insights for Addressing Stormwater Pollution</title>
		<link>http://localhost/demodata/?p=114</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 25 Jul 2012 21:18:17 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[saltdevelopment]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://localhost/demodata/?p=114</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<p><em>Scientific data identifies priority pollution problems in the county<br /></em><br /></p>  <!--more-->  <p>SAN DIEGO, Sept. 20, 2012—Today, San Diego Coastkeeper, an organization that protects and restores swimmable, fishable and drinkable waters of San Diego County, released its <a href="learn/san-diegos-waters/water-quality-monitoring.html">watershed report</a> that analyzes several years of water quality data. The comprehensive report examines water quality in four of the county’s watersheds—Los Penasquitos, Pueblo, San Luis Rey and Tijuana. Coastkeeper presented its findings as an important tool under the proposed stormwater permit to help watershed groups identify priority pollutants and strategies to address them.</p> <p>“San Diego Coastkeeper’s data consistently point to ammonia, phosphorus and Enterococcus as the most prevalent pollutants in San Diego County,” said Travis Pritchard, Coastkeeper’s water quality lab manager. “The data also show that every watershed in the region struggles to meet the water quality health standards established by California.”</p> <p>Based on an analysis of monthly water quality samples taken in nine of the county’s 11 watersheds, the report highlights the impacts of urbanization and water quality degradation due to development of natural spaces throughout the region.</p> <p>For this reason, says Coastkeeper’s Waterkeeper Jill Witkowski, Coastkeeper encourages municipalities and regulators to use this information to identify priority pollution problems and effective strategies and tactics to improve local water quality.</p> <p>This year’s water quality report closely examines four watersheds with water quality issues indicative of other watersheds that scored similar ratings:</p> <ul> <li><strong>Water Quality Index- Good</strong>: In rapid development since the 1970s, <strong>Los Penasquitos</strong> watershed currently has high levels of total dissolved solids and fecal indicator bacteria during both the wet and dry seasons. According to Pritchard, the primary culprit is the sediment transported by the flows, which increased by over 200 percent since the development started affecting the fragile lagoon 30 years ago.</li> <li><strong>Water Quality Index- Fair</strong>: In <strong>Pueblo</strong> watershed, nutrients, bacteria and trash are its major problems, which strongly correlate with increased development. Because this watershed is the region’s most developed with mixed residential, commercial and industrial areas, the dominance of hard, impervious surfaces drives many of the urban runoff problems in the creek and contributes to the degradation of water quality in San Diego Bay.</li> <li><strong>Water Quality Index- Marginal</strong>: <strong>San Luis Rey</strong>, on the other hand, is the least developed watershed. Half of the watershed contains open space for agricultural and residential purposes. Each accounts for about 15 percent of the watershed. The high amount of agriculture causes the high nutrient concentrations found in the watershed. The San Luis Rey River is home to historic steelhead trout runs, but habitat degradation (rather than chemical pollutants) threatens their dwindling number.</li> <li><strong>Water Quality Index- Poor</strong>: In contrast to other watersheds, <strong>Tijuana</strong> watershed comes last in water quality. Poor infrastructure across the border accounts for the vast majority of water quality problems in this system. Because Tijuana River flows into the ocean, the Imperial beaches become unsafe for human contact for much of the winter.</li> </ul> <p>“Under the proposed stormwater permitting process, each watershed group and municipality would have an obligation to outline how it will minimize pollutants that reach our waterways,” said Witkowski about the report's findings in regards to the MS4 permit. “Our livelihood depends on it.”</p> <p>The proposed MS4 permit allows stormwater departments a year to write their Water Quality Improvement Plans and bring them back for 30-day public review. San Diego Coastkeeper has requested to have input as the plans are developed, specifically as the departments choose priority pollutants and select strategies to address them.</p> <p>“Now that we’ve identified the pollutants and their sources in our report, developers and municipalities have the essential tool that will help them to identify water quality problems in their area and, more importantly, address them,” said Witkowski.</p> <p>Coastkeeper’s entire water quality report <a href="learn/san-diegos-waters/water-quality-monitoring.html">can be read here</a>. To learn more about San Diego Coastkeeper and its programs, please visit localhost/sdcoastkeeper.</p> <p>###</p> <p>SAN DIEGO COASTKEEPER: Founded in 1995, San Diego Coastkeeper protects and restores fishable, swimmable and drinkable water in San Diego County. Visit us online at http://localhost/sdcoastkeeper</p> <div></div>]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
		<wp:post_id>114</wp:post_id>

		<wp:post_date_gmt><![CDATA[2012-07-25 21:18:17]]></wp:post_date_gmt>
		<wp:comment_status><![CDATA[open]]></wp:comment_status>
		<wp:ping_status><![CDATA[open]]></wp:ping_status>
		<wp:post_name><![CDATA[september-20-san-diego-coastkeepers-water-quality-report-provides-critical-insights-for-addressing-stormwater-pollution]]></wp:post_name>
		<wp:status><![CDATA[publish]]></wp:status>
		<wp:post_parent>0</wp:post_parent>
		<wp:menu_order>90</wp:menu_order>
		<wp:post_type><![CDATA[post]]></wp:post_type>
		<wp:post_password><![CDATA[]]></wp:post_password>
		<wp:is_sticky>0</wp:is_sticky>
		<category domain="category" nicename="import-cate"><![CDATA[import cate]]></category>

	</item>
	<item>
		<title>September 27 - Re-Gallery to Host Sustainable Art Show on October 13</title>
		<link>http://localhost/demodata/?p=115</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 25 Jul 2012 21:18:17 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[saltdevelopment]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://localhost/demodata/?p=115</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<p><em>Free event will show Seaside Soiree pieces, raise money for Coastkeeper</em></p> <p></p>  <!--more-->  <p>SAN DIEGO, Sept. 27, 2012—Re-Gallery, San Diego’s sustainable fine art gallery, will host San Diego Coastkeeper’s pre-Seaside Soiree reception at the gallery on October 13 from 6 p.m. - 9 p.m. Reception guests will enjoy food, music and sustainable and environmental art, including pieces from Re-Gallery’s sustainable fine artists such as the award-winning Rodrigo McCoubrey and the internationally recognized LesterCorral. The event will also share a sneak peak of a few pieces available during the silent auction at Coastkeeper’s Seaside Soiree.</p> <p>A portion of all art sales will go to Coastkeeper to protect and restore fishable, swimmable and drinkable waters in San Diego. The reception attendees will also have a chance to purchase tickets for Coastkeeper’s Seaside Soiree on November 15.</p> <p>To RSVP for the event, please call Michelle Aufmann at (858) 259-2001. The reception will be at Re-Gallery at 348 South Cedros Ave Solana Beach, CA 92075 on Saturday, Oct. 13 from 6 p.m. – 9 p.m.</p> <p>To learn more about San Diego Coastkeeper, please visit localhost/sdcoastkeeper. Visit http://regallery.org/ to learn about Re-Gallery.</p> <p>###</p> <p>SAN DIEGO COASTKEEPER: Founded in 1995, San Diego Coastkeeper protects and restores fishable, swimmable and drinkable waters in San Diego County. Visit us online at http://localhost/sdcoastkeeper</p> <p>RE-GALLERY, located at 348 South Cedros Ave Solana Beach, CA 92075, has been the San Diego resource for sustainable fine art since 2010. Providing its distinguishing clients with an alternative to traditional forms of fine art, the gallery features one-of-a-kind pieces with stories just as unique as the objects themselves. Our goal is to provide art enthusiasts and serious collectors alike with a unique artwork that will inspire their imagination as well as their environmentalism.</p> <p>SAN DIEGO COASTKEEPER: Founded in 1995, San Diego Coastkeeper protects and restores fishable, swimmable and drinkable water in San Diego County. Visit us online at http://localhost/sdcoastkeeper</p> <p> </p> <div></div>]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>October 11 - Coastkeeper Announces Members of its First Community Advisory Council</title>
		<link>http://localhost/demodata/?p=116</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 25 Jul 2012 21:18:17 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[saltdevelopment]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://localhost/demodata/?p=116</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<p><em>Group will help find and fix water quality problems in San Diego County</em></p> <p></p>  <!--more-->  <p>SAN DIEGO, Oct. 11, 2012 –– San Diego Coastkeeper announces the members of its first Community Advisory Council. This new entity includes community members who bring individual perspectives on how water pollution impacts different neighborhoods throughout the region. Members of the group will help Coastkeeper find and fix water quality issues that the communities in San Diego County face.</p> <p>"San Diego Coastkeeper’s Community Advisory Council will work with us to help us identify and solve the critical issues affecting water quality in our county," said Micah Mitrosky, the Coastkeeper board member who coordinates the council. “By connecting with these volunteers through this collaborative committee, we’re ensuring the organization has direct involvement with the community to solve everyday water pollution problems and empower the community as part of those solutions.”</p> <p>Members include:</p> <p>•	Brent Alspach, Oceanside</p> <p>•	Margarita Diaz, Tijuana</p> <p>•	Jenny Kressel , Mission Hills</p> <p>•	Taya Lazootin, College Area</p> <p>•	Harry Orgovan, Chula Vista</p> <p>•	Allison Price, Mission Valley</p> <p>•	Craig Sherman, Carmel Valley</p> <p>•	Jessica Toth, Cardiff-by-the-Sea</p> <p>•	Hector Valtierra, La Mesa and El Cajon</p> <p>•	Alberto Vasquez, Encanto</p> <p>As the inaugural Community Advisory Council, these members get to create the structure and goals of the council. The group will collaborate with organizational staff and a liaison from the board of directors to inform the organization about water quality issues in San Diego County and to help devise solutions.</p> <p>Coastkeeper received a wave of applications after announcing the launch of the council at its Signs of the Tide event on August 7. Out of the nearly 30 applicants, Coastkeeper selected ten individuals after a series of application reviews and interviews.</p> <p>San Diego Coastkeeper will formally introduce the members of the Community Advisory Council to its supporters and donors at the Seaside Soiree on November 15 at Del Mar Powerhouse Community Center. Tickets are $200 and can be purchased through Coastkeeper’s website at localhost/sdcoastkeeper.</p> <p>For more information about the Community Advisory Council, please visit localhost/sdcoastkeeper.</p> <p>###</p> <p>SAN DIEGO COASTKEEPER: Founded in 1995, San Diego Coastkeeper protects and restores fishable, swimmable and drinkable waters in San Diego County. Visit us online at http://localhost/sdcoastkeeper</p> <p> </p> <p> </p> <p> </p> <div></div>]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>October 15 - Seaworld and San Diego Coastkeeper Team Up to Keep Mission Bay Beautiful</title>
		<link>http://localhost/demodata/?p=117</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 25 Jul 2012 21:18:17 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[saltdevelopment]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://localhost/demodata/?p=117</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<p></p>  <!--more-->  <p>SAN DIEGO (Oct. 10, 2012) -- SeaWorld and San Diego Coastkeeper are teaming up to keep Mission Bay beautiful with the inaugural Mission Possible: Clean the Bay Day on Saturday, Oct. 27, 2012.  Participants can bring their boat, kayak or paddle board to join the on-water effort, either on their own or as a team with family, friends or coworkers.   Those who cannot participate on the water can join the shoreline cleanup.  The organizers will award prizes, including yearlong passes to SeaWorld, beluga interactions, penguin tours and more.  The cleanup will take place on Mission Bay from 8 to 11 a.m. and the celebration and prizes will take place at Marie Starns Park (formerly South Shores Park), from 11 a.m. to noon.</p> <p>To find out more, visit localhost/sdcoastkeeper</p> <p>Since January 2012, volunteers with San Diego Coastkeeper have removed 740 pounds of debris from beaches on Mission Bay and nearby Mission Beach.  Most of these are buoyant items, like plastic foam and plastic particles, bags, wrappers and straws that impair water quality and degrade coastal habitats, and also harm wildlife through entanglement or ingestion.  While volunteers collected these items on the shoreline, the presence of debris extends into the water as well.  Sitting at the base of the San Diego Watershed, water from inland creeks, streams, rivers, and rain events flows into Mission Bay on its way to the Pacific Ocean.  Water transports trash left on the ground or accidentally blown out of trash bins through our watershed into our coastal waters.</p> <p>SeaWorld’s Rescue Team sees first-hand the effects of marine debris because they care for animals that become entangled or ingest the items.  Every year, SeaWorld rescues an average of 200 marine mammals, many of them affected by debris or pollution, such as fishing line and gear, oil spills and general debris such as plastic bags and other trash items.  Debris also affects sea birds, especially pelicans.  In 2012 so far, SeaWorld has cared for more than 200 brown pelicans, many of which were injured or ill because of marine debris.</p> <p>Editor’s note: SeaWorld will provide a media boat for those outlets interested in covering this event.  Because there will be a limited amount of space on the boat, availability will be on a first-come, first-served basis (those interested must contact SeaWorld Public Relations in advance).</p> <p>About San Diego Coastkeeper:</p> <p>Founded in 1995, San Diego Coastkeeper protects and restores fishable, swimmable and drinkable water in San Diego County. Visit online at http://localhost/sdcoastkeeper</p> <p>About SeaWorld San Diego</p> <p>With more than 145 million visitors since its opening on March 21, 1964, SeaWorld is San Diego’s leading tourist attraction and one of the most popular marine-life parks in the world.  SeaWorld San Diego is one of 10 parks operated by SeaWorld Parks &amp; Entertainment.  A global leader in animal care and conservation, SeaWorld Parks &amp; Entertainment cares for more than 60,000 animals including 200 endangered or threatened species. This commitment extends to animals around the world--the company has contributed more than $50 million to conservation, wildlife rescue and environmental stewardship initiatives and operates one of the world’s most respected animal rescue and rehabilitation programs.  SeaWorld parks have rescued more than 20,000 orphaned, injured or ill animals over four decades; SeaWorld San Diego alone has rescued more than 6,000 animals during that time.</p> <p>--SeaWorld--</p> <p> </p> <p> </p> <div></div>]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>October 29 - Hundreds of Volunteers, Boaters Team to Clean Mission Bay</title>
		<link>http://localhost/demodata/?p=118</link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 29 Oct 2012 08:00:00 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[saltdevelopment]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://localhost/demodata/?p=118</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<p><em>Volunteers remove 433 pounds of trash from Mission Bay and Surrounding Park </em></p> <p></p>  <!--more-->  <p>SAN DIEGO (Oct. 29, 2012) – Saturday morning hundreds of volunteers on boat and land conducted a three-hour clean sweep of Mission Bay for SeaWorld and San Diego Coastkeeper’s inaugural Mission Possible: Clean the Bay Day. More than 140 participants joined the on-the-water effort by boat, kayak and paddleboard, as well as by foot for the shoreline cleanup around Marie Starns Park. In total, volunteers removed 433 pounds of trash including unusual items like a DVD, an engine pump, a can of foam cleaner and a street sign. Today’s event ended with a celebration at the park to honor volunteers and give away prizes such as yearlong passes to SeaWorld to the volunteers who removed the most unusual item, the most cigarette butts, the most trash and the group with the best team spirit. DOWNLOAD A VIDEO NEWS RELEASE and PHOTOS FROM TODAY’S EVENT.</p> <p>“Since I use the water, I feel like I should give back,” said Jenn Bethe, a Pacific Beach resident, who participated in Mission Possible and has been doing beach cleanups and kayaking for more than 20 years. “It’s like helping your playground.” As a high school teacher at El Cajon Valley High School, Bethe said she enjoyed seeing the large number of youth at today’s cleanup. When they learn to volunteer at a young age, they are more likely to continue volunteering as adults, she said.</p> <p>Since January 2012, volunteers with San Diego Coastkeeper have removed 740 pounds of debris from beaches on Mission Bay and nearby Mission Beach.  Most of these are buoyant items, like plastic foam and plastic particles, bags, wrappers and straws that impair water quality and degrade coastal habitats, and also harm wildlife through entanglement or ingestion.  While volunteers collected these items on the shoreline, the presence of debris extends into the water as well.  Sitting at the base of the San Diego Watershed, water from inland creeks, streams, rivers, and rain events flows into Mission Bay on its way to the Pacific Ocean.  Water transports trash left on the ground or accidentally blown out of trash bins through our watershed into our coastal waters.</p> <p>SeaWorld’s Rescue Team sees first-hand the effects of marine debris because they care for animals that become entangled or ingest the items.  Every year, SeaWorld rescues an average of 200 marine mammals, many of them affected by debris or pollution, such as fishing line and gear, oil spills and general debris such as plastic bags and other trash items.  Debris also affects sea birds, especially pelicans.  In 2012 so far, SeaWorld has cared for more than 200 brown pelicans, many of which were injured or ill because of marine debris. <br /><br />About San Diego Coastkeeper:<br />Founded in 1995, San Diego Coastkeeper protects and restores fishable, swimmable and drinkable water in San Diego County. Visit online at http://localhost/sdcoastkeeper<br /> <br />About SeaWorld San Diego:<br />With more than 145 million visitors since its opening on March 21, 1964, SeaWorld is San Diego’s leading tourist attraction and one of the most popular marine-life parks in the world.  SeaWorld San Diego is one of 10 parks operated by SeaWorld Parks &amp; Entertainment.  A global leader in animal care and conservation, SeaWorld Parks &amp; Entertainment cares for more than 60,000 animals including 200 endangered or threatened species. This commitment extends to animals around the world--the company has contributed more than $50 million to conservation, wildlife rescue and environmental stewardship initiatives and operates one of the world’s most respected animal rescue and rehabilitation programs.  SeaWorld parks have rescued more than 20,000 orphaned, injured or ill animals over four decades; SeaWorld San Diego alone has rescued more than 6,000 animals during that time.    <br /><br />--SeaWorld--</p> <p> </p> <p> </p> <div></div>]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>November 2 - Coastkeeper Hosts 11th Annual World Water Monitoring Day</title>
		<link>http://localhost/demodata/?p=119</link>
		<pubDate>Fri, 02 Nov 2012 21:27:51 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[saltdevelopment]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://localhost/demodata/?p=119</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<p><em>Nearly 200 students learn about water quality at Birch Aquarium in La Jolla</em></p> <p></p>  <!--more-->  <p>SAN DIEGO, November 2, 2012—As part of the global World Water Monitoring Challenge, <a href="undefined/">San Diego Coastkeeper </a>hosted nearly 200 students at its 11th Annual <a href="index.php?option=com_content&amp;view=article&amp;id=48:world-water-monitoring-challenge&amp;catid=13&amp;Itemid=52">World Water Monitoring Day</a> at Birch Aquarium. The event featured environmental and ocean themed educational activities for the school children from San Diego and Tijuana, Mexico. Coastkeeper and its event partners aimed to raise awareness and involvement in protecting water resources around the world.</p> <p>“World Water Monitoring Day gives students a chance to explore water quality issues in their communities and give those issues a global perspective,” said Mallory Watson, community engagement coordinator for San Diego Coastkeeper.</p> <p>Coastkeeper, Birch Aquarium and the San Diego County Office of Education partnered to present topics on water chemistry, marine debris, and urban runoff and demonstrate the impact of these pollution sources on water quality. In particular today, the children learned about <a href="index.php?option=com_content&amp;view=article&amp;id=30:san-diegos-areas-of-special-biological-significance&amp;catid=49&amp;Itemid=32">San Diego’s Areas of Special Biological Significance</a> located off La Jolla’s shore and what it means to protect water quality at these biologically unique sections of the state’s coast.</p> <p>“One interactive station we hosted today asked children to test water quality in different jars of fresh water that have varying amounts of garden fertilizer in them,” said Travis Pritchard, San Diego’s Coastkeeper’s lab manager. “This very visual demonstration helps students connect the seemingly average routines that they have at home to harmful effects in their local waters.”</p> <p>Today’s event brings attention to World Water Monitoring Challenge, which is an international outreach program to build public awareness and involvement in protecting water resources around the world.  It takes place from March 22-December 31. Schools and groups are invited to participate through their own water monitoring activity during this season. To order testing kits and to learn more, visit the World Water Monitoring site.</p> <p>###</p> <p>SAN DIEGO COASTKEEPER: Founded in 1995, San Diego Coastkeeper protects and restores fishable, swimmable and drinkable waters in San Diego County. Visit us online at http://localhost/sdcoastkeeper.</p> <p> </p> <p> </p>]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
		<wp:post_id>119</wp:post_id>

	<item>
		<title>November 26 - Coastkeeper Announces Water Quality Monitoring Schedule  for 2013</title>
		<link>http://localhost/demodata/?p=120</link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 26 Nov 2012 08:00:00 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[saltdevelopment]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://localhost/demodata/?p=120</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<p><em>Volunteer program essential for collecting data to protect region's water. </em></p> <p></p>  <!--more-->  <p>SAN DIEGO, November 26, 2012––The quest for clean water continues as San Diego Coastkeeper, which protects and restores fishable, swimmable, drinkable waters, released its <a target="_self" href="quick-links/events/cat/cat_id/4.html">water quality monitoring schedule for 2013</a>. <a href="act/green-events-in-san-diego/san-diego-county-water-quality-monitoring.html">The Water Quality Monitoring Program</a> sends volunteer teams to locations across the county to collect baseline data that help to identify polluted waters and reveal solutions to reduce pollution at the source. <br /><br />The 2013 schedule is:</p> <ul> <li>January 26  (volunteer training)</li> </ul> <ul> <li>February 23 </li> </ul> <ul> <li>March 16  (volunteer training)</li> </ul> <ul> <li>April 20 </li> </ul> <ul> <li>May 18  (volunteer training)</li> </ul> <ul> <li>June 22 </li> </ul> <ul> <li>July 20  (volunteer training)</li> </ul> <ul> <li>August 17 </li> </ul> <ul> <li>September 14  (volunteer training)</li> </ul> <ul> <li>October 19 </li> </ul> <ul> <li>November 16  (volunteer training)</li> </ul> <ul> <li>December 14 </li> </ul> <p>"The water quality monitoring program is almost completely volunteer based, and this year we trained our 700th volunteer,” said Travis Pritchard, Coastkeeper’s water quality lab manager. “Because our volunteers produce professional-level data, they become a vital part of the Coastkeeper team and of a larger effort by many community, government and corporate stakeholders to understanding San Diego County’s water quality and how to improve it."<br /><br />Coastkeeper’s Water Quality Monitoring Program trains volunteers to collect and analyze water samples in San Diego County’s inland rivers and streams. The organization distributes the data to government agencies throughout the state, partner organizations and community members so that decision makers and concerned residents have access to comprehensive data when making decisions about how to best address water pollution. <br /><br />Samples are analyzed in the Water Quality Lab, which adheres to stringent guidelines set by the State Department of Water Resources. Methods developed by the Environmental Protection Agency are also implemented to ensure accurate data. <br /><br />Coastkeeper is currently working to post raw and analyzed data on its website, which allows the public to see the health trends of San Diego's watersheds. <br /><br />For the first time this year, Coastkeeper compiled, analyzed and presented the data in its comprehensive <a href="learn/san-diegos-waters/water-quality-monitoring.html">Watershed Report</a>. The report revealed that elevated concentrations of ammonia, nitrates and phosphorous were present in watersheds throughout the county. It also showed that the county's creeks have high levels of fecal bacteria.<br /><br />Anyone can become a volunteer. Those interested need to sign up for one of the water quality monitoring volunteer training sessions, which are held every other month prior to the sample collection. Once trained, a volunteer can help with every water quality monitoring event. To sign up, contact our Community Engagement Coordinator at (619) 758-7743 x 131 or by email at volunteer@localhost/sdcoastkeeper<br /><br />###<br /><br />About San Diego Coastkeeper: Founded in 1995, San Diego Coastkeeper protects and restores fishable, swimmable and drinkable water in San Diego County. Visit online at http://localhost/sdcoastkeeper</p> <p> </p> <p> </p>]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>November 28 - San Diego Coastkeeper&#039;s Signs of the Tide Puts a LID on Pollution</title>
		<link>http://localhost/demodata/?p=121</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 28 Nov 2012 08:00:00 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[saltdevelopment]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://localhost/demodata/?p=121</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<p><em>Event unravels how low impact development can halt North Park's urban runoff</em></p> <p></p>  <!--more-->  <p>SAN DIEGO, Nov. 28, 2012 – Urban runoff, the single biggest threat to San Diego water, continues to impact the region’s water quality of inland and coastal waters. On Dec. 6, San Diego Coastkeeper invites residents to its Signs of the Tide: Put a LID on Pollution event to find out how Low Impact Development, an emerging development technique, can stop urban runoff, provide a low-energy water supply and save the region’s waters from pollution. This event will focus on the challenges and opportunities present in the North Park community.</p> <p>Moderated by Coastkeeper Waterkeeper Jill Witkowski, who will set the scene with updates from a regulatory process that is considering low impact development, the event also features:</p> <ul> <li>Bill Harris, supervising public information officer for the City of San Diego, who will explore why San Diego needs LID and the outcomes of using LID in our community.</li> </ul> <ul> <li>Leslie Ryan, landscape architecture department chair at the NewSchool of Architecture and Design, who will explore real-world low impact development designs to address current problems with stormwater and flooding in the North Park community.</li> </ul> <ul> <li>Shawn Weedon, senior engineer from Geocon Incorporated, who will talk about soils found around North Park and the issues and opportunities these soils present for water drainage.</li> </ul> <ul> <li>Robert Thiele, sustainable architect, who will share examples of projects from San Diego and provide an economic perspective to making LID succeed in projects.</li> </ul> <p>To highlight the real-world application of LID in San Diego, Coastkeeper partnered with landscape architecture students from the NewSchool of Architecture and Design to work on creating innovative urban designs to reduce water pollution. The students studied an existing North Park plot of land and will reveal their solutions to redeveloping that lot with low impact solutions.<br /><br />The Signs of the Tide is on Dec. 6, 2012, from 6 p.m. – 8 p.m. at Queen Bee's at 3925 Ohio Street, San Diego, CA 92104. Light food and refreshments will be provided. Event entry is $5. <a href="http://www.usgbc-sd.org/Calendar?eventId=588448&amp;EventViewMode=EventDetails">RSVP here</a> for this event. <br /><br />San Diego Green Building Council, NewSchool of Architecture and Design, City of San Diego Think Blue and North Park Mainstreet Association proudly sponsor Signs of the Tide: Put a LID on Pollution event.<br /><br />For more information, please visit localhost/sdcoastkeeper.</p> <p>###<br /><br />Founded in 1995, San Diego Coastkeeper protects the region's bays, beaches, watersheds and ocean for the people and wildlife that depend on them. We balance community outreach, education, and advocacy to promote stewardship of clean water and a healthy coastal ecosystem. For more information, visit San Diego Coastkeeper online at http://localhost/sdcoastkeeper.</p> <p> </p> <p> </p>]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>December 6 - Coastkeeper Explores Future of Low Impact Development in San Diego</title>
		<link>http://localhost/demodata/?p=122</link>
		<pubDate>Fri, 07 Dec 2012 05:11:54 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[saltdevelopment]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://localhost/demodata/?p=122</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<p><em>Experts uncover building techniques that capture rainwater, protect water quality</em></p> <p><em> </em></p>  <!--more-->  <p>SAN DIEGO, Dec. 6, 2012 – Can development put a LID on water quality pollution? That’s the question that three expert speakers tried to answer at tonight’s Signs of the Tide, San Diego Coastkeeper’s community public forum. For these speakers, LID stands for low impact development, an emerging development technique that mimics nature’s way of handling storm and water runoff.</p> <p>Urban runoff, the single biggest threat to San Diego water, continues to impact the region’s inland and coastal water quality. When water runs over paved surfaces in San Diego, it takes with it accumulated trash, oils, toxins and chemicals and washes them into the region’s waters that ultimately end up in the bays and ocean.</p> <p>“We’ve paved our way to unhealthy waters in San Diego County,” said Coastkeeper’s Waterkeeper Jill Witkowski. “But we have an opportunity in our redevelopment and new development to build our way back to clean, healthy waters.”</p> <p>The challenge in San Diego, according to Geocon Incorporated’s Senior Engineer Shawn Weedon, is that the region has a lot of clay and shallow formation materials, which don’t let water infiltrate very easily. For example, in Normal Heights, the soil is made of mudstone.</p> <p>But the good news, Weedon says, is that many low impact development techniques can work.</p> <p>“A potential solution that I like and think is very attractive is planter boxes,” said Weedon, showing how homeowners can redirect runoff from roofs into high-design planter boxes adjacent to their homes. Other potential solutions include permeable pavement, which can look like regular pavement but allows rainwater to pass through, placed over a base layer that drains to a storm drain system. He also suggested vegetated swales or basins.</p> <p>City of San Diego’s Bill Harris, another speaker at the event, shared actual LID developments in the City of San Diego, with an added note that “the City is moving forward with LID.” In his presentation, he showed examples of LID projects in the city such as a retention basin in Memorial Park and an infiltration project planned for Southcrest Park.</p> <p>“We’re taking pollutants out by giving them time to settle in and letting nature do some of the work,” said City of San Diego’s Bill Harris about the permeable pavers installed at Kellogg Park in La Jolla.</p> <p>Robert Thiele, a sustainable architect, took participants on a nine-step visual exploration of low impact development opportunities in Balboa Park. The goal, he said, is “a complete park with a sustainable water supply that can be used over and over again.”</p> <p>The long-term vision included an onsite natural water treatment plant that Thiele says will be so beautiful that families will want to bring their children to visit it. Additionally, the park’s water reclamation and distribution systems, often called purple pipe, would distribute recycled water throughout the park, all powered by solar. He also shared a vision for eco-districts throughout the City of San Diego.</p> <p>Partners for tonight’s event included San Diego Green Building Council, City of San Diego Think Blue and North Park Mainstreet Association.</p> <p>For more information, please visit localhost/sdcoastkeeper.</p> <p>###</p> <p>Founded in 1995, San Diego Coastkeeper protects the region's bays, beaches, watersheds and ocean for the people and wildlife that depend on them. We balance community outreach, education, and advocacy to promote stewardship of clean water and a healthy coastal ecosystem. For more information, visit San Diego Coastkeeper online at http://localhost/sdcoastkeeper.</p> <p> </p> <p> </p>]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>January 8 - Coastkeeper, Surfrider Announces 2012 Beach Cleanup Data 2013 Schedule</title>
		<link>http://localhost/demodata/?p=123</link>
		<pubDate>Tue, 08 Jan 2013 08:00:00 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[saltdevelopment]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://localhost/demodata/?p=123</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<p><em>Ocean Beach swings from dirtiest beach to one of this year's cleanest beaches</em></p> <p><em> </em></p>  <!--more-->  <p>SAN DIEGO, January 8, 2013–– <a href="undefined/" target="_self">San Diego Coastkeeper</a> and the <a target="_blank" href="http://sandiego.surfrider.org/">Surfrider Foundation, San Diego Chapter</a>—two of the region’s leading environmental organizations—announce results from their 2012 <a target="_self" href="blog/marine-debris/item/324-data-cards-create-2012-marine-debris-report.html">beach cleanup data collection</a>. In 2012, more than 4,000 volunteers removed almost 7,600 pounds of trash, about an average of 1.7 pounds per person. <br /><br />The two groups coordinate twice-a-month beach cleanups along San Diego’s coastline, rotating through popular beaches. This year, volunteers collected the most trash at Mission Beach while Ocean Beach traded its dirtiest ranking the last three years to become one of the cleaner beaches in 2012. <br /><br />“We had more volunteers than ever proving that San Diego loves its beaches,” said Haley Jain Haggerstone, chapter coordinator for Surfrider San Diego. “Our 2012 beach cleanup data show that bigger trash items are finding their way to the proper receptacles, but it’s the smaller pieces of debris continuing to harm our beaches.”<br /><br /><a target="_self" href="learn/marine-debris/data-from-san-diego-beach-cleanups.html">According to 2012 data</a>, cigarettes, Styrofoam fragments and plastics too small to be identified accounted for more than 60 percent of the debris collected. Of the 181,776 pieces of trash collected in 2012, nearly 40 percent was cigarette butts (a considerable increase from 2011). Plastic pieces accounted for 30 percent of the total number of items, including parts of bags, bottles, cups, straws, food wrappers and other miscellaneous plastic items. <br /><br />With the amount of cigarette butts increasing at beach cleanups each year, both Coastkeeper and Surfrider have partnerships and campaigns dedicated to reducing the amount of cigarette waste polluting San Diego's water. <br /><br />"Rather than sending cigarette butts off to a landfill, Coastkeeper is registered with TetraCycle, a company that converts hard-to-recycle and non-recyclable materials into new products," said Mallory Watson, community engagement coordinator for Coastkeeper. "At our beach cleanups this year, volunteers will collect cigarette butts in separate containers to remove them from the trash flow." Coastkeeper Waterkeeper Jill Witkowski has also joined forces with law professors and policy analysts from across the country through the Cigarette Butt Pollution Project to explore innovative legal and policy options for reducing cigarette butt waste.<br /><br />Surfrider's Hold On To Your Butts campaign actively prevents cigarette debris by installing outdoor ashcans throughout the county and distributing pocket ashtrays to smokers. According to Haggerstone, the ashtrays, along with community advocacy, have decreased cigarette butt litter by 65 percent. <br /><br />Another geographical problem area last year, according to Haggerstone, is the large number of tires that volunteers removed from the Tijuana River during special cleanups aimed at removing trash from the river before the season’s first rains flush it to the ocean. <br /><br />To help solve these pollution problems and volunteer at beach cleanups, interested community members and visitors can help at one of the 35 cleanups already in the works for 2013. Surfrider and Coastkeeper ask volunteers to bring their own reusable bags, gloves and water bottles. Volunteers can find the full cleanup schedule at <a target="_self" href="undefined/">http://localhost/sdcoastkeeper</a> or <a target="_blank" href="http://sandiego.surfrider.org/">http://www.surfridersd.org</a>.<br />###</p> <p><strong>San Diego Coastkeeper </strong></p> <p>Founded in 1995, San Diego Coastkeeper protects and restores fishable, swimmable and drinkable waters in San Diego County. For more information, visit San Diego Coastkeeper online at <a target="_self" href="undefined/">http://localhost/sdcoastkeeper</a>.</p> <p><strong>Surfrider Foundation San Diego Chapter</strong></p> <p>The Surfrider Foundation is a non-profit grassroots environmental organization dedicated to the protection and enjoyment of oceans, waves and beaches through a powerful activist network. Founded in 1984 by a handful of visionary surfers in Malibu, California, the Surfrider Foundation now maintains over 250,000 supporters, activists and members worldwide. For more information on the San Diego Chapter, go to <a href="http://sandiego.surfrider.org/">http://www.surfridersd.org</a>.</p>]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>January 15 - Coastkeeper, Surfrider Beach Cleanups Could Save Region Over $2.5 Million</title>
		<link>http://localhost/demodata/?p=124</link>
		<pubDate>Tue, 15 Jan 2013 08:00:00 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[saltdevelopment]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://localhost/demodata/?p=124</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<p><em>New Report Contracted by EPA Estimates Litter Management Costs for California Cities</em></p> <p><em> </em></p>  <!--more-->  <p>SAN DIEGO January 15, 2013–– <a href="undefined/">San Diego Coastkeeper</a> and the <a href="http://sandiego.surfrider.org/">Surfrider Foundation, San Diego Chapter</a>—two of the region’s leading environmental organizations—host volunteer beach cleanups that could save the region approximately $2.5 million annually in beach debris cleanup.</p> <p>According to a release today, the <a target="_blank" href="http://www.epa.gov/">Environmental Protection Agency</a> (EPA) contracted <a target="_blank" href="http://www.kierassociates.net/">Kier Associates</a> to <a target="_blank" href="http://www.epa.gov/region9/marine-debris/cost-w-coast-debris.html">quantify the amount</a> that 90 cities throughout California, Oregon and Washington watersheds are spending to clean up litter and prevent trash from entering our oceans. The report estimates the average city spends $.83 per person for beach and waterway cleanups. When extrapolated across San Diego County, with a population of just over 3.1 million, that amounts to over $2.5 million.</p> <p>In 2012, more than 4,000 volunteers removed almost 7,600 pounds of trash, about an average of 1.7 pounds per person. Rotating through popular beaches throughout San Diego’s coastline, the two groups coordinate twice-a-month beach cleanups together, in addition to numerous special cleanups throughout the year. Last year, volunteers collected the most trash at Mission Beach while Ocean Beach traded its dirtiest ranking the last three years to become one of the cleaner beaches in 2012.</p> <p>“Instead of leaving debris cleanup solely to the governments, at the cost of taxpayers, our volunteer-based cleanups are good for the region’s environmental and economic health,” said Mallory Watson, community engagement coordinator for Coastkeeper.</p> <p><a target="_blank" href="learn/marine-debris/data-from-san-diego-beach-cleanups.html">According to 2012 data</a>,  cigarettes, Styrofoam fragments and plastics too small to be identified  accounted for more than 60 percent of the debris collected. Of the  181,776 pieces of trash collected in 2012, nearly 40 percent was  cigarette butts (a considerable increase from 2011). Plastic pieces  accounted for 30 percent of the total number of items, including parts  of bags, bottles, cups, straws, food wrappers and other plastic items.</p> <p>"Litter generally travels before it hits our beaches, so the best way to keep our water clean is to make sure the litter is caught and disposed of early," said Haley Jain Haggerstone, chapter coordinator for Surfrider San Diego.<br />The report estimates the average cost for comprehensive litter control programs in a region the size of San Diego County could cost as much as $20 million.</p> <p>To help solve these pollution problems and volunteer at beach cleanups, interested community members and visitors can help at one of the 35 cleanups already in the works for 2013. Surfrider and Coastkeeper ask volunteers to bring their own reusable bags, gloves and water bottles. Volunteers can find the full cleanup schedule at <a href="undefined/">http://localhost/sdcoastkeeper</a> or <a href="http://sandiego.surfrider.org/">http://www.surfridersd.org</a>.</p> <p><strong>### </strong></p> <p><strong>San Diego Coastkeeper </strong></p> <p>Founded in 1995, San Diego Coastkeeper protects and restores fishable, swimmable and drinkable waters in San Diego County. For more information, visit San Diego Coastkeeper online at <a href="undefined/">http://localhost/sdcoastkeeper.</a><strong><br /></strong></p> <p><strong>Surfrider Foundation San Diego Chapter</strong></p> <p>The Surfrider Foundation is a non-profit grassroots environmental organization dedicated to the protection and enjoyment of oceans, waves and beaches through a powerful activist network. Founded in 1984 by a handful of visionary surfers in Malibu, California, the Surfrider Foundation now maintains over 250,000 supporters, activists and members worldwide. For more information on the San Diego Chapter, go to <a href="http://sandiego.surfrider.org/">http://www.surfridersd.org</a>.</p>]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>January 29 - Coastkeeper Welcomes New Member to its Board of Directors</title>
		<link>http://localhost/demodata/?p=125</link>
		<pubDate>Tue, 29 Jan 2013 08:00:00 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[saltdevelopment]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://localhost/demodata/?p=125</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<p><em>Organization also announces its 2013 Executive Committee<br /></em></p> <p><em> </em></p>  <!--more-->  <p>SAN DIEGO, January 29, 2013––San Diego Coastkeeper, the region's leading environmental nonprofit protecting and restoring fishable, swimmable and drinkable waters in San Diego County, welcomes Sue Stewart to its board of directors and announces its 2013 executive committee. <br /><br />Captain Stewart served nearly 24 years as an attorney in the United States Navy's Judge Advocate General's Corps. With an LLM in environmental law, and having handled a broad array of assignments, Captain Stewart brings a wealth of legal experience to the board of directors. She has provided in-depth legal and policy analysis to senior government executives on domestic and international environmental matters, including on issues in regards to the Clean Water Act, Clean Air Act, Marine Mammal Protection Act, Endangered Species Act, Coastal Zone Management Act, International Convention for the Prevention of Pollution from Ships, and National Environmental Protection Act.   <br /><br />In addition to the new board member, Coastkeeper also released its lineup of 2013 executive committee members:<br /><br />•    President: Jo Brooks, retired attorney in international environmental law for the Department of State.<br />•    Vice President, Sandy Edwin Kaupp, medical researcher, U.S. Navy<br />•    Vice President and Interim Treasurer, Harriet Lazer, retired/former CFO at The Walker Group <br />•    Secretary, Eleanor Musick, partner at Procopio, Cory, Hargreaves &amp; Savitch LLP<br /><br />Coastkeeper's board of directors currently has ten members.</p> <p><strong>### </strong></p> <p><strong>San Diego Coastkeeper </strong></p> <p>Founded in 1995, San Diego Coastkeeper protects and restores fishable, swimmable and drinkable waters in San Diego County. For more information, visit San Diego Coastkeeper online at <a href="undefined/">http://localhost/sdcoastkeeper.</a><strong><br /></strong></p> <p> </p>]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
		<wp:post_id>125</wp:post_id>

	<item>
		<title>January 29 - Coastkeeper Opens Coastal 2013 Champions Nominations</title>
		<link>http://localhost/demodata/?p=126</link>
		<pubDate>Tue, 29 Jan 2013 08:00:00 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[saltdevelopment]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://localhost/demodata/?p=126</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<p><em>Organization will hold awards breakfast in honor of World Ocean's Day. </em></p> <p><em> </em></p>  <!--more-->  <p>SAN DIEGO, January 29, 2013 – San Diego Coastkeeper announced its  annual Coastal Champions nominations, celebrating the people, businesses  and organizations taking initiative in protecting and restoring San  Diego County’s waters. On June 4, honoring World Oceans Day, Coastkeeper  will announce seven winners who demonstrated leadership in different  areas of water protection. <br /><br />The awards include:</p> <ul> <li><strong>Runoff Rock Star</strong>: This award is for actions taken to reduce  urban runoff through best practices, such as low impact development,  pollution prevention and urban waste reduction. </li> </ul> <ul> <li><strong>Water Wise</strong>: This award is for achievement in water-friendly  landscaping techniques, such as water conservation and the use of  methods to promote healthy environmental restoration with native plants  and natural growth.</li> </ul> <ul> <li><strong>Marine Conservation</strong>: This award recognizes efforts to  advocate for ocean conservation programs, including the monitoring and  implementing of techniques and innovations dealing with marine protected  areas (MPAs) or other conservation areas of concern.</li> </ul> <ul> <li><strong>Find &amp; Fix</strong>: This award is for the success in a program,  project or idea that first finds a pollution problem, and then takes  action to fix that pollution problem in the community.</li> </ul> <ul> <li><strong>Blue Tech</strong>: The nomination goes to exceptional innovation in  the development and or use of technology to protect and restore  fishable, swimmable drinkable waters in San Diego County.</li> </ul> <ul> <li><strong>Lighthouse Award</strong>: This award is for a lifetime achievement in  advancing fishable, swimmable, drinkable waters in San Diego County.  Coastkeeper's board of directors will select the award recipient. </li> </ul> <ul> <li><strong>Volunteer of the Year</strong>: This award recognizes the efforts of  one of our many volunteers who have gone above and beyond. Coastkeeper  staff will select this recipient. </li> </ul> <ul> <li><strong>ASBS Award</strong>: San Diego has two recognized Areas of Special  Biological Significance (ASBS) in need of special water quality  protections. The ASBS Award is a special recognition, in addition to one  of the above awards, for effort and achievement to improve water  quality of ASBS.</li> </ul> <p>Save the date for the awards breakfast at the Birch Aquarium at Scripps in La Jolla on June 4, 2013.<br /><br />For  nominations and tickets, sign up for Coastkeeper’s newsletter. Check  back on February 1 at Coastkeeper’s World Oceans Day and Coastal  Champions 2013 page for more details. <br /><br />If you are interested in  sponsorship opportunities, want to reserve a table or place your name on  the nomination materials, please contact San Diego Coastkeeper  Executive Director Megan Baehrens at meganb@localhost/sdcoastkeeper or call at  619-758-7743 ext. 103. <br /><br />For more information, please visit <a href="localhost/sdcoastkeeper/">localhost/sdcoastkeeper</a>.</p> <p><strong>### </strong></p> <p><strong>San Diego Coastkeeper </strong></p> <p>Founded in 1995, San Diego Coastkeeper protects and restores  fishable, swimmable and drinkable waters in San Diego County. For more  information, visit San Diego Coastkeeper online at <a href="undefined/">http://localhost/sdcoastkeeper.</a><strong><br /></strong></p> <p> </p> <p> </p>]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>February 26 - Board of Supervisors Votes to Pursue Faster Beach Water Quality Testing</title>
		<link>http://localhost/demodata/?p=127</link>
		<pubDate>Tue, 26 Feb 2013 18:38:52 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[saltdevelopment]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://localhost/demodata/?p=127</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<p><em>Coastkeeper applauds county officials for move that could significantly reduce lag time between testing and notifying the public of beach safety concerns </em></p> <p><em> </em><em></em></p>  <!--more-->  <p>SAN DIEGO February 26, 2013–– <a>San Diego Coastkeeper</a>, an organization that protects and restores fishable, swimmable and drinkable waters, thanks San Diego County Board of Supervisors for voting today in favor of pilot testing faster beach water quality testing. If proven successful in San Diego County, the new rapid detection methods could produce results in as few as four hours, when the current turnaround takes 24 – 48 hours.</p> <p>“We see two significant improvements that will come from this—we can get people out of the water faster when it’s unsafe and return them sooner when it becomes safe,” said Coastkeeper Waterkeeper Jill Witkowski. “With the county’s large number of recreational water users and our vibrant tourism economy, these tests are critical to protect our health and economy.”</p> <p>Called quantitative polymerase chain reaction (qPCR), the new method removes the culturing process necessary in the current testing, which can take up to 48 hours. In as few as four hours, the qPCR method produces results showing the levels of harmful bacteria present in the water.</p> <p>According to an agenda item memorandum put forward to the full council by Chairman Greg Cox, the Southern California Coastal Water Research Project performed a successful pilot project study in Orange County to test the new method and determine if it could work along the state’s diverse coastline. The County’s yearlong localized study would begin April 1, 2013, to evaluate when and where the County’s Department of Environmental Health could effectively and efficiently measure the county’s beach water quality. According to Cox, the total study would cost $59,000.</p> <p>Currently, the Department of Environmental Health tests 80 county beaches using the culture-based method. San Diego Coastkeeper shares resulting beach statuses and advisories in its <a href="learn/san-diegos-waters/coastal-water.html">interactive countywide map</a> and its <a href="act/media-center/coastkeeper-apps.html">free Swim Guide app</a>.</p> <p>###</p> <p>San Diego Coastkeeper</p> <p>Founded in 1995, San Diego Coastkeeper protects and restores fishable, swimmable and drinkable waters in San Diego County. For more information, visit San Diego Coastkeeper online at <a>http://localhost/sdcoastkeeper</a>.</p> <p> </p> <p> </p>]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>March 12 - Coastkeeper&#039;s Community Advisory Council Launches LEAP</title>
		<link>http://localhost/demodata/?p=129</link>
		<pubDate>Tue, 26 Feb 2013 18:38:52 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[saltdevelopment]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://localhost/demodata/?p=129</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<p>Five-month mentorship program aimed at high school students</p> <p><em> </em><em></em></p>  <!--more-->  <p>SAN DIEGO, March 12, 2013 – Are you a motivated high school student with a passion for our environment? If you want to take that passion and put it into action,<a> </a><a target="_blank">San Diego Coastkeeper</a> wants you. Coastkeeper’s Community Advisory Council is looking for a few good youth environmentalists to apply for Coastkeeper LEAP, its newly devised mentorship program.</p> <p>Coastkeeper LEAP will pull together a small group of high school students to participate in a five-month education and mentorship program. Selected students will attend monthly field trips and workshops highlighting environmental concerns, initiatives and careers in San Diego. Paired with one or more members of Coastkeeper’s Community Advisory Council, students will develop a project focused on the environmental issue of their choice and present it at the conclusion of the program during a celebratory event.</p> <p>Selected students will meet on Saturday, May 11 for a kick-off event with <a>San Diego Coastkeeper</a> staff and its Community Advisory Council members. Students will get paired with mentors for the duration of the program to guide the development of their independent projects on the topic of their choice. Coastkeeper LEAP will meet as a group on the second Saturday of each month from May through October for educational, volunteer and hands-on experiences in the environmental field.</p> <p>The final meeting on October 12 will serve as an awards lunch, honoring the work of Coastkeeper LEAP students and offering an opportunity to present their work.</p> <p>To apply, interested students can submit this <a href="http://localhost/demodata/wp-content/uploads/2013/02/LEAP_Information.docx">application</a> and/or any questions to volunteer@localhost/sdcoastkeeper or 619-758-7743 x131</p> <p>###</p> <p>SAN DIEGO COASTKEEPER: Founded in 1995, San Diego Coastkeeper protects and restores fishable, swimmable and drinkable waters in San Diego County. Visit us online at http://localhost/sdcoastkeeper.</p> <p> </p> <p> </p> <p> </p>]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>March 15 - San Diego Coastkeeper Reaches Agreement with Department of Defense to Reduce Sewage Spills at Camp Pendleton</title>
		<link>http://localhost/demodata/?p=130</link>
		<pubDate>Fri, 15 Mar 2013 14:19:48 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[saltdevelopment]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://localhost/demodata/?p=130</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<p></p>  <!--more-->  <p>SAN DIEGO, March 15, 2013 – This week <a href="localhost/sdcoastkeeper">San Diego Coastkeeper</a> and the Department of Defense announced they have settled litigation to reduce the number of sewage spills at Camp Pendleton. Under the Clean Water Act, a federal law that governs water pollution, Coastkeeper filed suit on April 18, 2011, to address Camp Pendleton’s upward trend in the number of sewage spills.</p> <p>This week’s agreement formalized a commitment by the Department of Defense to reduce the number of Camp Pendleton sewage spills to ten or less each year by 2017. It also ensures that Camp Pendleton will alert Coastkeeper about spills larger than 50,000 gallons or spills that result in a beach closure. Coastkeeper, which protects and restores fishable, swimmable, drinkable waters, will use that information to update the public about human and environmental risks through its <a href="learn/san-diegos-waters/coastal-water.html">beach status website</a> and <a href="act/media-center/coastkeeper-apps.html">Swim Guide phone app.</a></p> <p>“The Department of Defense plays an important role in our region, so it’s encouraging to see its dedication to ensure clean and safe waters for its troops, our community and the environment,” said Jill Witkowski, Coastkeeper’s waterkeeper</p> <p>The agreement outlines a goal of reduced number of sewage spills for each year until 2017, when Camp Pendleton should see ten or less in each year. Provisions in the settlement allow for the agreement to cease before 2017 should the Department of Defense reach ten or less spills for two consecutive years before 2017. As part of the agreement, Coastkeeper will earn reasonable attorney and expert fees.</p> <p>According to Witkowski, another key component of the agreement is a pledge from both parties to build stronger working relationships that will help address issues in the future without resorting to lawsuits.</p> <p>###</p> <p>SAN DIEGO COASTKEEPER: Founded in 1995, San Diego Coastkeeper protects and restores fishable, swimmable and drinkable waters in San Diego County. Visit us online at http://localhost/sdcoastkeeper.</p> <p> </p> <p> </p>]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>March 27 - Belly Up Presents 2nd Annual Ocean Commotion Concert on March 27</title>
		<link>http://localhost/demodata/?p=131</link>
		<pubDate>Tue, 26 Feb 2013 18:38:52 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[saltdevelopment]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://localhost/demodata/?p=131</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<p>Headlined by The Barnwell Shift, this event will benefit Coastkeeper</p> <p><em> </em><em></em></p>  <!--more-->  <p>SAN DIEGO, March 19, 2013 – On Wednesday, March 27, <a href="index.php">San Diego Coastkeeper</a> invites the San Diego community to rock for a cause at <a href="http://www.bellyup.com/event/ocean-commotion/">Belly Up Tavern’s 2nd Annual Ocean Commotion Concert</a>.  Several up-and-coming local bands will return to Solana Beach to perform in celebration and support of San Diego’s inland and coastal waters. Bands include The Barnwell Shift, Big Penny and the Blue Moonies.</p> <p>Known for their progressive, yet playful “shift rock,” The Barnwell Shift consists of a talented trio of musicians who shift musical instruments and genres while artfully blending together the sounds of funk, folk and rock. Hailing from Oceanside, The Barnwell Shift seeks to challenge the traditional one-person, one-instrument musical norms while eliciting a truly unique crowd response filled with their smooth and shifty grooves.</p> <p>Also returning for the 2nd Annual Ocean Commotion is Big Penny, a four-piece band who calls North San Diego’s Valley Center their home.  Finding their musical inspiration within the banjo, guitar, harmonica, organ, drums, melodica, bass and mandolin, Big Penny cohesively blends together the sounds of rock, original folk, and dark country into an organic and unforgettable musical experience.</p> <p>Capping off what is sure to be a funky fresh night to remember, San Diego’s own Blue Moonies will perform to the sounds of reggae, rock, and soul.  With their vintage keyboards and tube amps, the Blue Moonies will take their Encinitas surf rock and combine it with reggae influences and soulful grooves on Belly Up’s stage in Solana Beach.</p> <p>Be sure to attend this <a href="http://www.bellyup.com/event/ocean-commotion/">Belly Up show</a> for exciting musical performances and a chance to shake it up with the friends and crew of San Diego Coastkeeper.  Enter in an opportunity drawing for a chance to win weekend vacation stays at Grand Pacific Resorts, a Signature Barr surfboard with one-of-a-kind artwork by local artist Martin Nasim, surf and skate apparel, gift certificates to North County breweries and restaurants, and much more.</p> <p>Party even harder knowing that all proceeds, including but not limited to every drawing ticket and every dance move, will benefit San Diego Coastkeeper’s work to protect and restore fishable, swimmable and drinkable water in San Diego County.</p> <p>Tickets to this March 27 event are available via phone through 858-481-8140, online through <a href="http://bellyupsolanabeach.frontgatesolutions.com/choose.php?a=1&amp;lid=78539&amp;eid=88566">www.bellyup.com</a> or in person at The Belly Up Tavern, 143 S. Cedros Ave, Solana Beach, CA 92075.</p> <p>Doors will open at 7 p.m. for this is a 21-and-up event.</p> <p>For more information about this event, please visit Coastkeeper’s website at localhost/sdcoastkeeper.</p> <p>###</p> <p>SAN DIEGO COASTKEEPER: Founded in 1995, San Diego Coastkeeper protects and restores fishable, swimmable and drinkable waters in San Diego County. Visit us online at http://localhost/sdcoastkeeper.</p> <p> </p> <p> </p> <p> </p> <p> </p>]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>March 21 - Coalition Supports City Council Committee’s Position on Water Purification</title>
		<link>http://localhost/demodata/?p=132</link>
		<pubDate>Tue, 26 Feb 2013 18:38:52 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[saltdevelopment]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://localhost/demodata/?p=132</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<p>Broad coalition urging city leaders to move forward with safe, reliable options for drinking water in San Diego</p> <p><em> </em><em></em></p>  <!--more-->  <p>SAN DIEGO, March 21, 2013 – <a href="http://sdwatersupply.com/">The Water Reliability Coalition</a> (WRC), a broad-based affiliation of environmental, consumer, business, labor, development, taxpayer and technical organizations, supports the City of San Diego’s Natural Resources &amp; Culture committee’s decision to move forward in implementing water purification in the City of San Diego.  Earlier today, before the council committee voted unanimously to support water purification, WRC members stood beside Mayor Bob Filner, Council President Todd Gloria, and council members David Alvarez and Lorie Zapf to encourage city leaders to take the steps needed to implement water purification.</p> <p>Four years ago, the City of San Diego began a "demonstration project" to show that advanced water treatment technologies can make water safe enough to augment our water supply. Today, the committee voted to direct City staff to develop a plan and timeline for next steps to implement water purification in San Diego. The plan is due in 90 days. The committee also wanted to ensure the plan maximizes our water supply and reduces the need for upgrades at the Point Loma Wastewater Treatment Plant. Doing so has the potential to save ratepayers nearly $1 billion in upgrades at the plant.</p> <p>"We're thankful to see positive results and continuing momentum with water purification in San Diego," said Jill Witkowski, <a href="index.php">San Diego Coastkeeper's</a> waterkeeper and WRC Co-Chair. "However, time is of the essence — taxpayer dollars, the environment and our water supply all are at stake. We hope to see the City move expeditiously with its next steps."</p> <p>“City ratepayers simply cannot continue to sustain rate increases with no end in sight,” said WRC Co-Chair and San Diego County Taxpayers Association Interim President &amp; CEO Chris Cate. “Taking advantage of reliable, safe water supply opportunities like water purification can help alleviate increases while providing a local source of drinking water.”</p> <p>Water Reliability Coalition Co-founder and Equinox Center Executive Director Lani Lutar said: "Taking the water purification project to the next stage is the environmentally responsible approach to enhancing the region's water reliability. While we must continue to embrace conservation opportunities, this new source of water is critical to the region's economic prosperity and our quality of life.”</p> <p>The Coalition believes recycling water for potable use can be an important part of San Diego’s water supply portfolio diversification and could provide one of the most cost-effective and environmentally friendly options to enhance local water supplies.</p> <p>###</p> <p>The Water Reliability Coalition is a broad-based affiliation of environmental, consumer, business, labor, development, taxpayer and technical organizations that have come together to support exploration of Indirect Potable Reuse as a potential strategy to develop a safe, reliable, sustainable &amp; cost-effective local water supply.</p> <p>Coalition members include: BIOCOM; Building Industry Association; Building Owners and Managers Association, San Diego Chapter; Business Leadership Alliance; Citizens Coordinate for Century 3; Coastal Environmental Rights Foundation; Empower San Diego; Endangered Habitats League; Environmental Health Coalition; Equinox Center; Friends of Infrastructure; Industrial Environmental Association; National Association of Industrial and Office Properties, San Diego Chapter;  San Diego and Imperial Counties Labor Council; San Diego Audubon Society; San Diego Regional Economic Development Corporation; San Diego Coastkeeper; San Diego County Taxpayers Association; San Diego Regional Chamber of Commerce; San Diego River Park Foundation; Surfrider Foundation, San Diego Chapter; Sustainability Alliance of Southern California; Utility Consumers’ Action Network</p> <p> </p>]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>

		<wp:ping_status><![CDATA[open]]></wp:ping_status>
		<wp:post_name><![CDATA[coalition-supports-city-council-committees-position-on-water-purification]]></wp:post_name>
		<wp:status><![CDATA[publish]]></wp:status>

	<item>
		<title>March 28 - Coastkeeper Welcomes Four Members to its Board of Directors</title>
		<link>http://localhost/demodata/?p=133</link>
		<pubDate>Tue, 26 Feb 2013 18:38:52 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[saltdevelopment]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://localhost/demodata/?p=133</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<p>Coastkeeper welcomes Lee Barken, Everett DeLano, Stewart Halpern, and George Yermanos to its board of directors.</p> <p><em> </em><em></em></p>  <!--more-->  <p>SAN DIEGO, March 28, 2013––<a href="index.php">San Diego Coastkeeper</a>, an environmental organization that protects and restores fishable, swimmable, and drinkable waters in San Diego County, welcomes Lee Barken, Everett DeLano, Stewart Halpern, and George Yermanos to its <a href="about-us/board.html">board of directors</a>.</p> <p>According to Board of Directors President <a href="about-us/board.html#David">Jo Brooks</a>, the new members’ diverse professional and environmental experiences will significantly increase the board’s capability to support Coastkeeper’s mission and staff.</p> <p>Lee Barken is the energy and cleantech practice leader at Haskell &amp; White, LLP, one of the largest independently owned accounting and business advisory firms in Southern California.  He specializes in renewable energy project finance, public policy analysis, and environmental commodities consulting.  3A CPA and LEED accredited professional, Barken is also an active member of the boards of <a href="http://www.cleantechsandiego.org/">CleanTECH</a><a href="http://www.cleantechsandiego.org/"> San Diego</a> and the San Diego Venture Group and serves as treasurer on the board of directors at the San Diego Workforce Partnership.  He resides in Chula Vista.</p> <p><a href="http://www.delano-delano.com/">Everett DeLano</a> is an attorney who specializes in land use and environmental law, with a commitment to preserving and protecting communities and the natural environment. With expertise encompassing the California Environmental Quality Act (CEQA) and the Clean Water Act, he represents homeowners’ associations, non-profit organizations, and neighborhood groups and individuals. Earlier in his career, he worked with the Natural Resources Defense Council in Los Angeles, the <a href="http://www.sierraclub.org/">Sierra Club</a> Legal Defense Fund in Denver, and the Land and Water Fund of the Rockies in Boulder, Colorado. DeLano lives in Valley Center and his firm, DeLano &amp; DeLano, is based in Escondido.</p> <p><a href="http://www.freeflightbirds.org/content/stewart-halpern">Stewart Halpern</a> has a broad business background with over 30 years of experience as the senior financial executive of companies such as San Diego-based Mad Catz Interactive, videogame publisher Rock Star Games, and entertainment entrepreneur Russell Simmons’ Rush Communications, along with extensive Wall Street experience as a sell-side equity analyst and investment banker.  Since stepping down as CFO from Mad Catz in late 2010, he has been independently advising a number of private companies on strategic, financial and operational matters while also serving as the treasurer on the board of <a href="http://www.freeflightbirds.org/">Free Flight</a>, a nonprofit exotic bird sanctuary in Del Mar. Halpern is a La Jolla resident.</p> <p><a href="http://www.sudprop.com/george-m-yermanos-csm.html">George Yermanos</a> is the vice president and director of property management for <a href="http://www.sudprop.com/">Sudberry Properties</a>, a San Diego based real estate development and asset management firm that emphasizes long-term environmental sustainability in its properties and practices. George oversees a retail portfolio of approximately 2.5 million square feet.  A certified shopping center manager (CSM) and former chairperson of the International Council of Shopping Centers, San Diego, he has 25 years of experience focused on retail and office construction and management in the San Diego region.  He lives in Encinitas.</p> <p>###</p> <p>San Diego Coastkeeper</p> <p>Founded in 1995, San Diego Coastkeeper protects and restores fishable, swimmable, and drinkable waters in San Diego County. For more information, visit San Diego Coastkeeper online at <a href="index.php">http://localhost/sdcoastkeeper</a>.</p> <p> </p>]]></content:encoded>
